translated: then here also the mere non-perception of a difference is not the totality of conditions for doubt.

analyzed: kintu
translated: But rather, it is accompanied by the recollection of the alternatives and so on.

original: tathā ca katipayakakṣyānantaraṃ kutracitkoṭyasmaraṇasya kutracidutkaṭaviṣayāntarasaṃcāras kutracijjijñāsābhāvasya kutracit yatvādau śraddhayā
analyzed: tathā ca katipaya kakṣyā anantaram kutracid koṭi asmaraṇasya kutracid utkaṭa viṣaya antara saṃcāraḥ kutracid jijñāsā abhāvasya kutracid
translated: And thus, after a few alternatives, in some cases there is no recollection of the alternatives, in some cases there is intense engagement with another object, in some cases there is no desire to know, in some cases there is faith in the self-evident,

analyzed: siddham punar nyāyena sādhitam
translated: and what is established by faith is again proved by reasoning.

original: iti nyāyena svārasikaviśvāsasyā vaśyakatvānna sarvatra śaṅkā/
analyzed: iti nyāyena svārasika viśvāsasya ā vaśyaka tvāt na sarvatra śaṅkā
translated: Thus, by the principle that the natural confidence must necessarily be present, there is no doubt everywhere.

analyzed: evam śaṅkāyām
translated: Thus, when there is doubt,

analyzed: anumāna aprāmāṇya vādī cārvākaḥ eva iti cārvākasya iti uktam
translated: only the Cārvāka who denies the validity of inference is mentioned, hence it is said 'of the Cārvāka'.

analyzed: sarva khaṇḍana vādī maṇḍanamiśraḥ upi advaita vādī iti advaitinā upi iti uktam
translated: It has been said that even Maṇḍanamiśra, who advocates the refutation of everything, is a non-dualist, i.e., an Advaitin.

analyzed: anena sva kriyā virodhaḥ upapāditaḥ
translated: By this, the contradiction with his own actions is established.

original: paramukhena samādhiṃ vācayitvā samaṃ prakṛtepītyāha yadīti//
analyzed: para mukhena samādhim vācayitvā samam prakṛte api iti āha yadi iti
translated: Having made the opponent state the answer, he says that the same applies to the present case also, with 'yadi' (if).

original: vyabhicārapadaṃ na ka /ṭa /ga / tvadakteti nāstirā / /rādikarā / /yatrādau ṭa /ga /rā / /sya cāvaṭa /ga /rā /
analyzed: vyabhicāra padam na yatra ādau ṭagarā
translated: The word 'vyabhicāra' (deviation) is not found in the text.
The third chapter of the Nyāyadyuti-yuta-tarkatāṇḍava.

original: na hi kaścidapi yāvajjīvaṃ koṭismaraṇa dhārāyāmeva vyāpriyamāṇonubhūyate/
analyzed: na hi kaścid api yāvajjīvam koṭi smaraṇa dhārāyām eva vyāpriyamāṇaḥ anubhūyate
translated: No one is ever seen engaged solely in the stream of remembering the conclusion for as long as he lives.

analyzed: na ca avirala lagra āśaṅkā ādhārā anubhūyate
translated: Nor is it experienced that there is a continuous stream of doubt.

analyzed: yena phala balāt koci smaraṇa ādi dhārāyāḥ avicchedaḥ kalpyeta
translated: By which, due to the power of the result, the stream of remembering etc. could be imagined to be uninterrupted.

original: anyathā pratyakṣepi viśeṣadarśanadhārāyāṃ vedepa vedanirdeṣatva jñānadhārāyāṃ ca vyāpriyeta/ uktaṃ hi
analyzed: anyathā viśeṣa darśana dhārāyām jñāna dhārāyām ca vyāpriyeta uktam hi
translated: Otherwise, even in perception, it would apply to the stream of seeing the particular, and in the Veda, to the stream of knowing the Veda to be faultless. For it has been said:

analyzed: yāvat śakti parīkṣāyām upajīvyasya bādhane
translated: In the examination up to the extent of ability, in the contradiction of what is depended upon,

analyzed: doṣaḥ na a śodhite doṣaḥ upajīvya tvam astu alam
translated: there is a fault. If it is not purified, let there be the fault of being depended upon, that is enough.

original: iti/ dvitīyepi svārthānumāne śaṅkādhāyakaṃ na tāvtaprativādivākyam/
analyzed: iti dvitīye api sva artha anumāne śaṅkā ādhāyakam na tāvta prativādi vākyam
translated: Thus. In the second case also, in one's own inference, the statement of the opponent does not give rise to doubt.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt
translated: Because of overextension.

analyzed: tasya tadā anupasthiteḥ ca nā api upādhi śaṅkā
translated: And also because of the non-presence of that [statement]. Nor is there doubt about the qualification,

analyzed: tasyāḥ api ukta nyāyena sarvatra asaṃbhavāt
translated: because that also is not possible everywhere, as stated by the same reasoning.

analyzed: phala balāt iti
translated: By the force of the result.

analyzed: śaṅkā rūpa phala balāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: by the force of the result in the form of doubt.

analyzed: anyathā iti
translated: Otherwise.

analyzed: śaṅkā abhāve api paraṃparā kalpane iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even in the absence of doubt, the assumption of a series [of inferences] is made.

analyzed: uktam hi iti
translated: It is said.

original: viśvāsādinā pramāṇatvena siddhasya śaṅkanāspadatvaṃ jñānapādīyānuvyākhyāne uktamityarthaḥ/
analyzed: viśvāsa ādinā pramāṇa tvena siddhasya śaṅkana āspada tvam jñānapādīya anuvyākhyāne uktam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: in the Anuvritti of the Jnanapada, it is said that what is established as a means of knowledge by trust etc. is not a subject of doubt.

analyzed: parīkṣāyām satyām pramāṇa tvena niścitasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is: of what is ascertained as a means of knowledge when there is examination.

analyzed: a śodhite
translated: In the unpurified.

analyzed: tarka ādinā apramāṇāt avivakte
translated: In what is not distinguished from the unestablished by reasoning etc.

analyzed: upajīvakena bādhe pi na doṣaḥ
translated: Even when there is contradiction by what is relied upon, there is no fault.

original: nanu upajīvyaṃ kathaṃ bādhyamityata āha upajīvyatvamastvalamiti//
analyzed: nanu upajīvyam katham bādhyam iti atas āha upajīvya tvam astu alam iti
translated: But how can what is relied upon be contradicted? To this he says: Let there be mere reliance.

analyzed: upajīvya tva mātram aprayojakam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is: mere reliance is not a reason.

analyzed: dvitīye api iti
translated: In the second case also.

analyzed: svārtha anumāne āhita śaṅkā bhavati iti pakṣe pi iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even in the case where doubt is produced in one's own inference.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt iti
translated: Because of overextension.

analyzed: pratyakṣe api kara caraṇa ādi viśeṣa darśane iti ukta stheṣu api prativādi vākyāt śaśaṅkā prasaṅgāt iti arthaḥ  upādhi śaṅkā iti
translated: Even in perception, when seeing the specific parts like hands and feet, it is said that doubt arises even in those cases due to the opponent's statement.🔽The doubt about the limiting adjunct.

analyzed: śaṅkā ādhāyikā iti anukarṣaḥ  ṇa ādi garāḥ           vyāptivādaḥ pu
translated: The continuation is that which causes doubt.🔽The section on the reasonings beginning with non-apprehension.🔽The section on pervasion.

analyzed: kvācitkyāḥ tu kvācitkena eva tarkeṇa nirāsāt
translated: Because the non-apprehension of what is to be inferred is refuted.

analyzed: nirāsaḥ tu evam dhūmasya agninā saṃbandhe upādhiḥ aindriyakaḥ ced upalabhyeta
translated: The refutation is as follows: If the limiting adjunct in the relation of smoke to fire were perceptible, it would be perceived.

analyzed: na ca upalabhyate
translated: But it is not perceived.

analyzed: atīndriyaḥ api pramāṇa antara vedyaḥ syāt
translated: Even if it is imperceptible, it would be known by another means of knowledge.

analyzed: na ca tat pramāṇam upalabhyate iti
translated: But that means of knowledge is not perceived.

original: ata eva paddhatausoyaṃ kaścitpramāṇāntarānugrāhako bhavatīti tarkasya kvacitkatvamevoktam/
analyzed: atas eva paddhatau saḥ yam kaścid pramāṇa antara anugrāhakaḥ bhavati iti tarkasya kvacitkatvam eva uktam
translated: For this very reason, in the Paddhati, it is said that reasoning is sometimes effective only because it is sometimes effective.

analyzed: pramāṇena anupalabhyamānaḥ api kaścid upādhiḥ bhaviṣyati iti nar bīja āśaṅkā piśācī tu prāmāṇika tvena
translated: Even if something that is not perceived by a means of knowledge could be a limiting adjunct, the demon of doubt about seeds does not arise.

analyzed: bādhaka sahasram aprāmāṇika tvena tvad abhimate api dvaita ādau
translated: But even in non-dualism accepted by you, there are thousands of refutations, and even in dualism accepted by you, which is not a means of knowledge,

original: sādhakhasabasraṃ nirdeṣatvena tvadabhimate tvadvākye doṣasahasraṃ ca bhaviṣyatītyādyatiprasaṅgahetutvāt
analyzed: nirdeṣa tvena tvad abhimate tvad vākye doṣa sahasram ca bhaviṣyati ityādi atiprasaṅga hetutvāt
translated: Because it leads to the absurdity that the statement approved by you, being free from defects, will have a thousand defects, etc.

analyzed: na api utpannasya vyāpti niścayasya
translated: The doubt about the seventh taste, etc. is not an impediment to the production of the ascertainment of pervasion.
Nor is it an impediment to the effect of the ascertainment of pervasion that has arisen.

analyzed: utpannena niścayena eva śaṅkā utpatti pratibandhāt
translated: Because the doubt is prevented from arising by the ascertainment that has arisen itself.

analyzed: na hi grāhya saṃśaya mātram tad niścaya pratibandhakam
translated: For mere doubt about the object to be grasped is not an impediment to that ascertainment.

analyzed: na ca utpannasya vyāpti niścayasya balavat bādhakam asti
translated: And there is no powerful sublation of the ascertainment of pervasion that has arisen.

analyzed: ukta iti koṭi smaraṇa ādi abhāvāt ityādinā ukta nyāyena iti arthaḥ  atas eva iti
translated: 'As stated' means by the reasoning stated by 'absence of recollection of the two alternatives, etc.'

analyzed: kvācitka upādhi sthale eva tarka anusaraṇāt iti arthaḥ
translated: 'For this very reason' means because reasoning is followed only in cases where there is a limiting condition somewhere.

analyzed: tvad abhimatā iti
translated: 'Approved by you' means

analyzed: khaṇḍana kāram pratyucyate  na vyāpti niścaya utpatti pratibandhikā iti etat vyanakti na hi iti
translated: it is said in response to the author of the critique.🔽He explains 'it is not an impediment to the production of the ascertainment of pervasion' by 'for, if it were so, etc.'

analyzed: tathātve saṃśaya uttara pratyakṣasya anumiti ādeḥ ca anudaya āpātāt iti bhāvaḥ 🔽tepi tva ṭagarā
translated: The idea is that if it were so, then perception after doubt and inference, etc. would not occur.🔽They too, however, are not impediments to the ascertainment of pervasion that has arisen.
The third chapter of the Tarkatandava, along with the Nyāyavārttika.

analyzed: yena autsargikam prāmāṇyam apodya iti uktam hi  utsargataḥ upi yat prāptam
translated: By which the natural validity is rejected, it has been said:🔽Even what is obtained by nature, free from exception,

analyzed: vyabhicāri apavādena mānam eva bhaviṣyati
translated: will be valid cognition itself, even if there is an exception due to deviation.

analyzed: iti uktam ca khaṇḍane pi
translated: And it has been said even in the Khandana:

analyzed: atyanta asati api jñānam arthe śabdaḥ karoti hi
translated: Even in the complete absence of an object, a word produces cognition.

analyzed: abādhāt tu pramām atra svatas prāmāṇya niścalām
translated: But from non-contradiction, it produces valid cognition here, which is unshakeable due to the intrinsic validity of itself.

original: iti / kathaṃ ca pratyakṣasiddhe annādau niḥśaṅkasya pratyakṣasiddhāyāṃ vyāptau śaṅkā/🔽uktaṃ ca vyāptipratyakṣasyāpi sahakārisāmarthyātprabhijñāvadatītādiviṣayakatvamiti/
analyzed: iti katham ca pratyakṣa siddhe anna ādau niḥśaṅkasya pratyakṣa siddhāyām vyāptau śaṅkā  uktam ca vyāpti pratyakṣasya api sahakāri sāmarthyāt prabhijñā vat atīta ādi viṣayaka tvam iti
translated: And how can there be doubt in one who is fearless about food etc. established by perception, regarding the pervasion established by perception?🔽And it has been said that even the perception of pervasion has as its object the past etc., like recognition, by the power of auxiliaries.

analyzed: uktam hi iti balavat bādhaka abhāve pramāṇam eva iti etat bhaktipādīya anuvyākhyāne uktam iti arthaḥ
translated: It has been said, etc. The meaning is that it has been said in the Anuvṛttyāṭīkā based on the Bhaktivāda that in the absence of a strong contradiction, it is valid cognition itself.

analyzed: apavādena vyabhicāri api mānam eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even if there is deviation due to exception, it is valid cognition itself.

analyzed: svatas prāmāṇya niścalām pramām śabdaḥ karoti iti anvayaḥ
translated: The construction is: a word produces valid cognition which is unshakeable due to the intrinsic validity of itself.

original: nanu pratyakṣa vyāptau śaṅkānudayepyanvayavyāptau sā bhaviṣyati/
analyzed: nanu pratyakṣa vyāptau śaṅkā anudaye pi anvayavyāptau sā bhaviṣyati
translated: But even if there is no doubt in the case of a directly perceived pervasion, it will arise in the case of an inferred pervasion.

original: paricitapratyakṣasthaleṣu hetoḥ sādhyavyabhicārajñānapyatītādau tacchaṅkayā sāsyādevetyata āha uktaṃ ceti// yadvā🔽sannikṛṣṭakatipayadhūmādivyaktivyāptigrahepyatītadivyaktiṣu tadgrahopāyābhāvātkathaṃ sarvatra vyāptigraha ityata āha uktaṃ ceti//
analyzed: paricita pratyakṣa sthaleṣu hetoḥ sādhya vyabhicāra jñāna pyatīta ādau tad śaṅkayā sāsyāt eva iti atas āha uktam ca iti yat vā  sannikṛṣṭa katipaya dhūma ādi vyakti vyāpti grahe pi atīta di vyaktiṣu tad graha upāya abhāvāt katham sarvatra vyāpti grahaḥ iti atas āha uktam ca iti
translated: In familiar cases of perception, there is knowledge of the reason's deviation from the probandum. In the past etc., that doubt will arise itself. Hence he says it has been said etc. Or,🔽even in the case of grasping the pervasion of a few proximate individual objects like smoke etc., how can there be the grasping of pervasion everywhere, due to the absence of means of knowing that in past etc. individual objects? Hence he says it has been said etc.

analyzed: śakti vyāpti ādi graha samarthana vāde evam iyatā granthena tarka anavatāre viśeṣa adarśanasya
translated: In the treatise supporting the grasping of power, pervasion etc. In this way, up to this point, in the non-descent of reasoning, the non-apprehension of a specific instance,

original: sarvatra satvādityā dinā pūrvapakṣiṇoktaṃ viśeṣādarśanamabhyupetya svārthānumāne
analyzed: sarvatra sattvāt ityādinā pūrvapakṣiṇā uktam viśeṣa adarśanam abhyupetya svārtha anumāne
translated: being present everywhere, etc., has been stated by the opponent. Accepting the non-apprehension of a specific instance, in one's own inference,

original: svārasikāhitaśaṅkayoḥ svavyāghātaprasaṅgenānuvāda uktaḥ /🔽adhunā nāstyeva viśeṣādarśanamityāha vācayiṣyate ceti//
analyzed: svārasika ahita śaṅkayoḥ sva vyāghāta prasaṅgena anuvādaḥ uktaḥ  adhunā na asti eva viśeṣa adarśanam iti āha vācayiṣyate ca iti
translated: the restatement of one's own contradiction has been stated by way of the naturally arising doubt of the probandum.🔽Now, he says that there is no non-apprehension of a specific instance at all. He says it will be stated etc.

original: atraiva bhaṅge kiñca vyabhicārivyāvṛttiviśeṣasyādarśana ityādigrantheneti bhāvaḥ//
analyzed: atra eva bhaṅge kiñca vyabhicāri vyāvṛtti viśeṣasya adarśane ityādi granthena iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Here, in this very refutation, the meaning is that it is by the text beginning with and the non-apprehension of a specific instance that excludes the deviant etc.

analyzed: kṣe śaṅkā anuṭa ṭhaḍa sā dinā pū ṭaḍa
translated: Kṣe, Śaṅkā, Nuṭ, Ṭha, Ḍha, Sa, Iti, Nāsti, Ṭha, Ḍha, Dinā, Pū, Ṭha, Ḍha.
Refutation of the objection that the invariable concomitance is not stated.

analyzed: vyāptivādaḥ
translated: The section on pervasion.

original: vācayiṣyate ca paramukhenaiva vyāptidhīkāle vyabhicara vyāvṛttaviśeṣadarśanamapyastīti//
analyzed: vācayiṣyate ca para mukhena eva vyāpti dhī kāle vyabhicara vyāvṛtta viśeṣa darśanam api asti iti
translated: And it will be stated by another's mouth itself that at the time of the cognition of pervasion, there is also the perception of a particular excluded from the counter-example.

analyzed: nā api anumāna prāmāṇya vādinā tad aprāmāṇya vādinam pratiprayukte para artha anumāne śaṅkā
translated: Nor is there doubt in a para-arthānumāna employed by one who asserts the validity of inference against one who asserts its invalidity.

original: tatra prati vādinā mayedaṃ sādhyaṃ vyabhicāriṣyatīti sarvatra śaṅkotthāpanāditi dvitīyaḥ/
analyzed: tatra prati vādinā mayā idam sādhyam vyabhicāriṣyati iti sarvatra śaṅkā utthāpanāt iti dvitīyaḥ
translated: There, the opponent always raises doubt, thinking This probandum will be fallacious for me, in every case. This is the second.

original: tathāpi tṛptyarthaṃ bhojane parabodhanārthaṃ śabdoccāraṇe evaṃ tattatkāryoddeśena tattatkāraṇe ca pravṛttirūpasvakriyāvyāghātena śaṅkānudayāt/
analyzed: tathā api tṛpti artham bhojane para bodhana artham śabda uccāraṇe evam tad tad kārya uddeśena tad tad kāraṇe ca pravṛtti rūpa sva kriyā vyāghātena śaṅkā anudayāt
translated: Even so, in eating for the sake of satisfaction, in uttering words for the sake of informing others, and in engaging in such and such causes for the sake of such and such effects, doubt does not arise due to the contradiction of one's own action.

analyzed: atra
translated: Here

original: parārthānumāne veti prāgvikalpitaṃ dvitīpakṣaṃ vivṛṇvanneti nirāha nāpīti//
analyzed: parārtha anumāne vā iti prāk vikalpitam dvitīya pakṣam vivṛṇvan na iti nirāha nā api iti
translated: in para-arthānumāna, the second alternative previously considered is explained by saying iti and refuted by saying na api.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: The second is to be supplied.

original: mayā cārvākeṇa khaṇḍanakāreṇa vā svakriyāvyāghātena vyāghāto virodho hānirvā/
analyzed: mayā cārvākeṇa khaṇḍana kāreṇa vā sva kriyā vyāghātena vyāghātaḥ virodhaḥ hāniḥ vā
translated: By me, a Cārvāka or the author of the Khandana, there is contradiction, i.e. inconsistency or loss, due to the contradiction of one's own action.

original: yadi sarvatra śaṅkā tvayotthāpyate tarhi bhojanamapi tṛptiṃ vyabhicariṣyati śabdoccāraṇamapi parabodhaṃ vyabhicariṣyatīti bhojanādau na pravṛttiḥ
analyzed: yadi sarvatra śaṅkā tvayā utthāpyate tarhi bhojanam api tṛptim vyabhicariṣyati śabda uccāraṇam api para bodham vyabhicariṣyati iti bhojana ādau na pravṛttiḥ
translated: If doubt is raised everywhere, then even eating will be deviant from satisfaction, and even the utterance of a word will be deviant from conveying meaning to others, so there would be no engagement in eating and so on.

original: asti ca sā/🔽ato na sarvatra śaṅkā kāryetyarthaḥ/
analyzed: asti ca sā  atas na sarvatra śaṅkā kāryā iti arthaḥ
translated: But it does exist.🔽Therefore, the meaning is that doubt should not be raised everywhere.

original: evaṃ vyāghātāvadhirāśaṅketyetadvṛdi kṛtvā vyāghātadaṇḍabhayena sarvatra śaṅkā notpattumarhatītyuktam/
analyzed: evam vyāghāta avadhiḥ āśaṅkā iti etat vṛdi kṛtvā vyāghāta daṇḍa bhayena sarvatra śaṅkā nā utpattum arhati iti uktam
translated: Thus, taking doubt up to contradiction as the basis, it is said that doubt should not arise everywhere out of fear of contradiction and punishment.

analyzed: tasya khaṇḍana uktam ra doṣam uddhartum āha atra iti
translated: To remove the fault stated by Khaṇḍana, he says Here and so on.

analyzed: pravṛtti
translated: Cārik. Ga. Ra. There also Ka. Your Ga. Ra. Engagement is deviated.
Pu. Nyāyadyuti-yuta-tarkatāṇḍava, Third Section

analyzed: śaṅkā ced anumān asti eva na ced śaṅkā tatastarām
translated: If there is doubt, then there is inference. If there is no doubt, then it is even more so.

analyzed: vyāghāta avadhiḥ āśaṅkā tarkaḥ śaṅkā avadhiḥ mataḥ
translated: Doubt up to contradiction is considered to be reasoning, with doubt as the limit.

analyzed: iti udayana ukta dūṣaṇa artham cārvāka bhūṣaṇa artham ca uktam khaṇḍane
translated: To refute the fault stated by Udayana and to ornament the Cārvāka, it is said in Khaṇḍana

original: vyādhāto yadi śaṅkāsti na cecchaṅkā tatastarām/
analyzed: vyādhātaḥ yadi śaṅkā asti na ced śaṅkā tatastarām
translated: If there is doubt due to contradiction, if there is no doubt, then it is even more so.

analyzed: vyāghāta avadhiḥ āśaṅkā tarkaḥ śaṅkā avadhiḥ kutas
translated: Doubt extends up to contradiction. How can reasoning extend up to doubt?

analyzed: iti asya arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: yadi vyāghātaḥ tarhi śaṅkā asti eva
translated: If there is contradiction, then there is certainly doubt.

original: vyāghāto hi svakriyāyāḥ śaṅkayā saha virodhaḥ/
analyzed: vyāghātaḥ hi sva kriyāyāḥ śaṅkayā saha virodhaḥ
translated: For contradiction is the incompatibility of one's own action with doubt.

analyzed: vyāghāta bhayāt śaṅkā na udetam arhati iti ukta prameye khaṇḍane uktam iti arthaḥ
translated: Out of fear of contradiction, doubt cannot arise. This is said in the refutation of the established conclusion.

analyzed: śaṅkā ced iti
translated: If there is doubt,

original: kālāntare deśāntare vā ayaṃ hetuḥ sādhyaṃ vyabhicāriṣyatīti śaṅkā cedutpannā tadānumānaṃ pramāṇamastyeva/
analyzed: kāla antare deśa antare vā ayam hetuḥ sādhyam vyabhicāriṣyati iti śaṅkā ced utpannā tadā anumānam pramāṇam asti eva
translated: if there arises the doubt that this reason will be deviant with respect to the probandum at another time or in another place, then inference is indeed a means of valid knowledge.

original: anumānaṃ vinā kālāntaradeśāntarayoranupasthiteḥ/🔽na cedevaṃ śaṅkā tadā sutarāṃ niḥsandehamanumānaṃ pramāṇamastyeva/
analyzed: anumānam vinā kāla antara deśa antarayoḥ anupasthiteḥ  na ced evam śaṅkā tadā sutarām niḥsandeham anumānam pramāṇam asti eva
translated: Because without inference, another time or another place is not presented.🔽And if there is no such doubt, then inference is all the more a means of valid knowledge free from doubt.

original: nanva numānaṃ pramāṇaṃ śaṅkā tu kathaṃ nivartyeti suhṛdbhāvena pṛcchantaṃ pratyāha tarkaḥ śaṅkāvadhirmataḥ/
analyzed: nanu a numānam pramāṇam śaṅkā tu katham nivartyā iti suhṛd bhāvena pṛcchantam pratyāha tarkaḥ śaṅkā avadhiḥ mataḥ
translated: But how can inference be a means of valid knowledge, and how can doubt be removed? To one who asks this out of friendship, he says: Reasoning is considered to extend up to doubt.

analyzed: yāvacchaṅkam tarka pravṛtyā tarkeṇa sā nivartanīyā iti
translated: As long as there is doubt, it is to be removed by the application of reasoning.

original: nanu tarkepi vyāpterāvaśyakatvāttatrāpi śaṅkāyāṃ tarkāntarānveṣaṇenavastheti cettatrottaraṃ vyāghātāvadhirāśaṅketi//
analyzed: nanu tarke api vyāpteḥ āvaśyaka tvāt tatra api śaṅkāyām tarka antara anveṣaṇena avasthā iti ced tatra uttaram vyāghāta avadhiḥ āśaṅkā iti
translated: If it be said that even in reasoning, since the pervasion is necessary, there would be an infinite regress of reasoning even in the case of doubt, we reply that the doubt ends with the contradiction.

analyzed: āśaṅkā paramparā jāyamānā satī kvacid viśrāmyati
translated: The doubt, arising in a series, rests somewhere.

original: yatra śaṅkāyāṃ kriyaṇāyāṃ svakriyāvyāghātādirbhavati tatra na śaṅkotpattumarhatīti tṛtīyaparicchede kusumāḍhjalyuktaślokārthaḥ/
analyzed: yatra śaṅkāyām kriyaṇāyām sva kriyā vyāghāta ādiḥ bhavati tatra na śaṅkā utpattum arhati iti tṛtīya paricchede kusumāḍhjali ukta śloka arthaḥ
translated: Where, in the case of doubt, there is contradiction of one's own action, etc., doubt cannot arise there. This is the meaning of the verse quoted by Kusumāñjali in the third chapter.

analyzed: durgama artha tvāt dūṣaṇa saukarya artham āha
translated: Because the meaning is difficult to understand, for the sake of ease in refuting, he says

analyzed: asya arthaḥ iti
translated: The meaning of this is...🔽The connection is stated.

analyzed: dūṣaṇa saukaryāya artham āha iti asti
translated: For the sake of ease in refuting, he says there is.
The refutation of the non-occurrence of what is to be inferred.

analyzed: vyāptivādaḥ pu
translated: The section on pervasion.

original: tathā ca śaṅkā pratiyogitayā vyāghātanirūpakatvena tannirvāhiketi kathaṃ śaṅkāṃ vinā vyāghātaḥ/
analyzed: tathā ca śaṅkā pratiyogitayā vyāghāta nirūpaka tvena tad nirvāhikā iti katham śaṅkām vinā vyāghātaḥ
translated: And thus, doubt, as the counter-correlate, serves as the determiner of contradiction. How can there be contradiction without doubt?

analyzed: na ced vyāghātaḥ tadā nivartaka abhāvāt sutarām śaṅkā asti eva iti brūmaḥ
translated: And if there is no contradiction, then doubt certainly exists due to the absence of what would remove it. We say:

original: kimanumānaprāmāṇyepi vyāptiniścayo na saṃbhavatītyucyate na saṃbhavatītyucyate kiṃ vānumānamātramapramāṇamiti/ nādyaḥ/
analyzed: kim anumāna prāmāṇye api vyāpti niścayaḥ na saṃbhavati iti ucyate na saṃbhavati iti ucyate kim vā anumāna mātram apramāṇam iti na ādyaḥ
translated: Is it said that even when the validity of inference is accepted, the ascertainment of the pervasion is not possible, or is it said that inference itself is not a means of valid knowledge? Not the first.

original: arke cenmadhu vindeta kimarthaṃ parvataṃ vrajet/
analyzed: arke ced madhu vindeta kimartham parvatam vrajet
translated: If one finds honey in the sun, why should one go to the mountain?

analyzed: iti nyāyena mama iṣṭa siddheḥ
translated: By this reasoning, my desired conclusion is established.

analyzed: na hi aham upeye anumāna prāmāṇye siddhe ipi upāya viśeṣe
translated: For I am not insisting on a particular means when the validity of inference as a means of knowledge is established.

analyzed: vyabhicāriṇā api sādhya siddhi prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because even an erroneous [reason] would lead to the establishment of the conclusion.

analyzed: sthāpanāyām viraktasya api tava dṛṣṭa prakāra tyāgena adṛṣṭena
translated: Even though you are disinterested in the proof, by abandoning the seen method and by the unseen

analyzed: tathā ca śaṅkā iti  tad nirvāhikā iti anvayaḥ
translated: and thus there is doubt.🔽The continuation is that which accomplishes that.
The meaning is that which accomplishes the contradiction.

analyzed: katham pratiyogi tayā ityādi
translated: How as the counter-correlate, etc.

original: evaṃ ca vyāghātāvadhirāśaṅketi tarkaḥ śaṅkāvadhiriti ca kuta ityuttarārdhasya svaṣṭatvādartho noktaḥ/🔽vyāptini ścayo na saṃbhavatīti tatsaṃbhavasya tarkādhīnatvāt/
analyzed: evam ca vyāghāta avadhiḥ āśaṅkā iti tarkaḥ śaṅkā avadhiḥ iti ca kutas iti uttara ardhasya su aṣṭa tvāt arthaḥ na uktaḥ  vyāptini ścayaḥ na saṃbhavati iti tad saṃbhavasya tarka adhīna tvāt
translated: And thus the doubt extends up to the contradiction, and the reasoning is limited by the doubt - how is this? The meaning of the latter half is not stated because it is clear.🔽Because the ascertainment of the pervasion is not possible, and its possibility depends on reasoning.

analyzed: tarkasya vyāpti sāpekṣa tve na anavasthā apatya anutthānāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that if reasoning depends on the pervasion, there is no regress, because it does not arise.

analyzed: arke ced iti
translated: If one finds honey in the sun, etc.

original: iṣṭasyārthasya saṃsiddhau ko vidvān yatnamācarediti vākyaśeṣaḥ/
analyzed: iṣṭasya arthasya saṃsiddhau kaḥ vidvān yatnam ācaret iti vākyaśeṣaḥ
translated: The rest of the sentence is: When the desired object is accomplished, what wise person would make an effort?

analyzed: ayam ca ślokaḥ śābara bhāṣya ādau uktaḥ
translated: And this verse is stated in the Śābarabhāṣya and other texts.

original: nanu tarkādhīnavyāptiniśca hetukaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ na prāptamevetyata āha na hīti//
analyzed: nanu tarka adhīna vyāpti niśca hetukam prāmāṇyam na prāptam eva iti atas āha na hi iti
translated: But then, the validity of inference, which depends on the ascertainment of pervasion, is not obtained at all. Therefore, he says not etc.

original: anumānaprāmāṇyaṃ svīkurvatā vyāptiniścaya saṃbhavovaśyaṃ vācyonyathātiprasaṅgāditi bhāvenāha vyabhicāriṇāmapīti//
analyzed: anumāna prāmāṇyam svīkurvatā vyāpti niścaya saṃbhavaḥ vaśyam vācyaḥ anyathā atiprasaṅgāt iti bhāvena āha vyabhicāriṇām api iti
translated: One who accepts the validity of inference must necessarily state the possibility of the ascertainment of pervasion, otherwise there would be an overextension. With this in mind, he says even of the fallacious etc.

analyzed: anumāna prāmāṇya svīkāraḥ tava ayuktaḥ iti āha sthāpanāyām iti
translated: He says that it is not proper for you to accept the validity of inference. He says in the proof etc.

original: kaścidapi mama sthāpyaḥ pakṣo neti vadataḥ khaṇḍanakārasyetyarthaḥ/
analyzed: kaścid api mama sthāpyaḥ pakṣaḥ na iti vadataḥ khaṇḍana kārasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: I have no thesis to be established at all, says the author of the Khandana.

analyzed: anumāna prāmāṇyam upetya vyāpti niścaya khaṇḍanam sva vyāhatam iti āha vyāpti sāpekṣeṇa iti
translated: Accepting the validity of inference, the refutation of the ascertainment of pervasion is self-contradictory. He says by that which depends on pervasion etc.🔽It is not possible.

original: na sambhavatītiṭha / /tarkece ḍa / /ścāyakaṃḍa / /yovaśyaṃṭa /ṭha / 🔽pu / nyāyadīpayutatarkatāṇḍavam tṛ /paricchedaḥ 🔽prakāntareṇānumānaprāmāṇyasādhanā pātācca/
analyzed: sambhavati iti ṭha tarke ce ḍa śca ayakam ḍa yo vaśyam ṭa ṭha
translated: In another way, the proof of the validity of inference is also not possible.

analyzed: vyāpti sāpekṣeṇa tarkeṇa anavasthā āpādana ayogāt ca
translated: And because it is not possible to establish an infinite regress by reasoning which depends on pervasion.

analyzed: pramāṇa tarkābhyām vyāvartavyam iti samaya bandha ayogāt ca
translated: And because it is not possible to make a rule that it should be refuted by means of valid means of knowledge and reasoning.

analyzed: vyāpteḥ aniścaye śabda śakteḥ api aniścayena advaita śruteḥ abodhaka tva āpātāt ca
translated: And because, if the pervasion is not ascertained, the power of the word is also not ascertained, and the non-dualistic statement would be non-informative.

analyzed: lakṣaṇāyāḥ api abhidhāya mūlaka tvāt
translated: And because even figurative meaning is based on denotation.

analyzed: na antyaḥ parakīya śaṅkā ādeḥ api anumeya tayā tad śaṅkā nivṛti artham tava vākya prayogāt
translated: The last one is not so, because even the doubt of others is inferable, and in order to remove that doubt, your statement is used.

original: anumānasyeva tarkasyāpi vyāptiniścayaṃ vinaiva sādhakhatvasaṃbhāditi bhāvaḥ/
analyzed: anumānasya iva tarkasya api vyāpti niścayam vinā eva bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that like inference, reasoning is also possible without the ascertainment of pervasion.

original: yadvā tatprāmāṇyanirvāhakopāyāntarābhāvāt asmaduktanirvāhasyaiva tvayāpi vācyatvāttaddūṣaṇoktirayuktetyāha vyāptīti//
analyzed: yat vā tad prāmāṇya nirvāhaka upāya antara abhāvāt asmad ukta nirvāhasya eva tvayā api vācya tvāt tad dūṣaṇa uktiḥ ayuktā iti āha vyāpti iti
translated: Or, because there is no other means to establish its validity, and because you also have to state the establishment as stated by us, the statement of its refutation is improper. Thus he says 'because of pervasion' etc.

original: vyāptisāpekṣatvena tarkasya khaṇḍanaṃ vyāhatamityāha pramāṇeti//🔽paramārthādvaitadṛṣṭyā nāsti samayabandhādivyavahāra ityata āha vyāpteriti//
analyzed: vyāpti sāpekṣa tvena tarkasya khaṇḍanam vyāhatam iti āha pramāṇa iti  paramārtha advaita dṛṣṭyā na asti samaya bandha ādi vyavahāraḥ iti atas āha vyāpteḥ iti
translated: The refutation of reasoning on the ground of its dependence on pervasion is contradicted. Thus he says 'by means of valid means of knowledge' etc.🔽From the point of view of the highest non-dual reality, there is no usage such as making a rule etc. Therefore he says 'because of pervasion' etc.

original: yadvā vyāptiniścayo na saṃbhavatītyetatsva vyāhatamityāha vyāpteriti//
analyzed: yat vā vyāpti niścayaḥ na saṃbhavati iti etat sva vyāhatam iti āha vyāpteḥ iti
translated: Or, this statement that the ascertainment of pervasion is not possible is contradicted by itself. Thus he says 'because of pervasion' etc.
The idea is that potency is to be grasped according to the method stated in the Pramanalaksanatika, either by a kevalavyatireki or an anvaya-vyatireki [inference].

analyzed: yat vā vṛddha vyavahāra ādi āvāpa udvāpābhyām iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Or the idea is that the ascertainment of pervasion is neglected in the grasping of potency from the usage of the elders by the method of agreement and difference.

original: lakṣaṇayādvaitajñānamastu kiṃ śaktigrahaṇenetyata āha lakṣaṇāyā iti//
analyzed: lakṣaṇayā advaita jñānam astu kim śakti grahaṇena iti atas āha lakṣaṇāyāḥ iti
translated: Or rather, let there be the knowledge of non-duality by secondary meaning, what is the use of grasping potency? Hence he says: of secondary meaning.

original: mukhyārthasaṃbandhapūrvakatvāllakṣaṇāyā iti bhāvaḥ//🔽nāntya iti// anumānamātramapramāṇiti pakṣa ityarthaḥ/
analyzed: mukhya artha saṃbandha pūrvaka tvāt lakṣaṇāyāḥ iti bhāvaḥ  na antyaḥ iti anumāna mātram apramāṇiti pakṣaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The idea is that secondary meaning is preceded by the connection with the primary meaning.🔽Not the last one - the meaning is that the view that inference alone is not a means of knowledge is not accepted.

analyzed: na āyāsa āpātāt ca ṭagarā tyatas āha
translated: And because of the undesired consequence of effort, therefore he says: that is explained by that in the form of a riddle.
The refutation of the non-production of the inferred.

analyzed: vyāptivādaḥ
translated: The section on pervasion.

analyzed: anumāna aprāmāṇyasya api pratyakṣa ādi asiddha tvena tatra anumānasya eva pramāṇayitavya tvāt ca
translated: And because the invalidity of inference is not established by perception etc., and therefore inference alone is to be proved in that case.

analyzed: anumāna aprāmāṇye kāla antara ādeḥ api asiddhyā tatra vyabhicāra śaṅkā yogāt ca
translated: And because even the doubt of fallacy is not possible in that case, due to the non-establishment of the distant point of time etc. in the case of the invalidity of inference.

analyzed: pravartaka nivartakayoḥ iṣṭa aniṣṭa sādhana tvayoḥ api anumeya tvena tava
translated: And because the means of attaining the desirable and the undesirable are also to be inferred by you.

analyzed: kutra api pravṛtti nivṛti ayogāt ca
translated: And because there is no possibility of engagement or disengagement anywhere.

original: advaite ṣaḍvidhatātparyaliṅgānāṃ prapañcamithyātvānubhūtasvaprakāśatvādau dṛśya mānatvānubhūtitvādiliṅgānāṃ coktyayogācca/
analyzed: advaite ṣaḍvidha tātparya liṅgānām prapañca mithyātva anubhūta sva prakāśa tva ādau dṛśya māna tva anubhūti tva ādi liṅgānām ca ukti ayogāt ca
translated: And because it is impossible to state the six kinds of indications of non-duality, such as the unreality of the world, self-luminousness of experience, etc., and the indications such as being experienced, etc.,

analyzed: saṃdigdha anaikāntike vyāvahārika prāmāṇyasya ā bhāvāt
translated: Because in the case of doubtful and inconclusive [reason], there is no conventional validity.

analyzed: viśva mithyātva ādeḥ avyāvahārika tvāt ca  pratyakṣa śabdābhyām iva liṅgena api jñāna utpatteḥ utpanna jñānasya bādhā abhāvena prāmāṇya niścayasya
translated: And because the unreality of the world, etc., are not conventional.🔽And because there is no special fault in inference, as in the case of perception and verbal testimony, by the reason, by the production of knowledge, and by the absence of contradiction of the produced knowledge, by the ascertainment of validity,

analyzed: tad adhīna niṣkampa pravṛtteḥ pravṛtti sāmarthyasya ca anubhavena anumāne viśeṣa aparādha abhāvāt ca
translated: And by the experience of the unhesitating engagement dependent on that, and by the capacity of engagement.

analyzed: kāla antara ādeḥ asiddhyā iti
translated: Because the delay, etc., are not established.

analyzed: para rītyā kāla deśayoḥ ānumānika tvam upetya idam dūṣaṇam dhyeyam
translated: This fault should be understood as being stated on the opponent's terms, accepting the inferability of time and place.

analyzed: siddhānte sākṣi siddha tvāt
translated: Because in the established conclusion, [time and place] are established by the witness [consciousness].

analyzed: vyāvahārika prāmāṇyam upetya tad uktiḥ iti atas āha saṃdigdha iti
translated: Accepting conventional validity, it is said. Therefore it is said: In the doubtful, etc.

original: kālānta rādau sādhyaṃ vyabhicariṣyati kimiti śaṅkāspada
translated: The probandum, such as delay, etc., will be contradicted. What is the doubt?

original: ityarthaḥ/ tātvikaprāmāṇyameva dṛśyatvādi hetūnāṃ upeyaṃ tadbodhya mithyātvādestātvikatvāt /
analyzed: iti arthaḥ tātvika prāmāṇyam eva dṛśya tva ādi hetūnām upeyam tad bodhya mithyātva ādeḥ tātvika tvāt
translated: The meaning is this. The true validity itself is to be accepted as the reason for being perceived, etc., because the falsity, etc. understood by them are true.

analyzed: anyathā vyāvahārika pramāṇa siddha prapañca vat mithyātvam api mithyā eva syāt iti bhāvena āha viśya mithyātva ādeḥ iti
translated: Otherwise, falsity would also be false, like the world established by empirical means of knowledge. With this idea, he says of the falsity, etc. of the world.

analyzed: jñāna utpatteḥ ityādi ṣaṣṭhī anta catuṣṭayasya api anubhavena iti anvayaḥ
translated: The four words ending in the sixth case, beginning with of the origin of knowledge, are also to be construed with by experience.

analyzed: re iti asti
translated: The reading is of the falsity, etc. of the world, which is true.
The Nyaya-Tandava with the Nyaya-Dipika, Third Section.

analyzed: anyathā anumānam eva pramāṇam na tu pratyakṣa ādi iti
translated: Otherwise, inference alone would be the means of knowledge, not perception and others.

original: pratyakṣepi netrameva pramāṇaṃ na tu śrotrādi vedepi dvaitavākyameva pramāṇaṃ natvadvaitavākyamiti ca syāt//
analyzed: pratyakṣe api netram eva pramāṇam na tu śrotra ādi vede pi dvaita vākyam eva pramāṇam na tu advaita vākyam iti ca syāt
translated: Even in perception, the eye alone would be the means of knowledge, not the ear, etc. Even in the Veda, the statements about duality alone would be the means of knowledge, not the statements about non-duality.

original: etenānumānātsaṃbhāvanāmātreṇa pravṛtyādikaṃ saṃvādācca prāmāṇyābhimāna iti nirastam/
analyzed: etena anumānāt saṃbhāvanā mātreṇa pravṛti ādikam saṃvādāt ca prāmāṇya abhimānaḥ iti nirastam
translated: By this, the view that activity, etc. is merely a possibility from inference and the pride in validity from agreement is refuted.

original: anumānājjñānaṃ jāyate tacca saṃvādītita vadatā tvayaiva tatpāmāṇyayopagamāt/
analyzed: anumānāt jñānam jāyate tat ca vadatā tvayā eva tad pāmāṇyayā upagamāt
translated: And by saying that knowledge arises from inference and that it is in agreement with reality, you yourself accept its validity.

analyzed: saṃbhāvanā tve nā api koṭi antara ullekhā pātāt ca
translated: And because if it were mere possibility, it would lead to the consideration of other alternatives.

analyzed: niṣkampa pravṛti anupapatteḥ ca
translated: And because unhesitating activity would be impossible.

analyzed: evaṃvidhasya pāribhāṣika saṃbhāvanā tvasya mayā abhyupagamāt ca  pratyakṣa ādinā api saṃbhāvanā mātram iti āpātāt ca
translated: And because I accept such a technical sense of possibility.🔽And because it would absurdly follow that even perception etc. are mere possibility.

analyzed: autsargika ābādhaḥ kvācitka bādhaḥ ca ubhayatra api samaḥ
translated: And the general rule of non-contradiction and occasional contradiction apply in both cases.

analyzed: netram iti cakṣuḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The word netra means eye.

analyzed: saṃbhāvanā mātreṇa iti  utkaṭa koṭika saṃdeha mātreṇa iti arthaḥ
translated: By mere possibility, it means🔽by mere doubt with a strong possibility.

analyzed: vahni ādi anumiti sthaḥ iti yojyam
translated: It should be connected with in the case of inference of fire etc.

original: saṃbhāvanamātreṇa pravṛttau sakampaiva pravṛttiḥ syāt na tu niṣkampetayāha niṣkampeti//
analyzed: saṃbhāvana mātreṇa pravṛttau sa kampā eva pravṛttiḥ syāt na tu niṣkampā itayā āha niṣkampā iti
translated: If one engages in activity by mere possibility, the activity would be hesitant, not unhesitating. To show this, he says unhesitating etc.

original: nanu mayopetā saṃbhāvanā niṣkampa pravṛttijanikaivetyata āha evamiti//
analyzed: nanu mayā upetā saṃbhāvanā niṣkampa pravṛtti janikā eva iti atas āha evam iti
translated: But the possibility accepted by me generates unhesitating activity. To this he says thus etc.

analyzed: paribhāṣā mātrasya anumiti prāmāṇya aparipanthi tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that mere technicality does not obstruct inference.

analyzed: nanu pratyakṣa śabdayoḥ utsargataḥ sarvatra ābādhaḥ eva
translated: But perception and verbal testimony are invariably non-contradictory in all cases.

analyzed: kvacid eva śukti rūpya ādau bādhaḥ
translated: In some cases only, like a shell and silver, there is contradiction.

original: ato na tatra saṃbhāvanāmātropagamena pratyakṣāderaprāmāṇyāpāta ityata āha autsargiketi//
analyzed: atas na tatra saṃbhāvanā mātra upagamena pratyakṣa ādeḥ aprāmāṇya āpātaḥ iti atas āha autsargika iti
translated: Therefore, in order to avoid the fallacy that perception etc. are not valid due to accepting mere possibility there, it is said that it is natural.

original: jñānamityadhikamṭa /ka /ga /rā / /tvehyanumitāviti kāṭa / tve hīnatvenāpi ko gā /rā / /yāpyupagaka /ga /rā / /nivṛṭa /ṭha /
analyzed: jñānam iti tvehi anumitau iti tve hīna tvena api
translated: Knowledge is the additional word. In the case of inference, even if there is weakness, who goes? In the case of acceptance, even if it is removed, who goes? It is not to be uttered.
The refutation of the refutation of the invariable concomitance of what is to be inferred.

analyzed: vyāptivādaḥ pu
translated: The section on pervasion.

analyzed: kiñca vyabhicāri vyāvṛtta viśeṣasya adarśane saṃbhāvanā eva kutas
translated: Moreover, how can there be mere possibility without seeing a particular that excludes what has deviation?

analyzed: anyathā saṃdigdha vyabhicāriṇī api sā syāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be doubt even in what has doubtful deviation.

original: darśane tu yaddarśane tava saṃbhāvanā taddarśanenaiva mama niścayostu/
analyzed: darśane tu yat darśane tava saṃbhāvanā tad darśanena eva mama
translated: But let there be certainty for me just by seeing what you have mere possibility of seeing.

original: sa viśeṣaḥ ka iti cedātmānameva pṛccha/
analyzed: sa viśeṣaḥ kaḥ iti ced ātmānam eva pṛccha
translated: If you ask what is that particular, ask yourself.

analyzed: yaḥ tvam darśanena saṃbhāvitavān niṣkampam pravṛttaḥ ca
translated: You who have mere possibility of seeing and have engaged in action without hesitation.

original: yadi tava samakoṭi śahkāsāmagrīviraho saṃbhāvanā hetuḥ/
analyzed: yadi tava samakoṭi saṃbhāvanā hetuḥ
translated: If the absence of the collection of causes for doubt about equal status is the cause of mere possibility for you,

analyzed: tarhi mama sama koṭi viṣama koṭika ubhaya śaṅkā sāmagrī virahaḥ niścaya hetuḥ
translated: then the absence of the collection of doubts about equal status, unequal status, and both for me is the cause of certainty.

original: yadi ca tavānveṣaṇepi vyabhicārādarśanasahakṛtamupādhyadarśanaṃ vā upādhya darśanasaṃbhāvanā vā yāvacchaktiparīkṣā
analyzed: yadi ca tava anveṣaṇe pi vyabhicāra adarśana sahakṛtam upādhya darśanam vā upādhya darśana saṃbhāvanā vā yāvat śakti parīkṣā
translated: And if, even in your investigation, there is no observation of contradiction, or no observation of a counter-reason, or the possibility of observing a counter-reason, then there is examination up to one's ability.

analyzed: vā saṃbhāvanā hetuḥ
translated: And if in your case, the non-observation of the counter-example along with the non-observation of the counter-reason, or the suspicion of the observation of the counter-reason, or the examination up to one's ability, or the cause of suspicion, is the cause of the ascertainment of pervasion,

analyzed: tarhi mama api te eva vyāpti niścaya hetavaḥ
translated: then in my case also, those same are the causes of the ascertainment of pervasion.

original: evaṃ ca yaduktaṃ vyāghāto yadītyādi tadaparāddhoṣerdhānuṣksayeva valgitamātram/
analyzed: evam ca yat uktam vyāghātaḥ yadi ityādi tat aparāddha ūṣeḥ dhānuṣksayā iva valgita mātram
translated: And thus, what was said - If there is contradiction... - that is mere boasting like the jumping of a bird whose arrow has been shot.

analyzed: ubhayatra iti
translated: In both cases means

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādau anumāne ca iti arthaḥ  niṣkampam pravṛttaḥ ca iti
translated: in perception etc. and inference.🔽And one who acts without hesitation.

analyzed: yaḥ tvam iti anukarṣaḥ
translated: He who is continued.🔽Saying the specific form only through the mouth of another, he says equally for me also, if for you etc.

original: paramukhenaiva viśeṣasvarūpaṃ vācayan samaṃ mamāpītyāha yadi taveti//
analyzed: para mukhena eva viśeṣa svarūpam vācayan samam mama api iti āha yadi tava iti
translated: Of one who has shot an arrow means

original: aparāddheṣoriti//🔽aparāddhaḥ lakṣyādanyatra gataḥ iṣuḥ śaro yasya tasyetyarthaḥ/ 🔽ṭi kasaṃṭa / ṭikaśaṅkāsā ga /rā / /dhyasaṃbhā ṭa /ga / bhavasaṃrā /
analyzed: aparāddha iṣoḥ iti  aparāddhaḥ lakṣyāt anyatra gataḥ iṣuḥ śaraḥ yasya tasya iti arthaḥ  ṭi garā bhava saṃrā
translated: one whose arrow, which has gone elsewhere than the target, has been shot.

The Tika, the doubt, the suspicion, the doubt, the possibility, the doubt, the possibility, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the doubt, the

original: nahi mayā niṣpanna bhojana kriyā vā kriyāyāḥ śaṅkāyāḥ śaṅkayā saha virodho vā tajjñānaṃ vā śaṅkānivartakamityucyate/
analyzed: nahi mayā niṣpanna bhojana kriyā vā kriyāyāḥ śaṅkāyāḥ śaṅkayā saha virodhaḥ vā tad jñānam vā śaṅkā nivartakam iti ucyate
translated: For it is not said that the completed act of eating or the doubt about the act is contradictory to the doubt, or that the knowledge of that removes the doubt.

original: yena kriyāyāṃ satyāṃ śaṅkānivṛtya tṛptikāraṇatvanirṇayaḥ tasmiṃśca sati kriyeti tvaduktonyonyāśrayaḥ tvaduktavirodhi pratiyogiśaṅkāvaśyaṃbhāvaśca
analyzed: yena kriyāyām satyām śaṅkā nivṛtya tṛpti kāraṇatva nirṇayaḥ tasmin ca sati kriyā iti tvad uktaḥ anyonya āśrayaḥ tvad ukta virodhi pratiyogi śaṅkā avaśyaṃbhāvaḥ ca
translated: By which, when the act is present, the doubt is removed and the determination of the cause of satisfaction is made, and when that is present, the act is present. Thus, the mutual dependence you have stated and the necessary presence of the contradictory doubt of the counter-entity are contradictory to what you have said.

analyzed: syāt
translated: It would be so.

original: kintu tvamapi kriyāmūlabhūtena śaṅkāviruddhakoṭyālambana viśeṣadarśanena nivṛttaśaṅkaḥ san manasā vyāptiṃ niścinuṣe/
analyzed: kintu tvam api kriyā mūla bhūtena śaṅkā viruddha koṭi ālambana viśeṣa darśanena nivṛtta śaṅkaḥ san manasā vyāptim niścinuṣe
translated: But you also, having removed the doubt by the specific perception of the contradictory aspect that is the basis of the act, determine the pervasion mentally.

analyzed: vācā tu na iti brūṣe
translated: But you say it is not so verbally.

analyzed: tasmāt vāc manasaḥ visaṃvādam kuruṣe
translated: Therefore, you create a contradiction between speech and mind.

original: na hi tatarthaṃ tatra niṣkampaṃ pravartate tacca tatkāraṇaṃ neti śaṅkate ceti saṃbhavati/
analyzed: na hi tatas artham tatra niṣkampam pravartate tat ca tad kāraṇam na iti śaṅkate ca iti saṃbhavati
translated: For it is not possible that one doubts whether that which proceeds irresolutely there for that purpose is the cause of that or not.

analyzed: tasmāt tvad vacanam mūkaḥ ham iti vat sva kriyā viruddham iti eva ucyate
translated: Therefore, your statement is said to be contradictory to your own action, like saying I am dumb.

original: māyāni ṭa /ka / /nādi kriṭa /ka /ga /rā / /ghapra ṭa /rā / syādarśa ga /rā / /svakriṭa /ga /rā / /nena viṭa /ga /rā / /vivāṭa /ga / /lgigitameṭha / 🔽dhuṭha /ḍa / 🔽svaktavyāniyānuttibhaṅgaḥ🔽vyāptivādaḥ pu /
analyzed: na ādi kriṭakagarā ghapra ṭarā viṭagarā  dhuṭhaḍa            vyāptivādaḥ pu
translated: Māyā ni ṭ. Ka. .. Ādi kri ṭ. Ka. Ga. Ra. .. Ghapra ṭ. Ra. Syād arśa ga. Ra. .. Svakri ṭ. Ga. Ra. .. Nena vi ṭ. Ga. Ra. .. Vivāṭa ga. .. Lgi-gita-meṭha. 🔽Dhura ṭ. 🔽The refutation of the non-assertion of what is to be stated.🔽The statement on pervasion. Pu. 🔽🔽

original: kiñca śaṅkānivartakena vyāghātena nivartyāyāḥ śaṅkāyāḥ svasmātpūrvasatvamevāpekṣyate/🔽tāvataiva dhvaṃsaṃ pratīva pratiyogitvopapatteḥ/🔽na tu yāvatsvāvasthānaṃ sahabhāvaḥ/🔽tathātve hi virodha eva na syāt/🔽nahi viśeṣadarśananivartyā śaṅkā bādha nivartyā bhrāntiḥ brahmajñānanivartyāvidyā tejonivartyaṃ timiraṃ ca nivartakasamakālaṃ dṛṣṭam/🔽bhinnakālīnā ca śaṅkā vyāghātena nivartitatvānna vyāghātakālesti/🔽yena tarkāpekṣā syāt/🔽anyathā brahmajñānādyanantaramapyavidyādikaṃ syāt//
analyzed: kiñca śaṅkā nivartakena vyāghātena nivartyāyāḥ śaṅkāyāḥ svasmāt pūrva sattvam eva apekṣyate 🔽tāvatā eva dhvaṃsam prati iva pratiyogi tva upapatteḥ 🔽na tu yāvat sva avasthānam sahabhāvaḥ 🔽tathātve hi virodhaḥ eva na syāt 🔽nahi viśeṣa darśana nivartyā śaṅkā bādha nivartyā bhrāntiḥ brahma jñāna nivartyā avidyā tejaḥ nivartyam timiram ca nivartaka sama kālam dṛṣṭam 🔽bhinna kālīnā ca śaṅkā vyāghātena nivartita tvāt na 🔽yena tarka apekṣā syāt 🔽anyathā brahma jñāna ādi anantaram api avidyā ādikam syāt

original: etena vyāghātasya svarūpasataḥ śaṅkānivartakatve śaṅkā nityanivṛttā syāt/
analyzed: etena vyāghātasya svarūpa sataḥ śaṅkā nivartaka tve śaṅkā nitya nivṛttā syāt
translated: By this, if contradiction were to remove doubt as an existent entity, the doubt would be eternally removed.

analyzed: vyāghāta udbhāvana vaiyarthyam ca syāt
translated: And there would be futility in pointing out the contradiction.

analyzed: jñātasya nivartaka tve
translated: If what is known were to be the remover,

original: śaṅkāyāḥ satvamupetyāpi na doṣa ityāha kiṃ ceti//
analyzed: śaṅkāyāḥ satvam upetya api na doṣaḥ iti āha kim ca iti
translated: even accepting the existence of doubt, there is no fault. He says What's more etc.

analyzed: virodhaḥ eva na syāt iti
translated: There would be no contradiction at all etc.

original: sahānavasthānarūpatvādvirodhasyeti bhāvaḥ/🔽nājāta ekonyaṃ hanti nāpyanyādhāra iti nyāyena vadhyaghātakasthale sahāvasthānamāvaśyakamityato deśatastathātvepi na kālatastathātvaṃ kintu
analyzed: saha anavasthāna rūpa tvāt virodhasya iti bhāvaḥ  na ajātaḥ ekaḥ nyam hanti na api anya ādhāraḥ iti nyāyena vadhya ghātaka sthale saha avasthānam āvaśyakam iti atas deśataḥ tathātve pi na kālataḥ tathātvam kintu
translated: The idea is that contradiction has the form of not co-existing.🔽By the principle that what is not born does not kill another, nor does it have another as its basis, co-existence is necessary in the case of what is killed and what kills. Therefore, even though there is suchness in terms of space, there is not suchness in terms of time, but rather

analyzed: paurvāparyam eva iti bhāvena āha na hi iti
translated: sequence alone. With this in mind, he says not etc.

analyzed: nivartya avidyā iti atra avidyā iti vibhāgaḥ
translated: In the ignorance to be removed, the word ignorance is analyzed.

original: nanu yadāṅkaḍhācicchaṅkāyāḥ satve syādeva tannivṛtyarthaṃ tarkāpekṣetyanavasthāpattirevetyata āha bhinneti//
analyzed: nanu syāt eva tad nivṛti artham tarka apekṣā iti anavasthā āpattiḥ eva iti atas āha bhinna iti
translated: But when there is the existence of doubt somewhere, it would indeed be necessary to depend on reasoning for its removal. Thus, the regress argument is itself established. To this he says different etc.

analyzed: iṣṭa āpattiḥ iti atas āha vyāghāta iti
translated: The reply is The contradiction etc.

analyzed: na sva niṭaka garā
translated: Not in one's own.
The Nyaya-Tandava with the Nyaya-Dipika, Third Section

original: vyāghātarūpavirodhasya tadabhāvavyāpyatvātmakatayā vyāptigarbhitatvena tajjñānāya punastakrāpekṣetikhaṇḍanaślokasya vyākhyānāntaramapyapāstam/
analyzed: vyāghāta rūpa virodhasya tad abhāva vyāpya tva ātmaka tayā vyāpti garbhita tvena tad jñānāya punar takra apekṣā iti khaṇḍana ślokasya vyākhyāna antaram api apāstam
translated: The other explanation of the Khandana verse is also refuted, because the contradiction is essentially the pervasion of the absence of that, and because it is pervasion-containing, the knowledge of that requires the repetition of that.
Because it is said that only the specific perception that is the basis of one's own action removes doubt.

analyzed: vyāghāta avadhi tvāt śaṅkāyāḥ iti sudhāyāḥ api ayam eva abhiprāyaḥ
translated: This is also the intention of the Sudha, that doubt has a limit in contradiction.

analyzed: kecid tu vyabhicāra jñāna abhāva samāna kālīnam anvaya vyatireka anuvidhāyi tva jñānam śaṅkā nivartakam
translated: But some say that the knowledge of conformity and non-conformity, which is contemporaneous with the absence of knowledge of exception, removes doubt.

original: na tu tatprayojyā kriyā na ca kriyājñānaṃ śaṅkānivartakam yenānyonyāśrayaḥ syāt ityāhuḥ //
analyzed: na tu tad prayojyā kriyā na ca kriyā jñānam śaṅkā nivartakam yena anyonya āśrayaḥ syāt iti āhuḥ
translated: And that does not cause action, and the knowledge of action does not remove doubt, by which there would be mutual dependence.
Thus ends the refutation of the impossibility of ascertaining the pervasion stated by Khandana.

analyzed: tad abhāva iti
translated: In the absence of that,

analyzed: śaṅkā abhāva vyāpya iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that it is pervaded by the absence of doubt.

analyzed: vyākhyāna antarā iti
translated: By another explanation,

original: vyāghāto yadi svarūpasan śaṅkānivartakastarhi śaṅkānitya nivṛttā syāt iti śeṣaḥ/
analyzed: vyāghātaḥ yadi svarūpa san śaṅkā nivartakaḥ tarhi śaṅkānitya nivṛttā syāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: if contradiction, if it exists in its own form, removes doubt, then doubt would always be removed. The rest is implied.

analyzed: vyāghātasya sva rūpa sataḥ sarvadā abhāvāt
translated: Because contradiction, which exists in its own form, is always absent.

original: na caita tsvarūpasannivartakona cettajjñānāya vyāptijñānāpekṣāyāṃ vyabhicāraśaṅkāstyevetyevaṃ vyākhyānāntaramityarthaḥ/
analyzed: na ca etat svarūpa sannivartakaḥ na ced tad jñānāya vyāpti jñāna apekṣāyām vyabhicāra śaṅkā asti eva iti evam vyākhyāna antaram iti arthaḥ
translated: And this is not a cause of the cessation of its own nature. If it were not so, then when there is a need for the knowledge of that [nature] through the knowledge of pervasion, there would be doubt of fallacy. This is the meaning of the other explanation.

analyzed: svakriyā iti
translated: One's own action.

analyzed: pravṛti ādi rūpa svakriyā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is one's own action in the form of engagement etc.

analyzed: ukta tvāt iti
translated: Because it has been stated.

analyzed: na hi mayā ityādi pūrva granthena ukta tvat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is because it has been stated by the previous text beginning with not by me.

analyzed: sudhāyāḥ api iti
translated: Even of the Sudha.
In the method of the Bhaktipada etc.

analyzed: jātiḥ sva vyāhatiḥ jñeyā chalam artha antara uttara
translated: The fallacy of contradiction should be known as a species, and quibble as a reply with a different meaning.

original: mityetavdyākhyānasudhāyā api nahi mayetyādinokta evābhiprāya ityarthaḥ/
analyzed: m iti etad vyākhyāna sudhāyāḥ api nahi mayā ityādinā uktaḥ eva abhiprāyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the intention stated by the text beginning with not by me is not even of the Sudha commentary on this.

analyzed: anvaya iti
translated: In the case of.

analyzed: bhojana ādau sati tṛpti ādi tad abhāve tad abhāve iti anvaya vyatireka anuvidhāyi tva jñānam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is the knowledge that it conforms to positive and negative concomitance, that there is satisfaction etc. when there is eating etc., and its absence when that is absent.

analyzed: anyonya iti
translated: Mutually dependent.🔽The meaning is the mutual dependence stated earlier.

analyzed: atra aruci bījam tu yatra āpta vākya ādi janya viśeṣa darśanena sva kriyā tatra anvaya vyatireka jñāna abhāvāt
translated: The seed of dislike here is that where there is one's own action by the perception of a particular caused by the statement of a reliable person etc., there is an absence of the knowledge of positive and negative concomitance.

analyzed: anvaya vyatireka anuvidhāyi tva jñānasya api viśeṣa darśana asmad ukta rīteḥ eva anusartavya tvāt kim anena iti
translated: Because the knowledge of conformity with positive and negative concomitance should also follow the method stated by us, what is the use of this?

analyzed: iti khaṇḍana ukta vyāpti niścaya anupapatti bhaṅgaḥ
translated: Thus ends the refutation of the impossibility of ascertaining the vyapti stated by Khandadeva.

analyzed: pra tva abhi tva yaḥ vyā he kha kta sā pra ṅga ṅgaḥ
translated: The section on the non-establishment of the vyapti between being and non-being.

analyzed: vyāptivādaḥ pu
translated: The section on vyapti.

analyzed: atha prameya tva abhidheya tvayoḥ vyāpti grahe
translated: Now, the refutation of the unwanted consequence of omniscience in the ascertainment of vyapti between prameyatva and abhidheyatva, as stated by Khandadeva.

analyzed: atra uktam khaṇḍane
translated: Here it is said in Khandana

analyzed: evam ced prameya tva abhidheya tvayoḥ vyāptim gṛhṇataḥ sārvajñyam syāt
translated: If it is so, then one who grasps the vyapti between prameyatva and abhidheyatva would be omniscient.

original: tathāca sarvāntargatāśeṣaviśeṣāṇāṃ jñātatvādayaṃ ghaṭo ne ti saṃśayādikaṃ na syāt/
analyzed: tathā ca sarva antargata aśeṣa viśeṣāṇām jñāta tvāt ayam ghaṭaḥ na iti saṃśaya ādikam na syāt
translated: And thus, because all the particulars included in everything would be known, there would be no doubt etc. like this is a pot.

analyzed: atha prameya tva abhidheya tvayoḥ vyāpti grahe
translated: Now, the refutation of the unwanted consequence of omniscience in the ascertainment of vyapti between prameyatva and abhidheyatva, as stated by Khandadeva.

analyzed: atra iti vyāpti jñāna viṣaye dūṣaṇam uktam iti arthaḥ
translated: Here it is said - the fault is stated with regard to the object of knowledge of vyapti.

analyzed: evam ced iti
translated: If it is so -

analyzed: vyabhicārāḥ bhāva sahacāra jñāna sahakṛta pratyakṣeṇa vyāpti grahaḥ ced iti arthaḥ
translated: if the grasping of vyapti is by perception aided by the knowledge of the absence of vyabhicara and co-existence.

analyzed: astu iti atas āha tathā ca iti
translated: Let it be so. Then he says thus.

original: saṃśayādikaṃ saṃśayaviparyayajñānādikaṃ na syādityarthaḥ/ 🔽yaccoktaṃṭa / /na cetika / /navetiga /ṭa /rā / /rajñānābhāvasahakṛtapratyakṣeṇa vyāptiścedityarthaḥ/
analyzed: saṃśaya ādikam saṃśaya viparyaya jñāna ādikam na syāt iti arthaḥ  yat ca uktam na ca itika na vā iti gaṭarā ra jñāna abhāva sahakṛta pratyakṣeṇa vyāptiḥ ced iti arthaḥ
translated: And what is said - if the non-existence of cognition is the reason for the non-existence of doubt and other cognitions, then let it be so.

analyzed: ityastuṭha tatas cetiṭha
translated: And from that,

original: pu / nyāyadīpayutatarkatāṇḍavam tṛ /paricchedaḥ 🔽na ca prameyamiti jñānaṃ sarvaviṣakamapi prameyatvaprakārameva na tu ghaṭatvādiprakārakaṃ /
analyzed: na ca prameyam iti jñānam sarva viṣakam api prameya tva prakāram eva na tu ghaṭa tva ādi prakārakam
translated: The Nyāyadyuti along with the Tarkatāṇḍava, Third Chapter🔽And the knowledge that something is an object of knowledge, even if it has all objects as its content, has only the form of being an object of knowledge, not the form of being a pot, etc.

analyzed: samāna prakārakam eva ca jñānam vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that knowledge with the same form alone prevents doubt, etc.

analyzed: tad prakāraka tvam hi tad vaiśiṣṭya viṣayaka tvam
translated: For, having that form means being the content of something qualified by that.

analyzed: prameyam iti jñānam ca sarva viṣayaka tvāt ghaṭa tva ādi vaiśiṣṭya viṣayakam eva iti
translated: And the knowledge that something is an object of knowledge, because it has all objects as its content, is only the content of something qualified by being a pot, etc.

original: atra kecidāhuḥ yadyapi prameyamiti jñānaṃ ghaṭatvādivaiśiṣṭyaviṣayakatvam/
analyzed: atra kecid āhuḥ yadi api prameyam iti jñānam ghaṭa tva ādi vaiśiṣṭya viṣayaka tvam
translated: Here, some say: Although the knowledge that something is an object of knowledge has as its content the qualification of being a pot, etc.,

original: tathāpi na ghaṭatvādiviśeṣaṇajñānajanyaṃ prameyamiti jñānātpūrvaṃ ghaṭatvādijñānaniyame mānābhāvāt/
analyzed: tathā api na ghaṭa tva ādi viśeṣaṇa jñāna janyam prameyam iti jñānāt pūrvam ghaṭa tva ādi jñāna niyame māna abhāvāt
translated: nevertheless, it is not produced by the knowledge of the qualification of being a pot, etc., because there is no reason to determine that the knowledge of being a pot, etc. precedes the knowledge that something is an object of knowledge.

original: janyajñānasya saṃśayādivirodhitve ca tadviśeṣaṇajñānajanyatvaṃ tantramiti saṃśayādikaṃ yuktamiti//🔽yadvā yathā jñānasya svābhāvena svaviṣayeṇa ca saha saṃbandhe viśiṣṭepyabhāvādvyāvṛtto viṣayeṇa saha saṃbandhaviśeṣo 'ntya eva /
analyzed: janya jñānasya saṃśaya ādi virodhi tve ca tad viśeṣaṇa jñāna janya tvam tantram iti saṃśaya ādikam yuktam iti  yat vā yathā jñānasya sva abhāvena sva viṣayeṇa ca saha saṃbandhe viśiṣṭe ipi abhāvāt vyāvṛttaḥ viṣayeṇa saha saṃbandha viśeṣaḥ ntyaḥ eva
translated: And if the produced cognition were contradictory to doubt etc., then the production of the cognition of its qualifier would be the determining factor, so doubt etc. are proper.🔽Or, just as in the relation of cognition with its own nature and object, even though there is no difference, the final relation with the object is different, being excluded from the other.

original: yathā vā ghaṭayamityatra ghaṭaghaṭatvayorviṣayatve 'viśiṣṭepi ghaṭatvāṃśe viśeṣyavyāvṛttaḥ/
analyzed: yathā vā ghaṭayam iti atra ghaṭa ghaṭa tvayoḥ viṣayatve viśiṣṭe api ghaṭa tva aṃśe viśeṣya vyāvṛttaḥ
translated: Or, just as in the expression I am cognizing the pot, even though the objectness of the pot and potness is not different, the relation with the potness part is different, being excluded from the qualifier.

analyzed: sabandhaḥ nyaḥ eva
translated: The relation is entirely different.

analyzed: saṃśaya ādi upapattim āśaṅkya nirāha na ca iti
translated: Fearing the possibility of doubt etc., he refutes it with And it is not so.

analyzed: samāna iti
translated: Sameness means

original: ayaṃ ghaṭo na vetyādisaṃdehasya ghaṭa evāyamiti ghaṭatvādiprakārakaniścayanivartyatvāditi bhāvaḥ/
analyzed: ayam ghaṭaḥ na vā ityādi saṃdehasya ghaṭaḥ eva ayam iti ghaṭa tva ādi prakāraka niścaya nivartya tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: the doubt Is this a pot or not? is to be removed by the ascertainment This is indeed a pot, which has the form of potness etc. This is the idea.

original: ghaṭatvādiprakārakamapi bhavati prameyatvena jñānamityāha tatprakārakatvaṃ hīti//
analyzed: ghaṭa tva ādi prakārakam api bhavati prameya tvena jñānam iti āha tad prakāraka tvam hi iti
translated: He says that the cognition of an object as an object of knowledge also has the form of potness etc. with For, having that form.
The reflection on potness etc.

analyzed: vaiśiṣṭya iti
translated: Vaisistya means

analyzed: bhāsamāna vaiśiṣṭya pratiyogi tva rūpa tvāt prakāra tvasya iti bhāvaḥ
translated: the nature of being the counter-correlate of the manifested relation, this is the idea of the nature of being a form.

analyzed: kecid tu tārkikāḥ
translated: But some logicians say:

original: viśeṣa jñānaṃ kāraṇaṃ neti matenāha yadveti// anya eveti//
analyzed: viśeṣa jñānam kāraṇam na iti matena āha yat vā iti anyaḥ eva iti
translated: The cause is not the knowledge of the specific, according to the view expressed by 'or'. 'Other' means

original: nasya sarva ga / /tatra ke ga /rā / /avi ka /ga /ṭa / saviga /rā / /t tārkiṭa /ṭha /ḍa / /ṇajñāṭa /ṭha /
analyzed: na sya sarva ga tatra ke garāḥ a vi kagaṭa sa vigarā t tārkiṭa ṭha ḍa ṇa jñāṭa ṭha
translated: not all-pervading. There, what are the two? A and G. R and A. V and G. R and A. T and R. K and T. D and T. Ḍ and T. Ṇ and J. Ṭ and Ṭ.

analyzed: pratva abhi tvayoḥ vi ā he kha kta sā pra ṅgaḥ ṅgaḥ
translated: The two, 'pratva' and 'abhitva', have the same meaning.

original: vyāptivādaḥ pu / 🔽tathā ghaṭoyaṃ prameyamiti jñānadvayepi ghaṭatvasya bhāsamānavaiśiṣṭyapratiyogitvarūpa🔽prakāratve 'viśiṣṭepi ghaṭoyamitijñānasya pramayemiti jñānādvyāvṛtto ghaṭatvavaiśiṣṭyāṃśe
analyzed: vyāptivādaḥ pu  tathā ghaṭaḥ yam prameyam iti jñāna dvaye pi ghaṭa tvasya bhāsamāna vaiśiṣṭya pratiyogi tva rūpa  prakāra tve viśiṣṭe api ghaṭaḥ yam iti jñānasya pramayā īm iti jñānāt vyāvṛttaḥ ghaṭa tva vaiśiṣṭya aṃśe
translated: The doctrine of pervasion.🔽Similarly, in the two cognitions 'this pot is an object of knowledge', although the form of potness is the same, being the qualifier in the cognition 'this is a pot' and the qualifier-cum-qualificand in the cognition 'this is an object of knowledge',

analyzed: saṃbandhaḥ nyaḥ eva
translated: the relation in the part qualified by potness is different in the cognition 'this is a pot' from that in the cognition 'this is an object of knowledge'.

original: tena ca svarūpasatā saṃbandhena ghaṭatvaviṣayakatvaṃ saṃśayavirodhitvena tantram/
analyzed: tena ca svarūpa satā saṃbandhena ghaṭa tva viṣayaka tvam saṃśaya virodhi tvena tantram
translated: And by that relation which exists as the form, the fact of being about potness by means of the relation which exists as the form is a factor in being opposed to doubt.

analyzed: tat ca prameyam iti jñāne na asti iti saṃśaya ādikam yuktam
translated: And that is absent in the cognition 'this is an object of knowledge', so doubt etc. are proper.

analyzed: etat eva abhipretya uktam ācāryaiḥ
translated: With this very thing in mind, the teachers have said:

analyzed: sarvam sāmānyatas yasmāt sarvaiḥ      anubhūyate
translated: Because everything is experienced by all in a general way,

analyzed: iti sāmānyatas svarūpa satā sambandha sāmānyena hetunā iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is: by the reason of generality, by the relation which exists as the form.

analyzed: yat vā yathā śvaitya sākṣātkāra anumityoḥ viṣaya kṛta viśeṣa abhāve api
translated: Or, as in the case of the perception of whiteness and the inference of it, although there is no difference in the object,

analyzed: pratiyogi anuyogi bhāvāt sva abhāva sabandha śīta viṣaya viṣayībhāva rūpaḥ nyaḥ eva iti arthaḥ ghaṭa tvām
translated: the relation between the object and the subject is of a different kind, consisting of the relation of the antecedent and consequent due to the natural relation. The meaning is that the knowledge of the universal 'pot' is different from that of the particular pot.

original: śe ghaṭatvena saha jñānasya viśeṣyavyāvṛtto 'nya evetyarthaḥ/
translated: The meaning is that the knowledge of the universal 'pot' along with the particular pot is different from the particular pot.

analyzed: tatas ca kim iti atas āha tena ca iti
translated: And what follows from that? Therefore, he says 'by that'.

analyzed: uktam iti
translated: 'It has been said'

analyzed: taittirīyabhāṣye
translated: in the Taittiriya commentary.

analyzed: prakṛta upayogi tayā artham āha sāmānyatas iti
translated: For the benefit of the present context, he says 'in general'.

analyzed: saṃbandha sāmānya iti
translated: 'In the general relation'

analyzed: yādṛśa saṃbandhena jñānam saṃśaya ādi virodhi tad anyena sabandhena iti arthaḥ
translated: means by a relation other than the one by which knowledge is opposed to doubt etc. The meaning is by a different relation.

original: tādṛśasaṃbandhe vivādinaṃ pratyāha yadveti//🔽śaṅkhaḥ śveta iti sākṣātkārasya śaṅkhatvādi hetujanyānumiteścetyarthaḥ//
analyzed: tādṛśa saṃbandhe vivādinam pratyāha yat vā iti  śaṅkhaḥ śvetaḥ iti sākṣātkārasya śaṅkha tva ādi hetu janya anumiteḥ ca iti arthaḥ
translated: To one who disputes about such a relation, he says 'or'.🔽The meaning is of the perception 'the conch is white' and the inference produced by the reason 'conchness' etc.🔽Even though there is no difference in the object, the relation between the object and the subject is of a different kind, consisting of the relation of the antecedent and consequent due to the natural relation. The meaning is that the knowledge of the universal 'pot' is different from that of the particular pot.🔽The meaning is that the knowledge of the universal 'pot' along with the particular pot is different from the particular pot.

original: patve 'viga / /prameyamatijñānasya ityadhikamka / /rapyaga /rā / /yatheti na ka /ṭa / /tvādau ṭa / ghaṭatvāghaḍa / /ghaṭatvādināṭa /ṭha /
analyzed: pa tve prameya mati jñānasya iti adhikam ka rapya garāḥ yathā iti na tva ādau tva ādau ghaṭa tva āghaḍa ghaṭa tva ādinā ṭa ṭha
translated: And what follows from that? Therefore, he says 'by that'.

analyzed: diti heḍa
translated: 'It has been said'🔽in the Taittiriya commentary.🔽For the benefit of the present context, he says 'in general'.🔽'In the general relation'🔽means by a relation other than the one by which knowledge is opposed to doubt etc. The meaning is by a different relation.🔽To one who disputes about such a relation, he says 'or'.🔽The meaning is of the perception 'the conch is white' and the inference produced by the reason 'conchness' etc.
The Nyāyadyuti-yuta-tarkatāṇḍava🔽The third chapter

analyzed: karaṇa vaijātya prayuktāt jāti bhedāt eva pīta tva bhrama virodhi tva avirodhi tve
translated: The difference in the nature of the cause produces the difference in the nature of the cognition, and hence the difference in the nature of the error of yellowness being inconsistent or not inconsistent.

analyzed: yathā vā maṇḍūka vasā ajjana akta nayanasya
translated: Or just as for a person whose eyes are anointed with the ointment of frog fat,

analyzed: puṃsaḥ vaṃśe cākṣuṣa spārśanayoḥ sākṣātkārayoḥ viṣaya kṛta viśeṣa abhāve pi jāti bhedāt eva uraga bhrama nivartaka tva anivartaka tve
translated: even in the absence of any difference in the object, the difference in the nature of the two perceptions, visual and tactile, produces the fact that one removes the error of snake and the other does not.

analyzed: tathā viṣaya kṛta viśeṣa abhāve pi sāmānya pratyāsatya janyam jñānam saṃśaya virodhi
translated: Similarly, even in the absence of any difference in the object, the cognition produced by a general impression is inconsistent with doubt.

analyzed: na tu tad janyam
translated: But that produced by that [impression] is not.

analyzed: kāraṇa vaijātya prayuktāt vaidharmyāt
translated: Because of the difference in the nature of the cause.

analyzed: etat api uktam sāmānyatas iti
translated: This has also been said: 'in general'.

analyzed: sāmānya pratyāsattim apekṣya iti arthaḥ  athavā saṃśaya virodhi tve na ghaṭa tva prakāraka tva mātram tantram
translated: The meaning is: depending on a general impression.🔽Or, in being inconsistent with doubt, the fact of being of the form of the cognition of pot-ness is not the only [relevant] factor.

analyzed: nanu śaṅgha gata rekhā uparekha parimāṇa ādi viṣayaka tvam sākṣātkārasya asti na tu anumiteḥ atas katham viṣaya kṛta viśeṣa abhāvaḥ
translated: But the perception has as its object the lines and sub-lines on the conch, etc., but inference does not. So how can there be no difference in the object?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: bhrama virodhi tvam tad amśe viśeṣyasya
translated: Because the qualified part, by virtue of which it is contradictory to error, is intended.

original: na hi śvaityāṃśe dvayoḥ kaścidapi viśeṣostīti bhāvaḥ/
analyzed: na hi śvaitya aṃśe dvayoḥ kaścid api viśeṣaḥ usti iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that there is no difference between the two in the white part.

analyzed: nivartaka tva anivartaka tve iti
translated: With regard to being a remover and not being a remover.

analyzed: yathāyogam anvayaḥ na tu yathākramam
translated: The relation is according to suitability, not according to sequence.

analyzed: cākṣuṣa tva jāti ākrāntasya anivartaka tvam pratyuta bhrama janaka tvam eva spārśa tva jāti yuktasya na nivartaka tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that that which is pervaded by the class of being visual has non-removal, rather it is only the producer of error, and that which is endowed with the class of being tactile does not have removal.

analyzed: na tu tad janyam iti
translated: But it is not produced by that.

analyzed: prameya tva jñānam ca prameya tva rūpa sāmānya pratyāsatti janyam iti vākyaśeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the knowledge of being an object of knowledge is produced by the proximity of the universal in the form of being an object of knowledge.

analyzed: iti arthaḥ iti
translated: This is the meaning.

original: kāraṇe vai ka kāraṇavai ga /rā / /tve ghaka /rā / /tvaṃ ghaga / /yathākramamanvayaḥ cākṣuṣeti nirdeṣacākṣuṣetyarthaḥ na tu tajjanyamiti
analyzed: kāraṇe tve yathākramam anvayaḥ cākṣuṣā iti na tu tat janyam iti
translated: The relation is according to sequence in the cause, in the cause, in the cause.

analyzed: iti astiṭha
translated: But it is not produced by that.

analyzed: pratva abhi tvayoḥ vi ā he kha kta sā praṅga ṅgaḥ
translated: The relation between being an object of knowledge and being an object of knowledge is established by the pervasion.

analyzed: vyāptivādaḥ pu
translated: The doctrine of pervasion.
But it is the nature of being ascertained as having the form of a pot that is not related to the excluded class.

analyzed: tat ca ghaṭaḥ yam iti niścayaḥ usti
translated: And that is the ascertainment that this is a pot.

original: na tu prameyamiti niścaye/🔽tatra ghaṭatvasya virodhyavyā
analyzed: na tu prameyam iti niścaye  tatra ghaṭa tvasya virodhya vyā
translated: But not the ascertainment that it is an object of knowledge.

original: vṛttaprameyatvāliṅgitatvena prakāratvāt//🔽nanvevaṃ cet prameyatvaviśiṣṭaghaṭatvānayaṃ iti jñānamapi saṃśayavirodhi na syāt/🔽tatra ghaṭatvasya virodhisādhāraṇaprameyatvāliṅgitatvenaiva diti cenna/
analyzed: vṛtta prameya tva āliṅgita tvena prakāra tvāt  nanu evam ced prameya tva viśiṣṭa ghaṭa tvān ayam iti jñānam api saṃśaya virodhi na syāt  tatra ghaṭa tvasya virodhi sādhāraṇa prameya tva āliṅgita tvena eva prakāra tvāt iti ced na
translated: There, because the universal of pot is qualified by the universal of object of knowledge, which is incompatible with the universal of non-pot, it is a type.🔽If it is so, then the knowledge that the universal of pot is qualified by the universal of object of knowledge would also not be incompatible with doubt.🔽If it is argued that it is so because the universal of pot is qualified only by the universal of object of knowledge, which is common to the incompatible [universals], it is not so.

analyzed: udāhṛta jñāne ghaṭa tvavatvasya prameya tva āliṅgita tvena apratīteḥ
translated: Because in the cited knowledge, the possession of the universal of pot is not apprehended as qualified by the universal of object of knowledge.

original: prameyamitijñāne tu svasminbhāsamānasya sarvasyāpi prameyatvāliṅgitatvena pratīteḥ//
analyzed: prameyam iti jñāne tu svasmin bhāsamānasya sarvasya api prameya tva āliṅgita tvena pratīteḥ
translated: But in the knowledge of object of knowledge, everything that appears in itself is apprehended as qualified by the universal of object of knowledge.

analyzed: yadi api siddhānte sāmānya pratyāsattiḥ na asti
translated: Even though in the established doctrine there is no proximity of the universal,

analyzed: anugata dharmā pākaraṇāt pūrva paricchede  tathā api paramatā avaṣṭambhena idam samādhānam
translated: because the all-pervading property is denied in the previous chapter,🔽nevertheless, this solution is given in the context of the opponent's view.

original: yadvā sāmānyaṃ tu samānānāṃ sadṛśānāṃ bhāvaḥ sāmānyamiti sādṛśyamevetyanugatajātibhaṅgoktidiśā
analyzed: yat vā sāmānyam tu samānānām sadṛśānām bhāvaḥ sāmānyam iti sādṛśyam eva iti anugata jāti bhaṅga ukti diśā
translated: Or, the universal is the existence of similar things. Similarity itself is the universal. In the direction of the refutation of the all-pervading universal,

analyzed: prameya tva viśiṣṭa sādṛsya pratyāsattim vā vā apekṣya iti
translated: Or it may be that it requires the proximity in the form of similarity residing in the object of knowledge, which is qualified by the property of being an object of knowledge.

analyzed: sva mata rītiḥ evā iyam api iti dhyeyam
translated: It should be understood that this is also the method of our own view.

analyzed: saṃśaya virodhi tve iti vibhāgaḥ  na iti nañaḥ anvayaḥ
translated: The division is based on the fact that it is opposed to doubt.

analyzed: viruddhā iti
translated: The negative particle is construed with not that.

original: viruddhā yā koṭiḥ tadavyāvṛttaṃ tasyāṃ vidyamānaṃ yadrūpaṃ yo dharmaḥ tadanāliṅgitetyarthaḥ/
analyzed: viruddhā yā koṭiḥ tad avyāvṛttam tasyām vidyamānam yat rūpam yaḥ dharmaḥ tad anāliṅgita iti arthaḥ
translated: Contradictory means: that which is not excluded from the contradictory category, the form or property that exists in it, is meant by not connected with that.

analyzed: udāhṛta jñāne iti
translated: In the stated knowledge means

analyzed: prameya tva viśiṣṭa ghaṭa tvavān ayam iti ukta jñāna ākāraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: the form of the knowledge stated as This has the property of being qualified by the property of being an object of knowledge and having the nature of a pot.

analyzed: ghaṭa tvavat tvasya iti
translated: Of having the nature of a pot means

analyzed: virodhi iti virodhinī yā
translated: the exclusion of the contradictory property.
The third chapter of the Tarkatandava, along with the Nyāyadyot.
