analyzed: etat api uktam sāmānyatas iti  virodhi koṭi avyāvṛtta dharma āliṅgita tvena iti arthaḥ
translated: This is also said in general.🔽The meaning is: by not being connected with a property that is not excluded from the contradictory category.

analyzed: yat vā sāmānya pratyāsatti sāpekṣam jñānam
translated: Or, knowledge that requires the proximity of the general.

original: ghaṭasya prameyatvenaiva saha guṇapradhānabhāvalakṣaṇasaṃbandhaṃ gṛhṇāti na tu ghaṭatvādinā saha tadā tadagrahepi anyadā tadgrahasaṃbhavena
analyzed: ghaṭasya prameya tvena eva saha guṇa pradhāna bhāva lakṣaṇa saṃbandham gṛhṇāti na tu ghaṭa tva ādinā saha tadā tad agrahe api anyadā tad graha saṃbhavena
translated: It grasps the relation characterized by the relation of subordinate and principal only with the measurability of the pot, not with the potness etc. Even when that is not grasped at that time, it can be grasped at another time.

analyzed: hāni abhāvāt iti na saṃśaya virodhi
translated: Because there is no loss, it is not contradictory to doubt.

analyzed: etat api uktam sāmānyatas iti
translated: This is also said in general.

analyzed: guṇa pradhāna bhāva rūpa saṃbandham vinā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is without the relation in the form of the relation of subordinate and principal.

original: yadvā vyāptijñānaṃ viprakṛṣṭavyāpyāṃśe na niścayarūpaṃ kintu saṃbhāvanārūpam vyāptyaṃśe tu niścayarūpamiti narasiṃhākāramiti na kopi doṣaḥ/
analyzed: yat vā vyāpti jñānam viprakṛṣṭa vyāpya aṃśe na niścaya rūpam kintu saṃbhāvanā rūpam vyāpti aṃśe tu niścaya rūpam iti narasiṃha ākāram iti na kaḥ api doṣaḥ
translated: Or, the knowledge of the pervasion is not in the form of certainty regarding the distant pervaded part, but is in the form of possibility. But regarding the pervaded part, it is in the form of certainty. So there is no fault in the form of man-lion.

original: ata eva paddhatauyadyanyatrāpi dhūmaḥ syāttarhi tasyāpyevamityevaṃ vyāptigraho bhavatītyataḥ
analyzed: atas eva paddhatau yadi anyatra api dhūmaḥ syāt tarhi tasya api evam iti evam vyāpti grahaḥ bhavati iti atas
translated: For this very reason, in the Pañjikā, it is said that the apprehension of pervasion is as follows: If there is smoke elsewhere also, then it would be like that.

analyzed: kā atrā anupapattiḥ iti anena etam eva pakṣam uktvā etena prameya tva abhidheya tvayoḥ vyāptim
translated: Therefore, there is no inconsistency. Having stated this very view by this, the apprehension of pervasion between measurability and expressibility

analyzed: sārvajñya prasaṅgaḥ iti api parāstim iti uktam
translated: is also refuted by saying that omniscience would result.

analyzed: ghaṭa tva sya eva tad āliṅgita tva pratīteḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that only the potness is cognized as embraced by that.

analyzed: guṇa pradhāna bhāva iti
translated: The relation of subordinate and principal.

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is the relation of qualifier and qualified.

analyzed: paddhati anurodhena pakṣa antaram āha yat vā vyāpti jñānam iti
translated: In accordance with the Padarthadharmasangraha, he states another view: Or, the knowledge of pervasion.

analyzed: na niścaya rūpam iti vibhāgaḥ
translated: The division is: It is not of the nature of ascertainment.

analyzed: saṃbhāvanā rūpam saṃśaya rūpam
translated: It is of the nature of possibility, of the nature of doubt with a prominent conclusion.

analyzed: na kaḥ api iti
translated: Not angry.

analyzed: sārvajñya āpatti doṣaḥ vā saṃśaya ādi abhāva āpatti doṣaḥ vā na iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: There is no fault of the attainment of omniscience, or the fault of the attainment of the absence of doubt, etc.

analyzed: evaṃrūpam jñānam adṛṣṭa caram iti atas laukika vaidika dṛṣṭāntau āha dṛṣyate iti
translated: Knowledge of this form is not seen. Therefore, he gives worldly and Vedic examples: It is seen.

analyzed: kā vā nugarā
translated: What is the meaning of anu?

analyzed: pratva abhi tvayoḥ vi ā he kha kta sā praṅga ṅgaḥ
translated: The connection between pratha and ābhita is stated.

analyzed: vyāptivādaḥ pu
translated: The section on pervasion.

original: dṛśyate hi yadyatithirāgacche ttarhi bhojayitavyaḥ yadi rathaṃrasāmā somaḥ syādaindravāyavāgrāt🔽gṛhṇīyādi vākyajanya jñānasya nimittāṃśe saṃbhāvanātvepi tasminsati naimittikaṃ
analyzed: dṛśyate hi yadi atithiḥ āgacche ttarhi bhojayitavyaḥ yadi rathaṃrasāmā somaḥ syāt aindra vāyava agrāt  gṛhṇīyāt iti vākya janya jñānasya nimitta aṃśe saṃbhāvanā tve pi tasmin sati naimittikam
translated: For example, if a guest arrives, he should be fed; if the Soma is Rathantarasaman, one should take the first cup for Indra and Vayu.

Even though the knowledge produced by the sentence is of the nature of possibility regarding the part of the cause, regarding the part that the effect should be done when that exists, it is of the nature of ascertainment.

analyzed: etat api uktam sāmānyatas iti
translated: This is also said in general.

analyzed: sāṃmugdhyena nirdhāraṇa audāsīnyena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: by direct perception, with indifference to determination.

original: anyathā tavāpi sarvaṃ khalvidaṃ brahmetyādivākyārthadīrna syāt/
analyzed: anyathā tava api sarvam khalu idam brahma ityādi vākya artha dīḥ na syāt
translated: Otherwise, even for you, the meaning of statements like All this is Brahman would not be established.

analyzed: sarva śabda prayogāḥ ca na syāt
translated: And all uses of the word all would not be possible.

analyzed: sārvajñya āpattiḥ iti āpādanam ca na syāt iti uktam
translated: And the consequence of omniscience would not be possible, it has been said.

analyzed: iti prameya tva abhidheya tvayoḥ vyāpti grahe
translated: Thus, the refutation of the consequence of omniscience stated by Khaṇḍana in the ascertainment of pervasion between being an object of knowledge and being expressible is completed.

analyzed: yadi rathantara iti
translated: If it is said in the Rathantara,

analyzed: somaḥ jyotiṣṭomaḥ
translated: Soma is the Jyotiṣṭoma.

original: jyotiṣṭome hi rathantaraṃ pṛṣṭaṃ bṛhatpṛṣṭaṃ bhavatīti vaikalpike rathantarākhyabṛhadākhyasāmanī🔽śrute tathāgnidevatetyupāṃśumāsādayati somo devatetyantaryāmyasyetyādinolūkhalākārāḥ
analyzed: jyotiṣṭome hi rathantaram pṛṣṭam bṛhat pṛṣṭam bhavati iti vaikalpike rathantara ākhya bṛhat ākhya sāmanī  śrute tathā agni devatā iti upāṃśum āsādayati somaḥ devatā iti antaryāmī asya ityādinā ulūkhala ākārāḥ
translated: For in the Jyotiṣṭoma, the Rathantara is mentioned as an option, and the Bṛhat is mentioned as an option. The two Sāmans called Rathantara and Bṛhat

analyzed: graha śabditāḥ pātra viśeṣāḥ ca śrutāḥ
translated: are mentioned. Similarly, the vessels called grahas are mentioned in the form of mortars, such as He obtains the Upāṃśu with Agni as the deity, the Antaryāmya with Soma as the deity, and so on.

original: tatra somo jyotiṣṭomo yadi rathantarākhyasomayuktaḥ syāt tadā aindravāyava evāgraḥ prāthamiko yeṣāṃ tānaindravāyavāgrāngṛhṇīyādityarthaḥ/
analyzed: tatra somaḥ jyotiṣṭomaḥ yadi rathantara ākhya soma yuktaḥ syāt tadā aindra vāyavaḥ eva agraḥ prāthamikaḥ yeṣām tān aindra vāyava agrān gṛhṇīyāt iti arthaḥ
translated: Among them, if Soma, the Jyotiṣṭoma, were to be connected with the Soma called Rathantara, then the meaning is that he should take those that have the Aindravāyava as the first, i.e., as the primary.

analyzed: vicāritam ca etat vākyam dvitīyasya tṛtīya pādīya ādi anaye
translated: This statement has been discussed in the first aphorism of the third chapter of the second part.

analyzed: anyathā iti
translated: If it is said otherwise,
The meaning is that none of the six alternatives stated earlier is accepted.

analyzed: tava api iti
translated: Yours also means

analyzed: khaṇḍana kārasya api iti arthaḥ  iti prameya tva abhidheya tvayoḥ vyāpti grahe
translated: the author of the Khandana also.

original: tsa bhoṭa / /tyādi vāṭa /rā / /nyasya jñā ṭa / 🔽pu / nyāyadīpayutatarkatāṇḍavam tṛ /paricchedaḥ 🔽atha pakṣatāvādaḥ // // /
analyzed: tsa bhoṭa tyādi vāṭarā nyasya jñā ṭa             atha pakṣatā vādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the refutation of the consequence of the necessity of admitting omniscience stated by Khandadeva in the ascertainment of the pervasion between being an object of knowledge and being an object of expression.🔽That is the end of the chapter on the definition of paksha.

analyzed: atha para ukta pakṣa lakṣaṇa bhaṅgaḥ
translated: Now begins the discussion on paksha.🔽Now begins the refutation of the definitions of paksha stated by others.

analyzed: atha pakṣatā nirūpyate
translated: Now paksha is being defined.

analyzed: tatra na tāvat sandhigdha sādhya dharmā dharmī pakṣaḥ
translated: The subject which is doubtful with regard to the presence of the property to be proved is not the paksha.

analyzed: atha pakṣatā vādaḥ
translated: Now begins the discussion on paksha.

analyzed: atha para ukta pakṣa lakṣaṇa bhaṅgaḥ
translated: Now begins the refutation of the definitions of paksha stated by others.

original: evamanumānavakṣaṇaṃ tadaṅga vyāptisvarūpaṃ tanniścayopāya muktvā tatra bādhakaṃ ca nirasyedānīmanumānasahakārisaṃpattirūpāvasaraprāptā
analyzed: evam anumāna vakṣaṇam tat aṅga vyāpti svarūpam tad niścaya upāya muktvā tatra bādhakam ca nirasya idānīm anumāna sahakāri saṃpatti rūpa avasara prāptā
translated: Thus, after stating the definition of inference, its auxiliary, the nature of vyapti, the means of ascertaining it, and refuting the objections against it, now, the attainment of the auxiliary of inference, which has come up as an occasion,

analyzed: pakṣatā nirūpyate iti āha atha iti
translated: is being defined as paksha. Thus it is said.

original: yadvānumānasya dvayaṃ sāmarthyaṃ vyāptiḥ samucitadeśavṛttitvaṃ ca/
analyzed: yat vā anumānasya dvayam sāmarthyam vyāptiḥ samucita deśa vṛtti tvam ca
translated: Or, there are two kinds of capacity of inference: vyapti and existence in a suitable place.

analyzed: tatra antyam api dvedhā
translated: Among them, the last one is also of two kinds.

analyzed: pakṣa dharmatā rūpā tad anya rūpā ca iti
translated: It is of the form of being a property of the subject and of a different form.

original: kayościtsamānadeśakālayoḥ kayościdbhinnadeśakālayorityādipaddhatyukteḥ/🔽tathā ca kvācitkapakṣadharmatāsāpekṣatvātsā nirūpyata ityāha atheti//
analyzed: kayoḥ cit samāna deśa kālayoḥ kayoḥ cit bhinna deśa kālayoḥ ityādi paddhati ukteḥ  tathā ca kvācitka pakṣa dharmatā sāpekṣa tvāt sā nirūpyate iti āha atha iti
translated: Because it is stated in the Paddhati that it is of two kinds - of those that are in the same place and time and of those that are in different places and times, and so on.🔽And thus, because it depends on the property of the subject being sometimes present, it is being determined. He says then (in the text).

analyzed: tatra pakṣatā nirūpaṇe kārye sati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: when the determination of the nature of the subject is to be done.

analyzed: saṃdigdha sādhya dharma iti  sādhya dharma iti eva uktau sapakṣasya api pakṣatā āpātāt saṃdigdhā iti uktam
translated: The subject is doubtful with regard to the property to be proved (in the text).🔽If it is said simply the property to be proved, then the similar instance would also be the subject. Therefore, doubtful is said (in the text).

analyzed: dharmi padam spaṣṭa artham iti eke
translated: Some say that the word subject has a clear meaning.

analyzed: prāmāṇika tva kathanāya iti anye
translated: Others say that it is for the purpose of stating what is authoritative.

original: sādhanetivyāptivāraṇāya dharmipadam dharmitvaṃ ca sādhyāpekṣayā dhyeyamiti prekṣāvantaḥ//
analyzed: sādhana itivyāpti vāraṇāya dharmi padam dharmi tvam ca sādhya apekṣayā dhyeyam iti prekṣāvantaḥ
translated: The word subject is used to exclude over-extension in the proof. And the nature of being a subject should be understood in relation to the probandum. Thus, the wise ones (say).🔽Bhūta (in the text) is redundant.

original: bhūtetyadhikamṭha / /yaṃ coktvā ṭha / /mitiprekṣāṭha /ḍa / m deya miti preṭha /
analyzed: ca uktvā deyam iti
translated: Having said this, it should be understood that it (in the text) refers to the subject.

analyzed: pakta palakṣa bhaṅgaḥ
translated: The analysis of the definition of the subject.

analyzed: pakṣatā vādaḥ  anumati kāle saṃdehasya asatvena viśeṣaṇa tva ayogāt
translated: The theory of the nature of the subject.🔽Because doubt does not exist at the time of inference, it cannot be a qualifier.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇa tve tiprasaṅgāt
translated: If it were an indicator, there would be an over-extension.

analyzed: asaṃdehe pi sāmagrī balāt anumiti darśanāt ca
translated: And because even in the absence of doubt, inference is seen due to the power of the collection of causes.

analyzed: nā api sādhaka māna abhāvaḥ yatra sa pakṣaḥ
translated: Nor is there absence of a proof in the case where it is the subject.

original: atra saṃdigdhaṃ ca tat sādhyaṃ ca saṃdigdhasādhyaṃ saṃdigdhasādhyaṃ dharmo yasyeti bahuvrīhau satidharmādanickevalādityanicpratyayaḥ/
analyzed: atra saṃdigdham ca tat sādhyam ca saṃdigdha sādhyam saṃdigdha sādhyam dharmaḥ yasya iti bahuvrīhau sati dharmāt anic kevalāt iti anic pratyayaḥ
translated: Here, that which is doubtful and also to be proved is the doubtful probandum. The compound 'saṃdigdhasādhya' is a bahuvrīhi compound. When there is a bahuvrīhi compound, the suffix 'ani' is added according to the rule 'sati dharmād ani kevalād iti'.

analyzed: tatra hi kevalāt iti na dharma viśeṣaṇam
translated: For there, 'kevalāt' is not a qualifier of 'dharma'.

analyzed: kintu bahuvrīhi ākṣipta pūrva padasya viśeṣaṇam
translated: But it is a qualifier of the preceding word implied by the bahuvrīhi compound.

original: tena pūrvapadībhavataḥ kevalādanyanirapekṣātparo yo dharmaśabdastadantādityartho bhavati/
analyzed: tena pūrvapadībhavataḥ kevalāt anya nirapekṣāt paraḥ yaḥ dharma śabdaḥ tad antāt iti arthaḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, the meaning becomes 'from that which ends with the word 'dharma', which is independent, i.e., not dependent on anything else, and which occurs as the first member'.

original: tathā ca saṃdigdhasādhyapadasya bahuvrīhau pūrvapadībhavato 'nyanirapekṣatvādbhavatyanijiti dhyeyam/
analyzed: tathā ca saṃdigdha sādhya padasya bahuvrīhau pūrvapadībhavataḥ dhyeyam
translated: And thus, in the bahuvrīhi compound of the word 'saṃdigdhasādhya', it should be understood that the suffix 'ani' is added because it is independent, i.e., not dependent on anything else, and occurs as the first member.

analyzed: etat ca dhātu vṛttau vyaktam
translated: And this is clear in the commentary on the root.

analyzed: ukta vigraha pakṣe kaivalyasya dharma viśeṣaṇa tve pi asti pratyaya prāptiḥ iti api āhuḥ
translated: In the case of the compound analyzed as above, even if 'kevalatva' (being alone) is a qualifier of 'dharma', they say that the suffix is obtained.

analyzed: a sattvena iti
translated: By 'non-existence' (asatvena).

original: parāmarśātpūrvaṃ liṅgadarśanavyāpti smaraṇādinā tasya nāśāditi bhāvaḥ/
analyzed: parāmarśāt pūrvam liṅga darśana vyāpti smaraṇa ādinā tasya nāśāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is destroyed by the perception of the reason, the recollection of pervasion, etc., before the superimposition (parāmarśa).

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt iti
translated: Due to excessive extension.

analyzed: siddhi daśāyām api pakṣa tā āpatteḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that even in the state of establishment, there is the occurrence of the subject.

analyzed: vyatireka vyabhicāra ca āha asaṃdehe pi iti
translated: And there is the fallacy of negative vyabhicāra (absence of the reason in similar instances) in the absence of doubt.

analyzed: ghana gharjita ādi sthale iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that in the case of the rumbling of clouds etc.

analyzed: yatra iti
translated: Where means

analyzed: yad niṣṭha sādhya viṣaye
translated: in that which is the locus of the probandum.

original: yadvā sādhyasādhakamānābhāvo yatra parvatādipradeśe sa ityarthaḥ/
analyzed: yat vā sādhya sādhaka māna abhāvaḥ yatra parvata ādi pradeśe saḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Or the meaning is that the absence of the means of knowing the probandum is in that place such as a mountain etc.

analyzed: evam agre pi
translated: Similarly later also.

original: śrotavyo gurūpadeśena jñātavyo mantavyo yuktyanusaṃdhānarūpamananotpannānumitirūpajñānena viṣayīkartavya ityarthaḥ/
analyzed: śrotavyaḥ guru upadeśena jñātavyaḥ mantavyaḥ yukti anusaṃdhāna rūpa manana utpanna anumiti rūpa jñānena viṣayīkartavyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: It means that it should be heard by the teacher's instruction, it should be known by the knowledge in the form of inference produced by the thought in the form of the investigation of reasoning, it should be made the object by the knowledge in the form of inference produced by the thought in the form of the investigation of reasoning.

original: yadātu dhātu vṛtyuktadiśā kevalāditi na dharmaviśeṣaṇaṃ kintu ityastu ṭha / /dhyeyamiti
analyzed: yadā tu dhātu vṛti ukta diśā kevalāt iti na dharma viśeṣaṇam kintu iti astu dhyeyam iti
translated: But when according to the explanation of the root's meaning, the qualifier is not from the mere preceding word but from the compound word, then it is to be thought of.

original: na ṭa /ḍa / /yadā tu 'vṛttau pañcamāntyapāde kevalātpūrvapadāt na padasamudāyāt ityuktadiśāthaḥ /
analyzed: na ṭa ḍa yadā tu vṛttau pañcama antya pāde kevalāt pūrva padāt na pada samudāyāt iti ukta diśā athaḥ
translated: But when according to the explanation in the fifth and last section of the commentary that it is from the mere preceding word and not from the compound word,

analyzed: tadā
translated: then it is to be thought of by oneself.

analyzed: asattvena iti ṭha
translated: In the absence of the suffix, the suffix is in excess.
The Nyāyadyuti along with the Tarkatāṇḍava, Third Section

original: śrotavyo mantavya ityādau sādhake satyapi pakṣatvadarśanāt/
analyzed: śrotavyaḥ mantavyaḥ ityādau sādhake sati api pakṣa tva darśanāt
translated: In the case of 'should be heard, should be thought of', etc., the subject is seen even when the means of knowledge is present.

analyzed: vipakṣasya api tad prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because of the undesirable consequence of that even in the case of the counter-example.

analyzed: nā api bādhaka māna abhāvaḥ yatra sa pakṣaḥ
translated: Nor is that the subject where there is absence of the contradictory cognition.

analyzed: sa pakṣasya api tad prasaṅgāt
translated: Because of the undesirable consequence of that even in the case of the subject.

analyzed: na api abhāva dvayam yatra sa pakṣaḥ
translated: Nor is that the subject where there are two absences.

analyzed: mantavyaḥ ityādau tad abhāve api pakṣa tvāt
translated: Because even in the absence of that, it is a subject, as in 'mantra' etc.

original: nāpi sādhāyavattayā viṣādhayiṣāviṣayo yaḥ sa pakṣaḥ/
analyzed: nā api sādhāyavat tayā viṣādhayiṣā viṣayaḥ yaḥ sa pakṣaḥ
translated: Nor is that the subject which is the object of desire to prove by the means of proof.

analyzed: anicchā yām api anumiti darśanāt
translated: Because even without desire, inference is seen.

analyzed: nanu siṣādhayiṣā viraha sahakṛta sādhaka māna abhāvaḥ yatra sa pakṣaḥ
translated: Is it not that the subject is where there is absence of the means of proof along with the absence of desire to prove?

analyzed: sādhake sati iti
translated: When there is the means of proof.

original: śravaṇaśabditaṃ upadeśajanyaṃ yajjñānaṃ tasminsatyeva tatsamānaviṣayaśravaṇānantarabhāvimanana rūpānumānena śravaṇaviṣayārthānumityanudayena 🔽mananavaiyarthyāpatteriti bhāvaḥ//
analyzed: śravaṇa śabditam upadeśa janyam yat jñānam tasmin sati eva tad samāna viṣaya śravaṇa anantara bhāvi manana rūpa anumānena śravaṇa viṣaya artha anumiti anudayena  manana vaiyarthya āpatteḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that when there is the knowledge called hearing, which is produced by instruction, then alone, after the hearing of the same object, the inference in the form of reflection does not produce the inference of the object which is the object of hearing,🔽there would be the uselessness of reflection.

analyzed: vipakṣasya iti
translated: 'Of the counter-example' means

analyzed: sādhya abhāvavataḥ
translated: of that which has the absence of the probandum.

analyzed: tatra sādhya abhāva sādhakasya eva satvena sādhya sādhak hasya abhāvāt
translated: Because there, only the prover of the absence of the probandum exists, and not the prover of the probandum.

analyzed: anena sapakṣasya api iti etat api vyākhyāta prāyam
translated: By this, 'of the similar instance' also is almost explained.

analyzed: tad abhāve api iti
translated: 'Even in the absence of that' means

analyzed: śravaṇa ādi rūpa sādhakasya eva tatra satvena abhāva dvaya abhāve pi pakṣatā satvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even though the two absences are absent there, due to the presence of the establisher in the form of hearing etc., there is absence of the subject.

analyzed: na api sādhyā iti
translated: Nor is it the probandum.

original: sādhyavatvena sādhayitumicchā sādhyavattayā siṣādhayiṣā tadviṣaya ityarthaḥ/
analyzed: sādhyavatvena sādhayitum icchā sādhyavat tayā siṣādhayiṣā tad viṣayaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the desire to prove something as having the property to be proved is the desire to prove it as having that property, and it has that as its object.

analyzed: aniṣṭāyāḥ aniṣṭa viṣayāyāḥ  icchām prati a viṣayībhūta padārtha viṣayāyāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Of what is undesirable, having an undesirable object.🔽The meaning is having an object that is not the content of desire.

analyzed: maṇi kṛtā lakṣaṇam āśaṅkate nanu iti
translated: Even though this definition has been established by the author of the Mīmāṃsā, he raises a doubt with the words But is it not so?🔽There is no yasas (he is).

original: yaḥ sa iti nāstiṭa /rā / /cchayānumitidaka / ṣṭāyāga /ṭa /rā / /śravaṇaviṣayārthasyānumānena tatra pakṣatābhāve anumityanudayenaityastiṭa /ḍa /
analyzed: yaḥ saḥ iti śravaṇa viṣaya arthasya anumānena tatra pakṣa tā abhāve anumiti anudayena eti asti ṭaṭaḍa
translated: The object that is the content of desire is not the object of inference, because in inference there is absence of the subject, and because there is no arising of inference.

analyzed: nena śraḥ iti astiṭha  pakta palaṇa bhaṅgaḥ
translated: By this, there is śra (hearing).

analyzed: pakṣatā vādaḥ
translated: The refutation of the view that the subject is the substratum of the probans and probandum.🔽The theory of the subject.

original: evaṃ ca mantavya ityatar siṣādhayiṣāviraharūpaviśeṣaṇābhāvāt ghanagarjitena madhānumāne
analyzed: evam ca mantavyaḥ siṣādhayiṣā viraha rūpa viśeṣaṇa abhāvāt ghana garjitena madhā anumāne
translated: And thus it should be understood that due to the absence of the qualifier in the form of the absence of the desire to prove, in the inference of rain from the rumbling of clouds,

original: sādhakamānarūpaviśeṣyābhāvāt siṣādhayiṣoḥ puṃso dhūmānumāne ubhayābhāvādvi śiṣṭābhāvādviśiṣṭābhāvo
analyzed: sādhaka māna rūpa viśeṣya abhāvāt siṣādhayiṣoḥ puṃsaḥ dhūma anumāne ubhaya abhāvāt vi śiṣṭa abhāvāt viśiṣṭa abhāvaḥ
translated: due to the absence of the qualificand in the form of the means of establishing, in the inference of smoke by a person who desires to prove, due to the absence of both, the absence of the qualified is the absence of the remainder.

analyzed: anugataḥ iti tatra tatra pakṣatā yuktā
translated: And the property of being the subject is present there, i.e., in the subject.

original: yatra tu siṣādhayiṣā virahayute spaṣṭadṛṣṭe ghaṭādau viśeṣaṇaṃ viśeṣyaṃ cāsti na tatra pakṣateti cenna/
analyzed: yatra tu siṣādhayiṣā viraha yute spaṣṭa dṛṣṭe ghaṭa ādau viśeṣaṇam viśeṣyam ca asti na tatra pakṣa tā iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that where there is absence of desire to prove, and where the qualifier and the qualified are clearly seen, as in a pot etc., there is no property of being the subject, it is not so.

original: asiṣādhayiṣordhūmānumāne ghanagarjitena meghānumāne cānumiteḥ pūrvaṃ liṅgaparāmarśarūpasadhakhamānasya satvenāpakṣatvāpātāt//
analyzed: asiṣādhayiṣoḥ dhūma anumāne ghana garjitena megha anumāne ca anumiteḥ pūrvam liṅga parāmarśa rūpa sadha kha mānasya satvena apakṣa tva āpātāt
translated: Because even for one who does not desire to prove, there would be the fault of not being the subject in the inference of smoke, and in the inference of clouds from dense thunder, due to the existence of the cognition in the form of the apprehension of the reason prior to the inference.

analyzed: maṇi ukta vivaraṇa pūrvakam prāc ukta doṣāḥ na iti āha evam ca iti
translated: Having stated the explanation given in the jewel, he says not so to the previously stated faults.

analyzed: evam pakṣa lakṣaṇe sati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: when there is a definition of the subject in this way.

analyzed: siṣādhayiṣoḥ iti etat siṣādhayiṣā viraha rūpa viśeṣa
translated: For one who does not desire to prove is stated to explain the absence of the qualifier in the form of absence of desire to prove.

analyzed: ubhayā iti
translated: Both means

analyzed: sādhaka mānasya siṣādhayiṣā virahasya ca abhāvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: the absence of the means of proof and the absence of desire to prove.

analyzed: evam avyāptim nirasya ativyāptim ca nirāha yatra tu iti
translated: Having thus refuted over-extension, he refutes over-extension by saying where there is absence of desire to prove.

analyzed: viśeṣaṇam iti
translated: The qualifier means

analyzed: siṣādhayiṣā virahaḥ pratyakṣa rūpa sādhaka mānam ca asti iti arthaḥ
translated: the absence of desire to prove and the means of proof in the form of perception exist.

analyzed: asiṣādhayiṣoḥ iti
translated: For one who does not desire to prove

analyzed: etat ca siṣādhayiṣā viraha rūpa viśeṣaṇa sadbhāvāya uktam evam
translated: This is stated to show the existence of the qualifier in the form of absence of desire to prove. Thus

original: ca tatra viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyayordvayorapi satvenānyatarābhāvena vobhayābhāvena vā na viśiṣṭābhāvastatrāstītyavyāptiriti bhāvaḥ//
analyzed: ca tatra viśeṣaṇa viśeṣyayoḥ dvayoḥ api satvena anyatara abhāvena vā ubhaya abhāvena vā na viśiṣṭa abhāvaḥ tatra asti iti avyāptiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that there is no absence of the qualified there, due to the existence of both the qualifier and the qualified, or due to the absence of either, or due to the absence of both.

original: viśiṣṭābhāvāditi nāstiṭa /ka /ga /rā / /punaḥ tatreti nāstika /ga /ṭa / prathamatopi nāstirā / /rahiteka /ga /ṭa / /ṣopaṭa / ṣābhāvoḍa /
analyzed: viśiṣṭa abhāvāt iti punar tatra iti nāstikagaṭa rahita ikagaṭa
translated: The absence of the qualified is not there. iti is not in K, G, and R. tatra is not in K, G, and T. prathamapi is not in R. rahitam is not in K, G, and T. ṣopakṣe is not in G. ṣābhāva is not in D.
The third chapter of the Nyāyadyuti-yuta-tarkatāṇḍava.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, if it is thought:

analyzed: siṣādhayiṣā viraha sahakṛta siddhi abhāvaḥ yatra sa pakṣaḥ
translated: That is a subject where there is an absence of the absence of accomplishment accompanied by the absence of desire to prove.

original: anumiteḥ pūrvaṃ ca sādhakamānatvepi na sādhyasya siddhirastīti tatra pakṣatā yuktā//
analyzed: anumiteḥ pūrvam ca sādhaka māna tve pi na sādhyasya siddhiḥ asti iti tatra pakṣatā yuktā
translated: And even before inference, although it is the means of proving, there is no accomplishment of what is to be proved, so the property of being a subject is proper there.

original: nanu evaṃ sati saṃśayānanatrapratyakṣasthale pakṣatā syāt/
analyzed: nanu evam sati saṃśaya ananatra pratyakṣa sthale pakṣatā syāt
translated: If that is so, then in a case of perception where there is doubt or non-apprehension, there would be the property of being a subject.

analyzed: tatra puruṣa tva siddhi rūpa viśeṣya abhāvena viśiṣṭa abhāva saṃbhavāt
translated: Because there is a possible absence of the qualified, which is the absence of the qualified in the form of the established existence of a man.

original: tasmātsiṣādhayiṣāvirahasaharakṛtasiddhitatkaraṇānyāntatvā vacchinnābhāvo yatra sa eva ca pakṣaḥ/
analyzed: tasmāt siṣādhayiṣā viraha sahara kṛta siddhi tad karaṇa anya anta tvā
translated: Therefore, that alone is the subject where there is an absence qualified by the absence of the means of accomplishing that accomplishment accompanied by the absence of desire to prove.

analyzed: pakṣadhara ādi ukta vivakṣām āśaṅkate atha matam ityādinā mā evam iti antena
translated: He raises the doubt expressed by Pakṣadhara and others with the words If it is argued and so on, up to not so.

analyzed: saṃśaya anantarā iti
translated: After doubt means

original: sthāṇurvā puruṣo veti saṃśayānantaraṃ puruṣatvavyāpyakarādirūpaviśeṣadarśanānantaraṃ puruṣa evāyamiti jāyamānapratyakṣasthala ityarthaḥ/
analyzed: sthāṇuḥ vā puruṣaḥ vā iti saṃśaya anantaram puruṣa tva vyāpya kara ādi rūpa viśeṣa darśana anantaram puruṣaḥ eva ayam iti jāyamāna pratyakṣa sthale iti arthaḥ
translated: after the doubt is it a post or a man, after seeing the specific features such as the hand etc. which are pervaded by manhood, the cognition this is a man arises. This is the meaning.

original: saṃśayānantarapratyakṣasthale doṣaparihārāya yajñapitanokta samādhiṃ pakṣadharādyuktadoṣeṇa pūrvapakṣimukhenaiva nirasitumāha tasmātsiṣādhayiṣeti//
analyzed: saṃśaya anantara pratyakṣa sthale doṣa parihārāya samādhim pakṣadhara ādi ukta doṣeṇa pūrvapakṣi mukhena eva nirasitum āha tasmāt siṣādhayiṣā iti
translated: In order to avoid the fault in the case of perception that occurs after doubt, he refutes the solution offered by Yajñapātra using the fault stated by Pakṣadhara and others, with the words Therefore, what is to be inferred and so on.

analyzed: siddhi tad karaṇa anyatara tva avacchinna iti asya niṣkarṣeṇa arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of restricted to being either the effect or the instrument is extracted as being different from that in the words not that.

original: siddhitatkaraṇābhyāṃ yadanyat jagat tadanyat siddhistatkaraṇaṃ ca tatvenetyarthaḥ/🔽anugatyarthamānyānyatvāvacchinnetyuktam/
analyzed: siddhi tad karaṇābhyām yat anyat jagat tad anyat siddhiḥ tad karaṇam ca tatvena iti arthaḥ  anugati artham ānya anya tva avacchinnā iti uktam
translated: The meaning is: that which is different from the effect and the instrument is different from the effect and the instrument.🔽Being different from that is stated in order to include the general meaning.

analyzed: anya anya tva avacchinna pratiyogitāka abhāvaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: the absence whose counter-correlate is restricted to being different from that.

analyzed: prāk ukta doṣam nirāha evam ca iti
translated: He rejects the previously stated fault with the words If it is so and so on.

original: nanvevaṃ dhūmādisthepyuktadiśā liṅgaparāmarśasatvātpakṣatā nasyādityata āha dhūmeti//
analyzed: nanu evam dhūma ādi stha ipi ukta diśā liṅga parāmarśa sattvāt pakṣatā na syāt iti atas āha dhūma iti
translated: But in that case, in the case of smoke etc. also, due to the presence of the apprehension of the inferential mark in the stated manner, there would be no pakshata. To this he says in smoke etc. etc.

analyzed: evam ca saṃśaya uttara pratyakṣa sthale iti ukta diśā
translated: The absence of the inferential mark is stated. The similar instance is stated. The difference from other things is stated. Thus, in the case of perception after doubt, as stated in the stated manner.

analyzed: pakta palaṇa bhaṅgaḥ
translated: The refutation of the objection regarding the definition of pakshata.

analyzed: pakṣatā vādaḥ
translated: The doctrine of pakshata.

original: evaṃ ca saṃśayānantarapratyakṣasthale ca siddherabhāvepi puruṣatvavyāpyakara caraṇādirūpasiddhikaraṇasya satvānna pakṣatā/
analyzed: evam ca saṃśaya anantara pratyakṣa sthale ca siddheḥ abhāve pi puruṣa tva vyāpya kara caraṇa ādi rūpa siddhi karaṇasya satvāt na pakṣa tā
translated: And in the case of perception after doubt, even though there is no establishment, due to the presence of the means of establishing the form of feet etc. which is pervaded by humanity, there is no pakshata.

analyzed: dhūma anumāne tu pakṣa tā yuktā
translated: But in the inference of smoke, pakshata is proper.
If it is argued that this is because the means of producing the inference, which is other than the apprehension of the inferential mark, is intended by the word 'means', it is not so.

analyzed: tatra pakṣatāyāḥ iṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because pakshata is accepted there.

analyzed: na ca evam tatra anumitiḥ eva syāt na tu pakṣatyakṣam
translated: And in that way, there would be only inference there, not perception of pakshata.

analyzed: anumiti sāmagryāḥ balavat tvāt
translated: Because the assemblage of causes of inference is strong.

original: anyathā dhūmānumānepi liṅgaparāmarśānantaraṃ tadanuvyavasāya eva syanna tvanumitiriti vācyam/
analyzed: anyathā dhūma anumāne api liṅga parāmarśa anantaram tad anuvyavasāyaḥ eva syan na tu anumitiḥ iti vācyam
translated: Otherwise, it should be said that even in the inference of smoke, after the apprehension of the inferential mark, there would be only the awareness of that, not inference.

analyzed: parāmarśa iti
translated: By the word 'apprehension' etc.

original: evaṃ cedapi saṃśayottarapratyakṣasthale puruṣatvavyāpyakarādidarśanarūpaparāmarśasatvepi taditarapatyakṣarūpasiddhikaraṇasyāpi satvān tatra
analyzed: evam ced api saṃśaya uttara pratyakṣa sthale puruṣa tva vyāpya kara ādi darśana rūpa parāmarśa satve pi tad itara patyakṣa rūpa siddhi karaṇasya api tatra
translated: Even so, in the case of perception arising from doubt, even though there is the recollection in the form of seeing the hand etc. pervaded by manhood, the cause of the establishment in the form of other perception also exists there,

analyzed: pakṣatā āpattiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: so there is the occurrence of the state of being the subject there. This is the idea.

analyzed: atamatam iti śaṅkitā eva nirāha tatra iti
translated: He rejects the doubt itself by saying 'not so, not so' in that case.

analyzed: saṃśaya uttara pratyakṣa sthale
translated: In the case of perception arising from doubt.

original: tathā ca tadarthaṃ siddhitatkaraṇānyānayatvetyādi na vaktavyamiti bhāvaḥ/
analyzed: tathā ca tad artham siddhi tad karaṇāni ānayatvā ityādi na vaktavyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus it is not necessary to say that for that purpose, the cause of establishment should be brought etc. This is the idea.

original: etena tatra pakṣatāvirahadarśanā tpakṣatāsatvasya tatra kenāpyakathanāditi maṇikaṇṭhoktaṃ nādartavyamityuktaṃ bhavati/
analyzed: etena tatra pakṣatā viraha darśanāt pakṣatā satvasya tatra kena api a kathanāt iti maṇikaṇṭha uktam na ādartavyam iti uktam bhavati
translated: By this, it is said that what Maṇikaṇṭha has said, that the absence of the state of being the subject there is seen, and the existence of the state of being the subject there is not stated by anyone, should not be followed.

analyzed: tad anuvyavasāyaḥ iti
translated: That is the cognition of that.

original: parāmarśotpatyanantaraṃ parāmarśānuvyavasāyaṃ pratibadhyānumiterevotpādobhyupagato 'numitisāmagryā balavatvayuktimāśritya tanna syāt ityarthaḥ/
analyzed: parāmarśa utpati anantaram parāmarśa anuvyavasāyam pratibadhya anumiteḥ eva utpādaḥ abhyupagataḥ numiti sāmagryāḥ balavatva yuktim āśritya tat na syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: After the production of the recollection, the production of only the inference is accepted, obstructing the cognition of the recollection of the inference, relying on the reason of the strength of the assemblage of the causes of inference. The meaning is that it should not be so.

analyzed: etat ca jñānasya bubhutsita grāhya tva matam āśritya uktam
translated: And this is said relying on the view that knowledge is to be grasped by the desirous.

analyzed: abubhutsita grāhya tve tu syāt eva anuvyavasāyaḥ iti dhyeyam
translated: But if the object is apprehended without desire to know, then there would be an after-knowledge, this should be borne in mind.

original: parāmarśasya caramakāraṇatvaṃ ca svasya jñātaikasatvena svapratyakṣājanakatveneti dhyeyam/
analyzed: parāmarśasya carama kāraṇa tvam ca svasya jñāta eka satvena sva pratyakṣa ajanaka tvena iti dhyeyam
translated: And the ultimate causality of the reflective awareness should be understood as the production of one's own perception by the mere existence of one's own knowledge.🔽The root ra in the form of seeing, K.G.T.R.A. Here in all cases, ka is present.

original: rādi darśanarūpa ka /ga /ṭa /rā / /atra sarvatra kā ityastiṭa / /rakaraṇa ka /ga /rā /
analyzed: ra ādi darśana rūpa kagaṭarā atra sarvatra kā
translated: There is no deficiency in the subject matter, TH.D.🔽Tat is redundant, TH.

analyzed: ttatra tatra iti adhikam tatra iti na vyavasāya tvena
translated: Tat is not TH. As a determinate perception, TH.

original: pu / nyāyadīpayutatarkatāṇḍavam tṛ /paricchedaḥ 🔽saṃśayānantarapratyakṣasthale viśakalitayorvyāptipakṣadharmatā jñānayoḥ satvepi liṅgaparāmarśābhāvāt/
analyzed: saṃśaya anantara pratyakṣa sthale viśakalitayoḥ vyāpti pakṣa dharma tā jñānayoḥ satve pi liṅga parāmarśa abhāvāt
translated: The Nyāyadyuti along with the Tarkatāṇḍava, Third Chapter🔽Even in the case of perception immediately following doubt, although the pervasion and the property of the subject are present in an uncombined form, there is no reflective awareness of the reason.

analyzed: sākṣātkaromi iti anuvyavasāyena samāna viṣaye phalava balena pratyakṣa sāmagryāḥ prābalya kalpanāt ca
translated: And because the causal efficiency of the perception is assumed to be stronger by the after-knowledge I am directly perceiving having the same object.

analyzed: nanu tathātve syāt
translated: If it were so, then even when there is inference in that case, there would be no inference.

analyzed: anumitsayā api hi pakṣa tā eva saṃpādyā
translated: For, in that case also, the subject itself has to be accomplished by the desire to infer.

analyzed: na tu anumitiḥ iti
translated: But not the inference.

analyzed: anuvyavasāyena parāmarśa nāśena anumiti kāraṇa abhāvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that there is no cause for inference due to the destruction of the reflective awareness by the subsequent cognition.

analyzed: viśakalitayoḥ iti
translated: The two unseparated things.
The hand etc. is pervaded by manhood.

original: ayaṃ ca karādimānityeva tatra dhīrnatu puruṣatvavyāpyakarādimānayamitita dhīrityanumitisāmagryabhāvādeva nānumitirna tu pakṣatāvirahāditi bhāvaḥ/
analyzed: ayam ca kara ādimān iti eva tatra dhīḥ na tu puruṣa tva vyāpya kara ādimān ayam dhīḥ iti anumiti sāmagrī abhāvāt eva na anumitiḥ na tu pakṣatā virahāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the idea there is only This person has a hand etc., not This person has a hand etc. which is pervaded by manhood. So, it is only due to the absence of the assemblage of causes for inference that there is no inference, not due to the absence of the pakshata relation.

original: tatrāpyastu parāmarśa iti vādinaṃ pratyāha sākṣāditi//
analyzed: tatra api astu parāmarśaḥ iti vādinam pratyāha sākṣāt iti
translated: To one who argues that even there let there be reflective awareness, it is said directly.

analyzed: samāne viṣaye iti
translated: In the same object means

analyzed: evam ca parāmarśe   janayitvā anumiti janaka tvam yuktam
translated: Thus, in reflective awareness, the capacity to produce subsequent cognition and then to produce inference is proper.

original: samāne viṣaye pratyakṣasāmagryā balavatvepi bhinne viṣaye 'numitisāmagrībalavatvasaṃbhavāditi bhāvaḥ//
analyzed: samāne viṣaye pratyakṣa sāmagryāḥ balavatve api bhinne viṣaye numiti sāmagrī balavatva saṃbhavāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Even though the assemblage of causes for perception is stronger in the same object, it is possible for the assemblage of causes for inference to be stronger in a different object. This is the idea.

analyzed: tathātve iti
translated: In that case means

analyzed: saṃśaya uttara pratyakṣa sthe pakṣatā satve pi pratyakṣa sāmagrī prābalyena pratyakṣasya eva utpāda aṅgīkāre sati iti arthaḥ
translated: when it is accepted that even though the pakshata relation exists in perception arising after doubt, perception alone arises due to the strength of the assemblage of causes for perception.

analyzed: tatra saṃśaya uttara pratyakṣa sthale 🔽anumitsā siṣādhayiṣā pade na atra abhimatā
translated: There, in the case of perception arising after doubt.🔽The desire for inference, which is the desire to know the object to be inferred, is meant by the word desire to know here.

analyzed: na tu siddhi sāmānya icchā
translated: But not the general desire for establishment.

analyzed: śravaṇa anantara bhāvinaḥ mananasya anudaya āpatteḥ iti bhāvena anumitsā pada prayogaḥ
translated: The use of the word 'desire to infer' is with the idea that reflection, which occurs after hearing, would not arise if there were no desire for establishment.

analyzed: anumitsayā apihi iti
translated: Even by the desire to infer, etc.🔽The meaning is that even by the desire to infer, the mere qualification in the form of the absence of the desire to establish accomplishes the absence of the qualified, which is caused by the absence, and thus accomplishes the subject in the form of the absence of the qualified.

analyzed: siṣādhayiṣā viraha rūpi vaśa eṣaṇasya abhāva prayukta viśiṣṭa abhāva saṃpādana dvārā viśiṣṭa abhāva rūpa pakṣatā eva saṃpādyā iti arthaḥ  tayoḥ kar śānu ṭhaḍa  pakta palaṇa bhaṅgaḥ
translated: The author of the commentary on the Nyāyabhāṣya says that the desire to establish is the cause of the desire to infer.🔽The author of the Nyāyakandalī says that the desire to establish is the cause of the desire to infer.🔽The author of the Nyāyakusumāñjali says that the desire to establish is the cause of the desire to infer.🔽The author of the Tattvacintāmaṇi says that the desire to establish is the cause of the desire to infer.

original: pakṣatāvādaḥ pu / 🔽tvayāca pakṣatāyāṃ satyāmapi pratyakṣasāmagrībalavatīti kalpanāditi cenna/
analyzed: pakṣatā vādaḥ  tvayā ca pakṣa tāyām satyām api pratyakṣa sāmagrī balavatī iti kalpanāt iti ced na
translated: The author of the Nyāyaratnākara says that the desire to establish is the cause of the desire to infer.🔽The author of the Nyāyakusumāñjalivṛtti says that the desire to establish is the cause of the desire to infer.🔽The author of the Nyāyakusumāñjalivyākhyā says that the desire to establish is the cause of the desire to infer.🔽The author of the Nyāyakusumāñjalipuṣpāvalī says that the desire to establish is the cause of the desire to infer.

original: ubhayatra pakṣatāyāṃ satyāmapi phalabalenānumitsā prabalapratyakṣasāmagrīrūpapratibandhakavirodhyuttambhikā/🔽tathā cānumitsāyāḥ pakṣatāsaṃpādakatvābhāvepi pratibandhakapratyakṣasāmagryāmuttejakatvāt/ tvayāpi hi
analyzed: ubhayatra pakṣatāyām satyām api phala balena anumitsā prabala pratyakṣa sāmagrī rūpa pratibandhaka virodhi uttambhikā  tathā ca anumitsāyāḥ pakṣatā saṃpādaka tva abhāve pi pratibandhaka pratyakṣa sāmagryām uttejaka tvāt tvayā api hi
translated: The author of the Nyāyakusumāñjalipuṣpāvalīvṛtti says that the desire to establish is the cause of the desire to infer.🔽The author of the Nyāyakusumāñjalipuṣpāvalīṭīkā says that the desire to establish is the cause of the desire to infer.🔽The author of the Nyāyakusumāñjalipuṣpāvalīṭīkāṭippaṇī says that the desire to establish is the cause of the desire to infer.

analyzed: siddhi rūpa pratibandhaka virodhi uttambhaka tvena eva siṣādhayiṣā pakṣatāyām praveśitā
translated: The author of the Nyāyakusumāñjalipuṣpāvalīṭīkāṭippaṇīṭīkā says that the desire to establish is the cause of the desire to infer.🔽The author of the Nyā

original: tvayā ceti// saṃśayottarapratyakṣasthale pakṣatāstīti vādinā cetyarthaḥ/
analyzed: tvayā ca iti saṃśaya uttara pratyakṣa sthale pakṣatā asti iti vādinā ca iti arthaḥ
translated: And by you - the meaning is that in the case of perception arising from doubt, there is pakṣatā (the property of being the subject of inference) according to the proponent.

analyzed: ubhayatra iti
translated: In both cases -

analyzed: dhūma anumāne saṃśaya uttara pratyakṣa sthale ca iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is in the case of inference of smoke and in the case of perception arising from doubt.

analyzed: phala iti
translated: By the effect -

analyzed: anuminomi iti anubhava siddha anumiti rūpa phala balena iti arthaḥ  anumitsā virodhi uttimbhikā iti anvayaḥ
translated: the meaning is by the power of the effect in the form of inference, which is established by the experience I infer.🔽The connection is that it is the cause of the arising of that which is contradictory to the desire to infer.

analyzed: anumiti pratibandhakasya yat virodhi tat uttimbhikā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is the cause of the arising of that which is contradictory to that which obstructs inference.

analyzed: kalpanāt iti
translated: By imagination -

original: anumitsādaśāyāṃ anumitirna syāditi doṣo neti yejyam/
analyzed: anumitsā daśāyām anumitiḥ na syāt iti doṣaḥ na iti
translated: it should be inferred that there is no fault in the state of desire to infer that there would be no inference.

analyzed: parasya api sammatam etat iti āha tvayā api iti
translated: He says that this is accepted even by the opponent, by you also -

analyzed: yajñapatinā api iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is by Yajñapati also.

original: siṣādhayiṣāvirahasahakṛtasiddhītyādivadatā siṣādhayiṣāvirahe sita siddhiḥ pratibandhikā tasyāṃ tu satyāṃ neti kṛtvā tādṛśasiddhyādyabhāvaḥ
analyzed: siṣādhayiṣā viraha sahakṛta siddhi ityādi vadatā siṣādhayiṣā virahe sita siddhiḥ pratibandhikā tasyām tu satyām na iti kṛtvā tādṛśa siddhi ādi abhāvaḥ
translated: By saying along with the absence of the desire to prove and the presence of establishment, etc., it is implied that in the absence of the desire to prove, establishment is obstructive, but when it is present, it is not. Therefore, the absence of such establishment, etc.,

analyzed: nanu evam anumitsā viraha sahakṛta pratyakṣa sāmagryāḥ balavatvena anumiti pratibandhaka tve
translated: If in this way, the collection of conditions for perception along with the absence of the desire to infer is obstructive to inference by being stronger,

original: tādṛśasāmagryabhāvaḥ tādṛśasiddhyabhāvaśca dvayamapyanumitau kāraṇamiti vinigamakābhāvātpakṣatātvamubhayorapyastviti cenna /🔽dvavoḥ kāraṇatvāviśeṣepi lāghavātsiddhyabhāva eva pakṣatārūpapakṣapadapravṛttinimittam/
analyzed: tādṛśa sāmagrī abhāvaḥ tādṛśa siddhi abhāvaḥ ca dvayam api anumitau kāraṇam iti vinigamaka abhāvāt pakṣatā tvam ubhayoḥ api astu iti ced na  dvavoḥ kāraṇa tva aviśeṣe api lāghavāt siddhi abhāvaḥ eva pakṣatā rūpa pakṣa pada pravṛtti nimittam
translated: The absence of such a collection and the absence of such establishment are both causes in inference. Since there is no reason to distinguish between them, let both have the nature of pakṣatā. If this is said, it is not so.🔽Even though there is no difference in the causal nature of the two, due to simplicity, the absence of establishment alone is the cause of the word pakṣa in the form of pakṣatā.

original: tyuktamiti cenna ga /ṭa /rā / /tathācānumitsāviraha sahakṛtapratyakṣasāmagrībalavatīti kalpanāt ga /ṭa /rā / /anumitsāvati tadabhāvavati cetyarthaḥ
analyzed: ti uktam iti ced na gaṭarā tathā ca anumitsā viraha sahakṛta pratyakṣa sāmagrī balavatī iti kalpanāt gaṭarā anumitsāvati tad abhāvavati ca iti arthaḥ
translated: If this is said, it is not so. The collection of direct perception along with the absence of desire to know is powerful. Because of the assumption of this, the absence of desire to know is the cause of the word pakṣa in the form of pakṣatā. The meaning is: in one who has desire to know and in one who does not have it.

analyzed: iti adhikam
translated: This is excessive.
The Nyāyadyuti along with the Tarkatāṇḍava, Third Chapter

original: tasmātsiṣādhayiṣāvirahasahakṛtasiddhyabhāvo yatra sa pakṣa iti cet maivam//
analyzed: tasmāt siṣādhayiṣā viraha sahakṛta siddhi abhāvaḥ yatra sa pakṣaḥ iti ced mā evam
translated: Therefore, if this is said: Where there is absence of establishment along with absence of desire to prove, that is the subject, this is not so.

original: satyāṃ siddhau asatyāmapi siṣādhayiṣāyāmanumitidarśanāt/🔽dṛśyate hyasaṃdihānasyāpi āptavākyādvahniṃ
analyzed: satyām siddhau asatyām api siṣādhayiṣāyām anumiti darśanāt  dṛśyate hi asaṃdihānasya api āpta vākyāt vahnim
translated: Because even when there is establishment, even when there is absence of desire to prove, inference is seen.

original: niścitavatopi giriśikhare abhraṃlihāṃ dhūmarekhāṃ paśyato daivāvdyāptismaraṇe sati ananumitsoranumitiḥ/
analyzed: niścitavataḥ api giri śikhare abhraṃlihām dhūma rekhām paśyataḥ daiva avdyāpti smaraṇe sati ananumitsoḥ anumitiḥ
translated: For one who is not doubting, even one who has ascertained fire from the words of a reliable person, even one who sees the line of smoke touching the peak of a mountain peak, when the recollection of pervasion by chance occurs, inference occurs in one who does not desire to know.

analyzed: na hi sāmagrī prekṣāvatī
translated: For a collection is not intelligent.

analyzed: yena mayā kartavyam anyena kṛtam iti paryālocya udāsīta
translated: By which, having considered that what was to be done by me has been done by another, it would remain neutral.

analyzed: anubhava anusāreṇa hi lakṣaṇam kalpyam
translated: For the definition is to be conceived in accordance with experience.

analyzed: na tu sva kalpita lakṣaṇa rakṣaṇa artham anubhava pīḍā
translated: But not the affliction of experience for the sake of preserving the conceived definition.

original: asti cātra na kevalaṃ vahniḥ śrutaḥ kiṃ tvanumitopītyanubhavaḥ/
analyzed: asti ca atra na kevalam vahniḥ śrutaḥ kim tu anumitaḥ api iti anubhavaḥ
translated: And here there is not only the heard fire, but also the inferred fire, thus there is experience.

analyzed: na tu adhikam
translated: But not more.

analyzed: gauravāt
translated: Because of heaviness.

analyzed: kiñca anya anya tva avacchinnāḥ bhāva tvena na janaka tvam
translated: Moreover, in the case of a gem etc., the absence of otherness is not the cause of the nature of being produced.

original: maṇyādisthalepi mantrānyānyābhāvatvenāpi hetutāpatyā pratibandhakābhāvakūṭaḥ kāraṇamiti siddhāntabhaṅgāpatteḥ/
analyzed: maṇi ādi sthale api mantra anya anya abhāva tvena api hetu tā āpatyā pratibandhaka abhāva kūṭaḥ kāraṇam iti siddhānta bhaṅga āpatteḥ
translated: Because of the possibility of being the cause even by the absence of the obstruction of the collection of the absence of the obstruction, there is the consequence of the fall of the conclusion.

analyzed: tṛṇa ādi anya anyatvena api hetu tā āpatyā kārya vaijātya asiddhi prasaṅgāt ityādi abhiprāyeṇa atra matam ityādi śaṅkitā sva matam upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: And because of the possibility of being the cause even by the absence of otherness of grass etc., there is the consequence of the non-establishment of the difference of the effect. Thus, with the intention of expressing this, he raises the doubt with the words this view etc., and concludes his own view with therefore.

analyzed: idam api lakṣaṇam avyāptiḥ iti bhāvena
translated: This definition is also incomplete, thinking thus,

analyzed: asiddha sādhane doṣaḥ kaḥ vyāptiḥ yadi vidyate
translated: What is the fault in proving the unestablished if there is pervasion?

analyzed: iti bhaktipādīya anuvyākhyāna sudhā uktam hṛdi kṛtvā nirāha satyām ityādinā
translated: Having thus placed in the heart what is said in the Anuvyaख्यानसुधा of भक्तिपाद, he refutes with satyāmityādi.

analyzed: tatra viśeṣaṇa viśeṣyayoḥ dvayoḥ api satvena anyatara abhāva prayuktasya ubhaya abhāva nimittakasya vā viśiṣṭa abhāvasya abhāvāt vayāptiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: There, the idea is that the absence of the qualified is not due to the absence of either, or to the absence of both, since both the qualifier and the qualified exist.

original: na ca / pakṣataiva neti vācyam anumitirūpaphaladarśanena tatra pakṣatāyā āvaśyakatvādityāha dṛśyate hīti//
analyzed: na ca pakṣatā eva na iti vācyam anumiti rūpa phala darśanena tatra pakṣatāyāḥ āvaśyaka tvāt iti āha dṛśyate hi iti
translated: And it should not be said that it is not even a subject, because the necessity of the subject there is due to the perception of the result in the form of inference, he says dṛśyate hi.

original: anubhava eva nāstītyata āha asti ceti//
analyzed: anubhavaḥ eva na asti iti atas āha asti ca iti
translated: He says asti cet that there is no experience itself.

analyzed: eva iti adhikam ṭarā tatra iti adhikam ṭaḍa tat iti adhikam
translated: Eva is redundant. Tat is redundant. Tat is redundant.

analyzed: pakta palaṇa bhaṅgaḥ
translated: The Refutation of the Pakṣapala's View

analyzed: pakṣatā vādaḥ
translated: The Theory of Paksatā

original: atrānumitsākalpane ca ghaṭanagarjitena medhānumānepi sā kalpyatām/
analyzed: atrā anumitsā kalpane ca ghaṭana garjitena medhā anumāne api sā kalpyatām
translated: And if desire for inference is imagined in this case, let it be imagined in the inference of intelligence from the roaring of clouds.

analyzed: yogya anupalabdhi bādhaḥ ca ubhayatra apisamaḥ
translated: And the objection that there is no apprehension of the possible is the same in both cases.

original: na ca chinne chidāntaramiva paricchine piracchedāntaramaśakyam/
analyzed: na ca chinne chidā antaram iva paricchine pira cheda antaram aśakyam
translated: And just as a second cutting is impossible when one is cut, so a second determination is impossible when one is determined.

analyzed: caitreṇa jñāti ṛthe maitrasya
translated: When an object is known by Caitra, it is not so for Maitra.

analyzed: caitrasya eva kāla antare jñāna antarasya
translated: It is not so for Caitra himself at a later time or for another cognition.

analyzed: tadānīm api pratyakṣa siddhe śābda jñāna antarasya
translated: Even then, in what is established by perception, of verbal knowledge other than that.

analyzed: pratyakṣa dhārā vāhi jñāna antarasya
translated: Of the knowledge other than the continuous perception.

analyzed: śabda liṅgābhyām niścite api arthe sāmagrī vaśāt śābda laiṅgika jñāna antarasya darśanāt
translated: Even when the meaning is ascertained by words and inferential marks, due to the assemblage of conditions, of verbal and inferential knowledge other than that, because it is seen.

original: nanu tatra phalabalenānumitsaiva kalpyatāṃ evaṃ cānumitsāviraharūpaviśeṣaṇābhāvaprayuktaviśiṣṭābhāvarūpapakṣatāsatvānnadoṣa ityata āha atreti//
analyzed: nanu tatra phala balena anumitsā eva kalpyatām evam ca anumitsā viraha rūpa viśeṣaṇa abhāva prayukta viśiṣṭa abhāva rūpa pakṣatā satvāt na doṣaḥ iti atas āha atra iti
translated: But there, let inference itself be imagined by the power of the result. And thus, due to the absence of the qualified absence in the form of the absence of desire to infer, there is no fault due to the existence of the subject in the form of the qualified absence caused by the absence of the qualifier. To this he says 'here'.

analyzed: ghana garjitena iti
translated: 'By the deep thunder'.

original: evaṃ ca tatra viśeṣaṇasatvamupetya sādhakamānarūpaviśeṣyābhāvaprayuktaviśiṣṭābhāvoktyā pakṣatvopapādanamasaṅgataṃ syāditi bhāvaḥ/
analyzed: evam ca tatra viśeṣaṇa satvam upetya sādhaka māna rūpa viśeṣya abhāva prayukta viśiṣṭa abhāva uktyā pakṣa tva upapādanam asaṅga tam syāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, accepting the existence of the qualifier there, the explanation of the qualified absence caused by the absence of the qualified object in the form of the valid means of knowledge would be irrelevant as establishing the subject. This is the idea.

analyzed: tatra anumitsā yogya ananubhava bādhitā iti atas āha
translated: There, desire to infer is contradicted by the non-apprehension of the possible. To this he says 'possible'.

analyzed: icchāyāḥ yogya tvāt tad anupalabdheḥ yogya anupalabdhi tvāt yogyā anupalabdhi iti uktam kim
translated: Because desire is possible, its non-apprehension is the non-apprehension of the possible. Therefore, it is said to be the non-apprehension of the possible. What is the point?

original: paricchedāntaraṃ kasyāpi nāstīti atha paricchettureva neti asminpakṣepi kālāntare
analyzed: pariccheda antaram kasya api na asti iti atha paricchettuḥ eva na iti asmin pakṣe pi kāla antare
translated: Is it that no one has any other determination? Or is it that the determiner himself does not have it? Even in this view, at a later time,

original: nāstyuta tadā tadetyatrāpi pramāṇāntareṇa nāsti uta pūrvaparicchedajanakapramāṇena
analyzed: na asti uta tadā tadā iti atra api pramāṇa antareṇa na asti uta pūrva pariccheda janaka pramāṇena
translated: There is no such thing as then that, even here, it is not by another means of knowledge, but by the means of knowledge that generates the previous determination.

original: śabdaliṅgābhyāṃ paricchinne punastābhyāmeva paricchedāntare neti kalpānkrameṇa nirāha
analyzed: śabda liṅgābhyām paricchinne punar tābhyām eva pariccheda antare na iti kalpān krameṇa nirāha
translated: Having determined by word and inference, it is not again by those two that there is another determination. He refutes the alternatives in order.

analyzed: caitreṇa jñātaḥ iti
translated: It is known by Caitra.

original: dhastū bhaṭa /ga / /ghaṭapadaṃ na ṭha /ṭa / /evaṃ ca iti na ṭa / tatretyapi na ḍaḥ / /ropi na ḍa /
analyzed: ghaṭa padam na evam ca iti na tatra iti api na na na
translated: But the word ghaṭa is not ṭha. Thus, the word ca is not ṭa. Even the word tatra is not ḍa. The word api is also not ḍa.
Nyāyavārtika-tārkatipāyī, third chapter

original: kiñca maṇimantrādivatsiddheḥ pratibandhakatve siddhe viśiṣṭābhāvasya kāraṇatvaṃ siddhyet/
analyzed: kiñca maṇi mantra ādi vat siddheḥ pratibandhaka tve siddhe viśiṣṭa abhāvasya kāraṇa tvam siddhyet
translated: Moreover, if the establishment is a hindrance like a gem or a mantra, the causal nature of the qualified absence would be established.

analyzed: na ca tat asti
translated: But that is not so.

analyzed: siddheḥ bādha vat sākṣāt virodhi viṣayatva abhāvāt
translated: Because establishment, like contradiction, does not have the nature of being directly opposed to its object.
Because, like the knowledge of deviation, it does not have the nature of obstructing the cause.

analyzed: maṇi ādi vat anvaya vyatirekayoḥ api abhāvāt
translated: And because, like a gem, etc., there is no positive or negative concomitance.

original: api ca yadi virodhyaviṣayiṇyapi siddhiḥ siṣādhayiṣāvirahasahakārisaṃpatyā samānaviṣayā numitipratibandhikā
analyzed: api ca yadi virodhya viṣayiṇī api siddhiḥ siṣādhayiṣā viraha sahakāri saṃpatyā samāna viṣayā numiti pratibandhikā
translated: Moreover, if establishment, even though not having a contradictory object, is an obstruction to the inference having the same object due to the concurrence of the absence of the desire to establish,

analyzed: tarhi liṅga jñānam api upādhi jñāna sahakṛtam sākṣāt evam liṅga parāmarśa pratabandhakam syāt
translated: Then, the knowledge of the inferential mark, aided by the knowledge of the superimposition, would directly be the impediment to the manifestation of the inferential mark.

analyzed: na tu vyabhicāra dhī dvārā
translated: But not through the knowledge of the fallacy.

original: na ca siddheravirodhitve 'numitidhārā na vicchidyeneti vācyam/
analyzed: na ca siddheḥ avirodhi tve numiti dhārā na vicchidyena iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that if the superimposition is not contradictory, the stream of inference would not be interrupted.

analyzed: nanu ukta sthale sarvatra phala balāt pratibandhakībhūta siddheḥ uttejakam kiñcid parikalpanīyam
translated: In all the cases mentioned, something that stimulates the superimposition, which is the impediment, must be imagined due to the force of the result.

original: anyathā pratibandhake sati kāryodayasya durghaṭatvādityata āha kiṃ ceti//
analyzed: anyathā pratibandhake sati kārya udayasya durghaṭa tvāt iti atas āha kim ca iti
translated: Otherwise, it would be difficult to account for the arising of the effect when there is an impediment. To this, he says Moreover, etc.

original: pratibandhakatvaṃ siddheḥ kiṃ grāhyābhāvāvagāhitvenota siddhyantara vighaṭakatvenānvayavyatirekābhyāṃ vā na trayamapīti krameṇa nirāha
analyzed: pratibandhaka tvam siddheḥ kim grāhya abhāva avagāhi tvena uta siddhi antara vighaṭaka tvena anvaya vyatirekābhyām vā na trayam api iti krameṇa nirāha
translated: As for the superimposition being the impediment, it cannot be due to apprehending the absence of the object to be known, nor can it be due to obstructing another superimposition, nor can it be due to positive and negative concomitance. All three are rejected in order.

original: siddheḥ pratibandhakatve sādhakaṃ netyuktvā bādhakamapyāha api ceti//
analyzed: siddheḥ pratibandhaka tve sādhakam na iti uktvā bādhakam api āha api ca iti
translated: Having said that there is no proof for the superimposition being the impediment, he states the contradiction with Moreover, etc.

analyzed: liṅga jñānam iti
translated: The knowledge of the inferential mark means

analyzed: mahānasa ādau gṛhīta vyāptikasya parvate yat liṅga darśanam tat iti arthaḥ
translated: the seeing of the inferential mark on the mountain by one who has grasped the pervasion in the kitchen, etc.

original: siddherapratibandhakatve 'numityavicchedo vā siddhasādhanatvasyādoṣatvaṃ vā syādityata ādyaṃ bādhakaṃ tāvadāśaṅkya nirāha na ceti//
analyzed: siddheḥ apratibandhaka tve numiti avicchedaḥ vā siddhasādhanatvasya adoṣatvam vā syāt iti atas ādyam bādhakam tāvat āśaṅkya nirāha na ca iti
translated: If the establishment of the object is not a hindrance, there would be an uninterrupted series of inferences or the establishment of what is already established would not be a fault. Thus, first, the objection is raised and refuted as follows: It is not so, etc.

original: śābdabodhakasthale siddherapratibandhakatvena tatrāpi śābdabodhaparaṃparāpatteḥ/ 🔽yakānuka /ṭa / yatvānuga /rā / /kāraṇetyadhikamṭha / /na kenāpītiṭhar / /bādhakatvesā ṭha / 🔽paktapalaṇabhaṅgaḥ
analyzed: śābda bodhaka sthale siddheḥ apratibandhaka tvena tatra api śābdabodha paraṃparā āpatteḥ  kāraṇā iti adhikam ṭha na kena api iti ṭhar  pakta palaṇa bhaṅgaḥ
translated: Because in the case of the producer of verbal cognition, the establishment is not a hindrance, so there would be a series of verbal cognition there also.

analyzed: pakṣatā vādaḥ
translated: The word also is redundant.🔽There is no objection by anyone.🔽The refutation of the objection regarding the establishment of the object.🔽The theory of paksha (subject).🔽Because the cognition of the inferential mark remains for as long as the verbal cognition, there is no cause for the series of inferences.
Because the view that the cognition of the object qualified by the inferential mark is the object of cognition is refuted.

original: na ca liṅgaparāmarśasya sthitikṣaṇe caikā tannāsakṣaṇe cānyetyanumitidvayaṃ niyameva syāt taddhetoḥ satvāditi vācyam/
analyzed: na ca liṅga parāmarśasya sthiti kṣaṇe ca ekā tad nāsā kṣaṇe ca anyā iti anumiti dvayam niyama eva syāt tad hetoḥ satvāt iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that at the moment of the persistence of the cognition of the inferential mark, there would necessarily be two inferences, one at the moment of its cessation, because the cause of that exists.

analyzed: kvacid utkaṭa viṣaya antara jijñāsayā pratibandha saṃbhavena
translated: Because in some cases, there may be an obstruction by the desire to know about a very strong external object, and there is no cause for the rule.

analyzed: kadācid anumiti dvaya āpādane ca hetu satvena iṣṭa āpatteḥ
translated: And if the presence of the reason entails the occurrence of two inferences, then the desired conclusion follows.

original: kathaṃ hi vijñātaṃ bhavatā kadāpyanumitidvayaṃ nāstīti/
analyzed: katham hi vijñātam bhavatā kadāpi anumiti dvayam na asti iti
translated: For how do you know that two inferences never occur?

analyzed: anuminomi iti anuvyavasāyasya dvitīya abhāva aviṣayaka tvāt
translated: Because the cognition 'I infer' is not about the absence of a second [inference].

original: kāraṇībhūtasya śābdagocarajñānasya vināśena kāraṇābhāvānna śābdabodhaparaṃpareti cetsamamihāpītyāha liṅgaparāmarśasyeti//
analyzed: kāraṇībhūtasya śābda gocara jñānasya vināśena kāraṇa abhāvāt na śābda bodha paraṃparā iti ced samam iha api iti āha liṅga parāmarśasya iti
translated: If it is argued that the succession of verbal cognition is due to the destruction of the cognition that is the cause of the verbal cognition, then the same applies here as well. He says 'the inferential cognition' etc.

analyzed: jñānavat jñānasya iva
translated: Like cognition, of cognition.

analyzed: ātma lābha rūpa janma kṣaṇam api upādāya vā vināśa kṣaṇam api upādāya vā dvi kṣaṇa iti uktam
translated: Or taking the moment of birth which is of the nature of self-acquisition, or taking the moment of destruction, it is said to be two moments.

analyzed: nanu dhūmavat parvataḥ gnimān iti anumiti ākāra upagamena anumatitiḥ api parāmarśa rūpā iti atas āha liṅga iti
translated: If it is argued that the form of inference is accepted as 'the mountain with smoke is fiery', then the cognition 'I infer' is also of the form of inferential cognition, he says 'the inferential mark' etc.

analyzed: svatastva anumāna vāde nirāsāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it has been refuted in the doctrine of the self-validity of inference.

analyzed: anuminomi iti anuvyavasāyaḥ eva anumiti dvaya abhāve mānam iti atas āha anuminomi iti
translated: The cognition 'I infer' itself is the valid cognition of the non-existence of two inferences. Therefore he says 'I infer' etc.

analyzed: dvitīyam bādhakam nirāha siddha sādhanam tu iti
translated: He refutes the second objection by saying 'but the proof of what is already established' etc.

analyzed: prāmāṇya svatastve anumāna ukti prastāve
translated: It has been refuted in the context of the statement of inference in the doctrine of the self-validity of pramāṇas.
The Nyāyadyuti-yuta-tarkatāṇḍava🔽The third chapter

original: siddhasādhanaṃ tu parārthānumāna eva doṣo na svārthānumāne iti vakṣyate//
analyzed: siddhasādhanam tu parārtha anumāne eva doṣaḥ na svārtha anumāne iti vakṣyate
translated: The fallacy of siddhasādhana (proving what is already established) is a fault only in the case of inference for others, not in inference for oneself, as will be stated.

analyzed: tasmāt pa kṣatā durnirūpā iti
translated: Therefore, the subject is difficult to determine.

analyzed: iti para ukta pakṣa lakṣaṇa bhaṅgaḥ
translated: Thus ends the refutation of the definition of the subject stated by others.

analyzed: vakṣyate iti
translated: Will be stated

analyzed: sva mate numāna doṣa ukti vāde
translated: In the statement of the faults of inference in one's own view.

original: etena siddhyabhāvasya pakṣatātvakhaṇḍanenaiva siṣādhayiṣāvirahasahakṛtasādhyaniścayābhāvaḥ pakṣateti śiromaṇipakṣopi pratyukto dhyeyaḥ/🔽pūrvoktadoṣāṇāmatrāpyanuvṛtteḥ uktadoṣānsaṃkṣepeṇānuvadanpūrvapakṣamupasaṃharati tasmāditi//
analyzed: etena siddhi abhāvasya pakṣatā tva khaṇḍanena eva siṣādhayiṣā viraha sahakṛta sādhya niścaya abhāvaḥ pakṣatā iti śiromaṇi pakṣaḥ api pratyuktaḥ dhyeyaḥ  pūrva ukta doṣāṇām atra api anuvṛtteḥ ukta doṣān saṃkṣepeṇa anuvadan pūrvapakṣam upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: By this very refutation of the truth of the absence of establishment being the nature of the subject, the view of Śrīmatī that the absence of the ascertainment of the probandum in conjunction with the absence of the desire to prove is the subject should also be considered refuted.🔽By this, by the very refutation of the truth of the absence of establishment being the nature of the subject, the view of Śrīmatī that the absence of the ascertainment of the probandum in conjunction with the absence of the desire to prove is the subject should also be considered refuted.

analyzed: iti maṇi ukta pakṣa lakṣaṇa bhaṅgaḥ
translated: Thus ends the refutation of the definition of the subject stated in the Nyāya-mañjarī.

analyzed: atha sva mate pakṣa lakṣaṇam
translated: Now, the definition of the subject in one's own view.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

original: liṅgābhimatas yatra yadā yaṃ prati yadvijananānukūlasahakārisaṃpattistatra tadā taṃ prati tatsādhyam
analyzed: liṅga abhimataḥ yatra yadā yam prati yad vijanana anukūla sahakāri saṃpattiḥ tatra tadā tam prati tat sādhyam
translated: Where, when, and for whom there is the attainment of the concurrence of auxiliary factors favorable to the production of what is intended to be inferred, that is to be inferred for him at that time.

analyzed: atha sva mate pakṣa lakṣaṇam  /
translated: Now, the definition of the subject in one's own view.

analyzed: sādhya dharma viśiṣṭaḥ pakṣaḥ eti mithyātva anumāna khaṇḍane bhagavat pāda uktam pakṣa laṇam iha
translated: The definition of paksha stated by the revered teacher in the critique of the inference of falsity, as that which is qualified by the probandum is the paksha,

original: vivakṣuḥliṅgena yatpratītirjanayitavyā sa sādhyadharmaiti ṭīkoktaṃ pariṣkṛrvansādhyasvarūpaṃ
analyzed: vivakṣuḥ liṅgena yad pratītiḥ janayitavyā sa sādhya dharmaḥ iti ṭīkā uktam pariṣkṛrvan sādhya svarūpam
translated: the author, wishing to state it here, refines the statement in the commentary that which is to be made known by the inferential mark is the probandum, and

analyzed: tāvat āha liṅka abhimatasya iti
translated: first states the nature of the probandum, saying of what is intended as the inferential mark.

original: tasmātparoktavakrapakṣalakṣaṇeṣu satyāṃ siddhau asatyāmapi siṣādhayiṣāyāṃ yā anupapattistatrāvyāptiḥ
analyzed: tasmāt para ukta vakra pakṣa lakṣaṇeṣu satyām siddhau asatyām api siṣādhayiṣāyām yā anupapattiḥ tatra avyāptiḥ
translated: Therefore, in the crooked definitions of paksha stated by others, when there is establishment, even when there is no desire to prove, there is non-pervasion in that non-coherence.

original: siddheranumitipratibandhakatve bījābhāvaḥ liṅgajñānasyāpi liṅgaparāmarśapratibandhakatvāpātaḥ iti doṣatrayam /
analyzed: siddheḥ anumiti pratibandhaka tve bīja abhāvaḥ liṅga jñānasya api liṅga parāmarśa pratibandhaka tva āpātaḥ iti doṣa trayam
translated: If establishment were an obstruction to inference, there would be the absence of a cause, and the consequence would be that the knowledge of the inferential mark would also obstruct the reflection on the inferential mark - thus there are three faults.

analyzed: iti adhikam ga ṭa rā t para ukta pakṣa tā ṭa
translated: Thus it is excessive. The definition of paksha stated by others is excessive.

analyzed: sva tepa laṇam
translated: The definition of paksha by the author himself

analyzed: pakṣatā vādaḥ
translated: The doctrine of paksha

original: tādṛśasādhyaviśiṣṭasya tadā taṃ prati tasyānumitau pakṣaḥ//
analyzed: tādṛśa sādhya viśiṣṭasya tadā tam prati tasya anumitau pakṣaḥ
translated: At that time, for him, that which is qualified by such a probandum is the paksha in that inference.

original: na ca pakṣatāyā apyanumitihetutvena sahakārirūpāyāḥ kathaṃ sahakārisaṃpattirūpateti vācyam/
analyzed: na ca pakṣatāyāḥ api anumiti hetu tvena sahakāri rūpāyāḥ katham sahakāri saṃpatti rūpa tā iti vācyam
translated: And let it not be said that since paksha-hood is also a cause of inference, how can it be the fulfillment of a cooperating factor?

analyzed: parvataḥ agnimān pra meya tvāt iti vyabhicāri prayogāt āvyāpti nirāsāya liṅga abhimatā iti uktam
translated: The word inferred is used to exclude over-extension in cases like The mountain has fire, because it is to be inferred, where there is a fallacious inference.

analyzed: vyāpya tvena abhimatasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: that which is intended to be the inferable property.

analyzed: samāna adhikaraṇa vyadhikaraṇa sarva sādhya svarūpa nirvacana artham yatra yadā ityādi uktam
translated: The phrase wherever there is... etc. is used to define the nature of the probandum, which may be co-extensive or not with the probans.

original: deśāntare kalāntare puruṣāntaraṃ prati vastvantarajñāne cānukūlasahakārisaṃpattimādāya deśāntarādau sādhyatāpattidoṣanirāsāya yattacchabdacatuṣṭayam/
analyzed: deśa antare kalā antare puruṣa antaram prati vastu antara jñāne ca anukūla sahakāri saṃpattim ādāya deśa antara ādau sādhya tā āpatti doṣa nirāsāya yat tat śabda catuṣṭayam
translated: In order to avoid the fallacy of the probandum being established in other places, times, persons, and in the knowledge of other things, by the availability of favorable cooperating factors, the four words that... etc. are used.
The availability of cooperating factors means the combination of cooperating factors.
The final meaning is: being fit to be the object of an inference produced by the probans is being the probandum.

original: etena sādhyaśabdena kiṃ saṃdigdho dharmo vivakṣitaḥ kiṃ vā prajñāpanīyaḥ yadvā pramitsitaḥ /
analyzed: etena sādhya śabdena kim saṃdigdhaḥ dharmaḥ vivakṣitaḥ kim vā prajñāpanīyaḥ yat vā pramitsitaḥ
translated: By this, what is meant by the word probandum? Is it a doubtful property, or one to be made known, or one to be known?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ satyām siddhau ityādi pūrva bhaṅga ukta granthe niścitasya api sādhya tva ukti virodhāt
translated: Not the first, because it would contradict the statement in the previous section that even a certain property is to be proved.

analyzed: pramāṇa saṃplava vādinām niścite pi anumāna pravṛttiḥ aṅgīkārāt ca
translated: And because those who advocate the combination of means of knowledge accept the operation of inference even in what is certain.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: svārtha anumāne prayojya kartuḥ abhāvena prajñāpana abhāvāt
translated: In self-directed inference, there is no statement due to the absence of an employed agent.

analyzed: na tṛtīyaḥ
translated: The third is not so.

analyzed: aniṣṭa anumāna abhāva prasaṅgāt ityādi upaplavaḥ poḍhaḥ
translated: Because of the undesirable consequence of the absence of inference, the initial objection is removed.
Because the property that is the object of cognition produced by the inferential mark is intended by the term 'property to be proved'.

analyzed: tasya kāla antara ādikam ādāya atiprasaṅga nivṛti arthaḥ yatra yadā iti evam nirukta tvāt
translated: In order to prevent over-extension by taking time, etc., it is stated as 'wherever' and so on, because it is defined thus.

original: evaṃ ca parvataniṣṭhadhūmena parvatīyavahnyanumityutpādanadaśāyāṃ vahneḥ sādhyatvaṃ
analyzed: evam ca parvata niṣṭha dhūmena parvatīya vahni anumiti utpādana daśāyām vahneḥ sādhya tvam
translated: And thus, in the stage of producing the inference of the fire belonging to the mountain by the smoke belonging to the mountain, the fire is to be proved.

analyzed: nadīpūreṇa ūrdhva deśa vṛṣṭi anumiti utpāda velāyām vṛṣṭeḥ sādhya tvam kṛttikā udayena rohiṇī udaya asat anumati kāle
translated: In the stage of producing the inference of the rain in the upper region by the flood in the river, the rain is to be proved. In the stage of inferring the absence of the rising of Rohini by the rising of Krittika,
the absence of the rising of Rohini is to be proved. Thus, etc., should be thought of.

original: astu sādhyamevaṃ rūpaṃ tataḥ kimityata āha tādṛśeti//
analyzed: astu sādhyam evam rūpam tatas kim iti atas āha tādṛśa iti
translated: Let the property to be proved be of such a form, then what follows from that? To this he says 'such' and so on.

analyzed: ukta rūpa iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is 'of the stated form'.

analyzed: tam prati puruṣam prati
translated: To that person.

analyzed: tasya iti
translated: 'Of that' means

analyzed: vahni ādi vastunaḥ 🔽sādhya dharmasya iti adhikam ṭha
translated: of the thing like fire, etc.🔽'Of the property to be proved' is additional.
The Nyāyadyuti-yuta-tarkatāṇḍava🔽The third chapter

analyzed: mamat mate pakṣatāyāḥ anumiti sahakāri saṃpatti rūpa tvena a numiti ahetu tvāt
translated: In my view, pakṣatā is not the cause of inference, because it is a condition for inference, in the form of a favorable state of the means of knowledge.

analyzed: tvad mate pi hi pakṣatā hetuḥ
translated: Even in your view, pakṣatā is the cause as the absence of an obstruction in the form of establishment.

analyzed: siddheḥ ca na siddhiḥ pratibandhikā
translated: And establishment is not an obstruction to establishment.

analyzed: kintu anukūlā eva iti uktam
translated: But it is only favorable, as stated.

original: nanvevaṃ sati liṅgaparāmarśadaśāyāmeva pakṣatā na tu tataḥ prāk/
analyzed: nanu evam sati liṅga parāmarśa daśāyām eva pakṣatā na tu tatas prāk
translated: If that is so, then pakṣatā exists only at the stage of the inferential cognition, not before it.

analyzed: tatas ca liṅga parāmarśaḥ katham pakṣa dharmatā viṣayakaḥ
translated: And then how can the inferential cognition be about the property of the subject?

analyzed: syāt iti ced
translated: If this is argued,

original: atrāpi kālāntare puruṣāntaraṃ prati vastvantarānumitau vastvantaraviśiṣṭasya pakṣatāvyudāsāya tadā taṃ prati tasyetyuktiḥ//🔽nanu sādhyadharmaliṣiśiṣṭatvaṃ sādhyadharmasaṃbandhitvam/
analyzed: atra api kāla antare puruṣa antaram prati vastu antara anumitau vastu antara viśiṣṭasya pakṣatā vyudāsāya tadā tam prati tasya iti uktiḥ  nanu sādhya dharma liṣi śiṣṭa tvam sādhya dharma saṃbandhi tvam
translated: then even here, in order to exclude the pakṣatā qualified by another object when inferring another object at another time or for another person, it is said then for him at that time.🔽If it is argued that being qualified by the property to be established is being related to the property to be established,

analyzed: tat ca vyāpya tayā sādhanasya api asti iti tatra ativyāptiḥ iti ced na
translated: and that exists for the reason also as the pervaded, so there is over-extension there, it is not so.

analyzed: dharma dharmi bhāvena vaiśiṣṭyasya vivakṣita tvāt
translated: Because the qualification by the relation of property and possessor is intended.

analyzed: sādhya padam sapakṣa ādau ativyāpti nirāsāya
translated: The word 'to be established' is used to rule out over-extension in similar instances.

original: sādhyaviśiṣṭaḥ pakṣa ityevokte vastutogniviśiṣṭaparvatasyāpi sādhyatvāttadviśiṣṭānyasya pakṣatvaṃ syāt/
analyzed: sādhya viśiṣṭaḥ pakṣaḥ iti eva ukte vastutas agni viśiṣṭa parvatasya api sādhya tvāt tad viśiṣṭa anyasya pakṣa tvam syāt
translated: If it is said that the subject is that which is qualified by the probandum, then even the mountain qualified by fire would be the subject, because it is the probandum.

analyzed: tad artham dharma grahaṇam
translated: For that purpose, the word 'property' is used.

original: na ca vahnireva sādhyo na parvata iti vācyam/
analyzed: na ca vahniḥ eva sādhyaḥ na parvataḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that only fire is the probandum, not the mountain.

original: vahnisvarūpamātrasya prāgeva siddhatvāt/🔽parvatasaṃbandhitvenāsiddhatvāttadrūpeṇa vahniḥ sādhyate iti cettarhi yathā parvata
