translated: Only those, i.e.,

analyzed: sādhāraṇā sādhāraṇa dharma sādhya samāna adhikaraṇa dharmāṇām eva iti arthaḥ
translated: only those properties that are common and are co-extensive with the property to be proved.

analyzed: sādhāraṇa tva ādi jñānam iti
translated: The knowledge of commonness, etc.,

original: anyathā parvato 'gnimān pakṣatvādityādau prameyatveneva vṛkṣatvarūpeṇa vā jāte 'pi jñāne sādhyasaṃśayāpatteriti bhāvaḥ/
analyzed: anyathā parvataḥ gnimān pakṣa tvāt ityādau prameya tvena iva vṛkṣa tva rūpeṇa vā jāte pi jñāne sādhya saṃśaya āpatteḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that otherwise, in cases like The mountain has fire because it is a subject, even if there is knowledge in the form of a universal like being an object or being a tree, there would be doubt about the probandum.

analyzed: sādhāraṇa iti
translated: Commonness, etc.,

original: sādhāraṇasyāvyāptyantarbhāprastāva ityarthaḥ// 🔽tupa ka / /sapakṣavipakṣetyārabhya etāvān granthaḥ nāstiga /rā / /ṇadharmasā ṭa /ṭha / /vṛkṣavatvādi ṭa /ḍa /
analyzed: sādhāraṇasya avyāpti antar bhā prastāvaḥ iti arthaḥ  tupa ka sapakṣa vipakṣa iti ārabhya etāvān granthaḥ vṛkṣavat tva ādi ṭaḍa
translated: The meaning is that the common property is not included in over-extension.🔽The text beginning with similar instances and dissimilar instances up to this point is missing.
The Nyāyadyuti along with the Tarkatāṇḍava, Third Chapter

analyzed: kim ca evam sati vyāptasya pakṣa dharma tva apramiti rūpa asiddhiḥ api āśraya hetu svarūpa tad viśeṣaṇa asatva jñāna nibandhanā iti āśraya asatva ādīnām api hetvābhāsa antara tvam
translated: Moreover, in that case, the non-establishment in the form of the non-cognition of the property of the subject of the pervasion would also be based on the knowledge of the non-existence of the substratum, the reason, the nature, and the specific properties, so the non-existence of the substratum and others would also be another fallacy of the reason.

original: nanucābhāvajñānādbhāpramāvyatirekaḥ sarvatranaitāvatāsādhāraṇa tvaṃ sidhyati yacceha nirūpyata iti cenna/
analyzed: nanu ca abhāva jñānāt bhā pramā vyatirekaḥ sarvatra na etāvatā asādhāraṇa tvam sidhyati yat ca iha nirūpyate iti ced na
translated: But it may be argued that the absence of valid cognition is present in all cases due to the knowledge of non-existence. Even by this much, the commonality is not established, as to what is being examined here. This is not so.

analyzed: vyabhicārasya api vyāpti abhāva rūpa tvena abhāva jñānāt bhāva rūpa vyāpti pramā virahaḥ iti sāmyāt
translated: Because even in the case of contradiction, since it is of the form of absence of pervasion, there is absence of the form of pervasion in the form of valid cognition due to the knowledge of non-existence. Thus, there is similarity.

analyzed: evam agre pi
translated: In the same way, it should be understood in the future also.

analyzed: upajīvya tvāt teṣām eva udbhāvanam iti atra atiprasaṅga antaram ca āha kim ca iti
translated: In this [argument], he states another absurdity in the form of What if... regarding the fact that they [the reasons] are to be stated because they are to be relied upon.

analyzed: viruddhe na aikāntika dvaye ca
translated: In the case of two contradictory inconclusive reasons,

original: pramāvyatirekāviśeṣyavāntarabhedādbhoktau yo 'tiprasaṅga uktaḥ taduddhāramāśaṅkya sāmyena nirāha nanvityādinā//
analyzed: pramā vyatireka aviśeṣya vāntarabhedāt bhoktau yaḥ tiprasaṅgaḥ uktaḥ tad uddhāram āśaṅkya sāmyena nirāha nanu ityādinā
translated: The absurdity that was stated in the case of the enjoyer due to the difference of being qualified and not qualified by the absence of valid cognition, he raises the doubt of its removal and refutes it by similarity, beginning with But...

analyzed: sarvatra iti
translated: In all cases means

analyzed: āśraya asatva svarūpa asatva hetu viśeṣaṇa asatva ādi jñāna nibandhana asiddhiṣu sarvāsu api āśraya ādi abhāva jñānau dyāpti pakṣa dharma tā rūpa bhā pramā virahaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: In all cases of non-establishment due to the non-existence of the substratum, the non-existence of the nature of the reason, the non-existence of the qualifier, etc., there is absence of valid cognition in the form of pervasion and the property of the subject due to the knowledge of the absence of the substratum, etc. This is the meaning.

analyzed: etāvatā iti
translated: By this much means

analyzed: bhāva pramā vyatireka nimitta tva mātre ca bhāvi pramā vyatirekam prati asādhāraṇa kāraṇa tvam āśraya abhāva jñānānām asti iti arthaḥ
translated: And the meaning is that the knowledge of the absence of the substratum has the mere nature of being the cause of the distinction from the cognition of the existent as the non-common cause with regard to the distinction from the future cognition.

original: tāvatā hetvābhāsādhikyaṃ kuto netyata āha tacceti//
analyzed: tāvatā hetvābhāsa ādhikyam kutas na iti atas āha tat ca iti
translated: How is it that there is no excess of fallacious reasons by that much? To this he says: That, etc.

original: bhāvapramāvyatirekaṃ prati yadasādhāraṇaṃ kāraṇaṃ tadeveha hetvābhāsaprakaraṇe vibhajcamānatvena nirūpyata ityarthaḥ/
analyzed: bhāva pramā vyatirekam prati yat asādhāraṇam kāraṇam tat eva iha hetvābhāsa prakaraṇe vibhajcamāna tvena nirūpyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the non-common cause with regard to the distinction from the cognition of the existent, which is alone, is described here in the chapter on fallacious reasons as what is being distinguished.

original: iti sāmyāditi//🔽tathā ca sādhyābhāvavyāptarūpaviruddhasyānaikāntikadvayasya cāvyāptitvenaikadūṣaṇatvameva na tu tvaduktaprakāreṇānekahetvābhāsatvamiti bhāvaḥ//
analyzed: iti sāmyāt iti  tathā ca sādhya abhāva vyāpta rūpa viruddhasya anaikāntika dvayasya ca avyāpti tvena eka dūṣaṇa tvam eva na tu tvad ukta prakāreṇa aneka hetvābhāsa tvam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Thus, by parity of reasoning.🔽And the meaning is that since the contradictory, which has the nature of pervasion by the absence of the probandum, and the two kinds of inconclusive, have the nature of non-pervasion, they are indeed a single fault, but not the nature of many fallacious reasons in the manner stated by you.

analyzed: ṇa tvam ga tat ca iha kagarā bhāvapraṭaṭhaḍa
translated: The nature of being a fallacy is G. And that is here divided by the section on fallacious reasons.

analyzed: anumā doṣa vādaḥ
translated: The chapter on the refutation of fallacies in inference, composed by Līlā.

analyzed: kim ca pratirodhasya api sarva kārya sādhāraṇa doṣa tvāt hetvābhāsa tvam na syāt
translated: Moreover, since contradiction is also a fault common to all effects, it should not be a fallacy of a reason.

original: yadi ca satpratikṣasya dvedhā pratibandhakatāsādhāraṇyasādhāraṇī ca tatrāsādhāraṇamanumitipratibandhakatvamādāya
analyzed: yadi ca dvedhā pratibandhaka tā sādhāraṇā asādhāraṇī ca tatra asādhāraṇam anumiti pratibandhaka tvam ādāya
translated: And if the contradictory of the existent has double the nature of an impediment - generality and particularity - then, taking the particularity of being an impediment to inference,
the fallacy of the reason is the same as the impediment to the valid knowledge of the existent, which has double the nature of an impediment.
The refutation of the non-mixture of fallacies of reasons stated by Maṇikaṇṭha.

original: nanvabhāvajñānasya bhāvapramāvyatirekahetutve hetvābhāsatvarūpāsādhāraṇadoṣatvaṃ vyāptyabhāvajñānasya na syādityataḥ pratibandīmukhena samādhātumāha
analyzed: nanu abhāva jñānasya bhāva pramā vyatireka hetu tve hetvābhāsa tva rūpa asādhāraṇa doṣa tvam vyāpti abhāva jñānasya na syāt iti atas pratibandī mukhena samādhātum āha
translated: If the knowledge of non-existence is the cause of the exclusion of the valid knowledge of existence, then the particularity of being a fallacy of reason, which is the nature of being a fault not common to all, would not be the knowledge of the absence of pervasion. Therefore, in order to resolve this by way of a counter-question, he says

analyzed: kim ca iti  sarva kāryā iti
translated: Moreover, etc.🔽All effects means🔽all effects other than inference.
The meaning is that being a fallacy of reason is being a fault not common to all reasons.

analyzed: para mukhena uttaram vācayitvā samam iti āha yadi ca iti
translated: Having made the opponent state the answer, he says it is the same if.

analyzed: samam iti
translated: The same means

analyzed: tathāca asādhāraṇam anumiti pratibandhaka tvam ādāya hetvābhāsa tvam bhaviṣyati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: and thus, taking the particularity of being an impediment to inference, there will be the nature of being a fallacy of reason. This is the meaning.
The refutation of the non-mixture of fallacies of reasons stated by Maṇikaṇṭha.
Refutation of the fourfold division of fallacious reasons stated by Līlāvatī.

analyzed: līlāvatyām tu
translated: But in Līlāvatī,

analyzed: asiddha viruddha savyabhicāra anadhyavasitāḥ catvāraḥ hetvābhāsāḥ
translated: the four fallacious reasons are the unestablished, the contradictory, the over-pervading, and the inconclusive.

analyzed: bādha pratirodhau tu pūrva ukta rītyā
translated: But contradiction and obstruction, as stated earlier,
Refutation of the fourfold division of fallacious reasons stated by Līlāvatī.

analyzed: līlāvatyām tu iti
translated: But in Līlāvatī,

analyzed: iti uktam iti anvayaḥ
translated: the meaning is that this is stated.

analyzed: pūrva ukta rītyā iti  dvayī praka garāt ṇa uktaṭa
translated: As stated earlier,🔽as stated in the Dvīpīya-prakaraṇa-granthāraṇya.
The Nyāyadyuti along with the Tarkatāṇḍava, Third Section

analyzed: vyāpti pakṣa dharma tā apa hāreṇa eva doṣau
translated: The faults are only by the absence of pervasion and the property of the subject.

analyzed: na svātantreṇa
translated: Not independently.

analyzed: tatra vyāpti pakṣa dharmatāva tvena aniścitaḥ hetuḥ asiddhaḥ
translated: There, the reason that is not ascertained as having the property of the subject and pervasion is unestablished.

analyzed: tena asiddhi trayasya saṃgrahaḥ
translated: Thus, the three types of unestablished are included.

analyzed: pakṣa eka vṛttiḥ anadhyavasitaḥ
translated: The inconclusive is that which occurs only in the subject.

analyzed: yadi api savyabhicāra viruddha anadhyavasiteṣu vyāpti apramiti rūpā vyāpya tva asiddhiḥ asti
translated: Although in the over-pervading, contradictory, and inconclusive, there is the non-establishment of the pervaded, which is the non-ascertainment of pervasion,

original: tathāpi vyabhicāriṇi parārthānumāne sarvopasaṃhārapravṛttodāharaṇavākyādupādhyasphuraṇadaśāyāṃ vyāptigrahaṇa sambhavāvdyāptyagraho nodbhāvayituṃ
analyzed: tathā api vyabhicāriṇi parārtha anumāne sarva upasaṃhāra pravṛtta udāharaṇa vākyāt upādhya sphuraṇa daśāyām vyāpti grahaṇa sambhavau dyāpti agrahaḥ na udbhāvayitum
translated: Even so, in a fallacious inference for another, when the example sentence that applies to all cases is not functioning, and the condition of the non-manifestation of the counter-example is present, the apprehension of the pervasion is possible, so the non-apprehension of the pervasion cannot be pointed out.

analyzed: śakyaḥ iti vyabhicāraḥ eva udbhāvyaḥ
translated: Therefore, only the fallacy of the counter-example should be pointed out.

original: viruddhe tu viparītapratibandhe vākyasthe 'ntaraṅge sphurati sati bahiraṅgavyāptyajñānādikaṃ nodbhāvyam/
analyzed: viruddhe tu viparīta pratibandhe vākya sthe ntaraṅge sphurati sati bahiraṅga vyāpti ajñāna ādikam nā udbhāvyam
translated: But in the contradictory, when the internal contradiction in the form of the contrary pervasion is manifest, then the ignorance of the external pervasion etc. should not be pointed out.

original: bādhitasthale hetoḥ sādhyābhāvavadvṛttitvena vyāpterapahāreṇa sandigdhasādhyavadvṛttitvābhāvena pakṣadharmatāpa hāreṇetyarthaḥ/
analyzed: bādhita sthale hetoḥ sādhya abhāvavat vṛtti tvena vyāpteḥ apahāreṇa sandigdha sādhyavat vṛtti tva abhāvena pakṣa dharmatā apa hāreṇa iti arthaḥ
translated: In the case of the sublated, the pervasion of the reason with the absence of the probandum is removed, and the doubt regarding its presence in the probandum is removed, and the property of being a logical reason is removed, this is the meaning.

analyzed: dūṣaṇa saukaryāya asiddhi ādeḥ lakṣaṇam āha tatra iti
translated: For the ease of refutation, he states the definition of the unestablished etc. as follows:

analyzed: asiddha trayasya iti
translated: Among them, the three types of unestablished.

analyzed: āśraya asiddha svarūpa asiddha vyāpya tva asiddha rūpa siddha trayasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The three types of unestablished are the unestablished locus, the unestablished form, and the unestablished pervasion.

analyzed: sādhya abhāva vyaptaḥ viruddhaḥ
translated: The contradictory is that which is pervaded by the absence of the probandum.
The fallacious is that which occurs in all three positions. Since these are clear, their definitions are not stated.

analyzed: sāṅkarya śaṅkām anūdya nirāha yadi api ityādinā
translated: Fearing redundancy, he raises the doubt and refutes it with Even though and so on.

analyzed: vyabhicāriṇī iti
translated: Erroneous.

original: anityaḥ śabhdaḥ prameyatvāt yatra prameyatvaṃ tatrānityatvaṃ ghaṭādāviti vyabhicāriṇītyarthaḥ/
analyzed: anityaḥ śabhdaḥ prameya tvāt yatra prameya tvam tatra anitya tvam ghaṭa ādau iti vyabhicāriṇī iti arthaḥ
translated: Sound is non-eternal because it is cognizable, where there is cognisability, there is non-eternality, as in a pot, etc. This is the meaning of 'erroneous'.

original: viparītapratibandha iti//🔽pratibandho vyaptiḥ sādhyābhāvena saha hotorvyāptirūpaviparītavyāptau sphurantyāṃ nityaḥ
analyzed: viparīta pratibandhaḥ iti  pratibandhaḥ vyaptiḥ sādhya abhāvena saha hotoḥ vyāpti rūpa viparīta vyāptau sphurantyām nityaḥ
translated: Contradictory pervasion.🔽When the pervasion in the form of pervasion with the absence of the probandum flashes in the mind, the probandum is🔽Parihara. Haraṅka. Ga. Ra.

analyzed: parihā bdaḥ bdaḥ
translated: In the form of the letter ṭa. By avoiding the letter ṭa. The letter ḍa. The letter ṭa. The letter ḍa.
The chapter on the fallacies stated by Līlā.

original: anumādoṣavādaḥ pu / 🔽anadhyavasite tu vipakṣavyāvṛttimukhena vyatirekaṇavyāpterdarśitatvānna vyāptyasiddhirudbhāvayituṃ śakyā/
analyzed: anumā doṣa vādaḥ  anadhyavasite tu vipakṣa vyāvṛtti mukhena vyatirekaṇa vyāpteḥ darśita tvāt na vyāpti asiddhiḥ udbhāvayitum śakyā
translated: The chapter on the fallacies of inference.🔽But when it is not ascertained, the pervasion of the vyatireka (negative concomitance) by the method of exclusion from the vipakṣa (counter-example) having been shown, the non-establishment of the pervasion cannot be alleged.

original: na cānadhyavasite sandigdhasādhyavatpakṣamātravṛttitvena sādhyābhāvasambandhādvyabhicāra evāstviti vācyam/
analyzed: na ca anadhyavasite sandigdha sādhyavat pakṣa mātra vṛtti tvena sādhya abhāva sambandhāt vyabhicāraḥ eva astu iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that there is indeed the fallacy of vyabhicāra (inconsistency) due to the relation of the absence of the probandum by the mere occurrence in the pakṣa (subject) which is doubtful with regard to the probandum when it is not ascertained.

analyzed: sapakṣa vipakṣayoḥ liṅga jñānasya eva an adhyavasāya rūpa jñāna hetu tvena sarala dūṣaṇatayā udbhāva tvāt
translated: Because the knowledge of the linga (reason) in the sapakṣa (similar instance) and the vipakṣa (counter-example) is the cause of the form of knowledge which is in the form of non-ascertainment, and it is alleged as a simple fault.

analyzed: tad phalataḥ vyabhicāraḥ tu vilambita pratītikaḥ iti uktam ā
translated: But the fallacy of non-concomitance is said to be one where the cognition is delayed.

original: tanna/ vyabhicāriṇi tvayā samarthitena vyabhicārasyodbhāvytavenaiva maduktāvyāpterevodbhāvyatvasiddheḥ/
analyzed: tat na vyabhicāriṇi tvayā samarthitena vyabhicārasya udbhāvya tvena eva mad ukta avyāpteḥ eva udbhāvya tva siddheḥ
translated: That is not so. Because when non-concomitance is established by you, the fallacy of over-extension in my statement is established by you itself by pointing it out.

analyzed: uktam hi sādhya abhāva sambandha rūpaḥ
translated: For it has been said that the form of the relation of the absence of the probandum

analyzed: śabdaḥ kṛtaka tvāt iti vākyāt avagamyamānāyām iti artaḥ
translated: is understood from the sentence Sound is non-eternal because it is produced, the meaning is that.

analyzed: anadhyavasitā itu iti
translated: But when there is doubt,

original: bhūrnityā gandhavatvāt yatra nityatvābhāvaḥ tatra gandhavatvābhāvo jalādāviti sādhyābhāvahetvabhāvayorvipakṣavṛttitmukhena🔽vyatirekavyāpteranadhyavasita prayoktrā darśitatvādityarthaḥ //
analyzed: bhūḥ nityā gandhava tvāt yatra nitya tva abhāvaḥ tatra gandhava tva abhāvaḥ jala ādau iti sādhya abhāva hetu abhāvayoḥ vipakṣa vṛtti t mukhena  vyatireka vyāpteḥ anadhyavasita prayoktrā darśita tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: where there is absence of eternality, there is absence of the property of having smell, as in water etc., the universal concomitance of the absence of the probandum and the absence of the reason by way of occurrence in the contrary🔽has been shown by the proponent who has not ascertained it, this is the meaning.

analyzed: vyabhicāraḥ eva iti
translated: The fallacy of non-concomitance itself,

analyzed: sandhigdha vyabhicāraḥ eva astu iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that let there be only the fallacy of doubt of non-concomitance.🔽Simple,

analyzed: sarala iti akleśa dūṣaṇatayā iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that it is a fault that does not cause difficulty.

analyzed: tad phala bhūtaḥ
translated: The result of that is the knowledge of doubt, which is the result of the fallacy.

analyzed: katham siddhiḥ iti atas āha uktam hi iti
translated: How is it established? To this he says For it has been said etc.

analyzed: sādhāraṇasya avyāptau antarbhāva prastāve prāk uktam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it has been said earlier in the context of the inclusion of the inconclusive in over-extension.

original: yarūpatvena iti yajñānarūpatvena /🔽iti cadvedhā śodhitamasti ṭa / /yathetyadhaikamṭa / /hetupadamadhikamasti ṭa /ḍa / 🔽pu / nyāyadīpayutatarkatāṇḍavam tṛ /paricchedaḥ

analyzed: anumā doṣa vādaḥ

translated: If the non-existence of the reason is to be established by the non-apprehension of the existence of the reason, then the fallacy of contradiction, which is of the form of the absence of pervasion, is also to be established by the non-apprehension of pervasion, so it is the same.

analyzed: viruddhe pi niyata sādhya abhāva saṃbandha rūpāyām viparīta vyāptau mad uktā vyāptiḥ antargatā eva

Nyāyakośa, 3rd Section

translated: Moreover, even in the stage where a favorable argument is introduced, since the knowledge of the reason in similar and dissimilar examples exists, it would follow that it is a fallacy by being an obstruction to inference at that time also. With this in mind, he says thus

The section on the fallacy of the reason, stated by Bhāsarvajña, is concluded.

analyzed: pakṣa traya vṛttinā aikāntikaḥ

analyzed: asādhāraṇa anupasaṃhāriṇau anadhyavasati tā antarbhūtau

analyzed: ekatra tulya bala hetu dvaya upanipātaḥ sa pratipakṣaḥ

analyzed: saḥ eva viruddhavyabhicārī iti ucyate

translated: by the varieties of being unestablished in the basis, unestablished in form, unestablished in being pervaded, unestablished in having a different substratum, and so on.

analyzed: pakṣa traya iti

occurring in the position of the subject, the similar instance, and the dissimilar instance.

analyzed: pakṣaḥ iti arthaḥ

analyzed: tri rūpaḥ iti

analyzed: pakṣa vṛtti tvam sapakṣe satvam vipakṣāt vyāvṛtta tvam iti evam rūpeṇa trirūpaḥ iti arthaḥ

analyzed: iti tat api nirastam

analyzed: vyadhikaraṇa asiddhi ādeḥ adoṣa tva

analyzed: satya dṛśya tvāt brahmavat iti

analyzed: ayam atra niṣkṛṣṭaḥ ṛthaḥ

analyzed: bahudhā ca nirucyāntām

The refutation of the general rule stated by others regarding the fallacies of the reason.

original: śrotrṛbuddhisaukaryāyoktasya sarvasya niṣkṛṣṭamarthamāha ayamatreti//🔽caturvidhā hi vādibhirucyamānāḥ sambhavanti
analyzed: śrotrṛ buddhi saukaryāya uktasya sarvasya niṣkṛṣṭam artham āha ayam atra iti  caturvidhāḥ hi vādibhiḥ ucyamānāḥ sambhavanti

analyzed: hetvābhāsāḥ  pakṣa dharmatā viraha rūpā vā

analyzed: vyāpti viraha rūpā vā

original: vyāptivirahahetubhūtā veti hṛdi nidhāya krameṇāha na tāvadityādinā//

analyzed: ukta tvāt iti na kaga ṭarā sarva ukta dviraha rūpā dviraha hetu bhūta  vāṭhaḍa

analyzed: sa anyena pakta hesanimaṅgaḥ  anumā doṣa vādaḥ

analyzed: na api tad vighaṭakāḥ

analyzed: tvad pakṣe siddhasādhana vat asiddhi unnāyaka tvena svatas doṣa tva ayogāt
translated: Because in your view, like the establishment of what is already established, they cannot be faults by themselves due to being the promoters of the unestablished.

analyzed: nā api vyāpti vighaṭana rūpāḥ

analyzed: avyāpti antarbhāva āpatteḥ

analyzed: na ca hetvābhāsa tve pañcama prakāraḥ sti

analyzed: vyāpti pakṣa dharma tā yukta hetoḥ ābhāsa tva ayogāt

original: kiṃ ca savyabhicāraviruddhānadhyavasiteṣu na tāvadavyāptirnāstīti yuktam/
analyzed: kim ca savyabhicāra viruddha anadhyavasiteṣu na tāvat avyāptiḥ na asti iti yuktam
translated: Moreover, it is not right to say that there is no over-extension in the fallacious, contradictory and indeterminate [reasons],

analyzed: teṣu pakṣa dharma tāyāḥ satvena hetoḥ ābhāsa tva ayogāt
translated: because in those cases the reason cannot be fallacious, since the property of being the subject is present.

original: nāpyavyāpteḥ satve 'pi tadajñā ne 'pi anyajñānādevānumānaṃ duṣṭamiti vācyam/
analyzed: na api avyāpteḥ sattve api anya jñānāt eva anumānam duṣṭam iti vācyam
translated: Nor can it be said that inference is faulty merely by the knowledge of something else, even though over-extension is present.

analyzed: anyasya anumāna avirodhi tve doṣa tva ayāgāt
translated: Because if something else is not contradictory to inference, it cannot be a fault.

analyzed: virodhi tvam api na tāvat sākṣāt phala vighaṭa nena
translated: And contradiction is not, first of all, by directly obstructing the result.

analyzed: bādha pratirodha antarbhāva āpatteḥ
translated: Because that would amount to being included in contradiction and obstruction.

analyzed: na api karaṇa vighaṭa nena
translated: Nor is it by obstructing the means [of knowledge].

analyzed: tathātve
translated: Because if it were so, then either the pervasion or the property of being the subject would be obstructed.

original: nanvastvito 'nya traiva kaścana prakāra ityata āha na ca hetvābhāsa tva iti//
analyzed: nanu astu itas kaścana prakāraḥ iti atas āha na ca hetvābhāsa tve iti
translated: But it is not so. Therefore, it is said that there is no other kind of fallacy of reason than these three.🔽The meaning is that there is no fifth kind other than the four kinds of obstructing the pervasion or the property of being the subject.🔽The kind is just the possession of pervasion and the property of being the subject. Therefore, it is said that pervasion, etc.🔽By another kind, he denies the opponent's accepted restriction of the fallacious reasons such as the uncertain to the five kinds. He says Moreover, etc.

analyzed: vyāpti pakṣa dharmatā tad vighaṭanaka rūpa prakāra catuṣṭaya anyaḥ pañcamaḥ prakāraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no fifth kind other than the four kinds of obstructing the pervasion or the property of being the subject.

analyzed: vyāpti pakṣa dharma tā yuktatvam eva prakāraḥ iti atas āha vyāpti iti
translated: The kind is just the possession of pervasion and the property of being the subject. Therefore, it is said that pervasion, etc.

analyzed: prakāra antareṇa savyabhicāra ādi hetvābhāsa niyamam para abhimatam nirāha kiñca iti 🔽phala iti
translated: By another kind, he denies the opponent's accepted restriction of the fallacious reasons such as the uncertain to the five kinds. He says Moreover, etc.🔽The meaning is that there is no fifth kind other than the four kinds of obstructing the pervasion or the property of being the subject.🔽The kind is just the possession of pervasion and the property of being the subject. Therefore, it is said that pervasion, etc.

analyzed: anumiti rūpa phala iti arthaḥ bādhā iti
translated: The meaning is that the result is in the form of inference. By contradiction, etc.

original: pakṣadharmatvābhāvavyāpyatayā iti pūritamastiṭa / /nakāle bhinnajñāga /ṭa /rā / /ṭakatvena ga /ṭa /rā / /ṭakatvena ga /ṭa /rā / /nya evakaṭa /ṭha /ḍa /
analyzed: pakṣa dharma tva abhāva vyāpya tayā iti na kāle
translated: The completed part is the absence of the property of the subject and the pervasion. At the time of the different cognition, the cognition of the absence of the property of the subject and the pervasion is different from the cognition of the absence of the property of the subject and the pervasion.

analyzed: saḥ iti ḍa
translated: That is the absence of the property of the subject and the pervasion.
The Lamp of Logic, along with the Nyāya, Volume Three

analyzed: vighaṭanasya āvaśyaka tvena avyāpti asiddhi anyatara antarbhāvasya durvāra tvāt
translated: Since the refutation is necessary, the inclusion of either over-extension or non-establishment is unavoidable.

original: etadevābhipretyoktaṃ pramāṇalakṣaṇe asiddhiravyāpti śca hetuvirodha iti//
analyzed: etat eva abhipretya uktam pramāṇa lakṣaṇe asiddhiḥ avyāptiḥ ca hetu virodhaḥ iti
translated: With this very intention, it is said in the Lakṣaṇakārikā: Non-establishment, over-extension, and contradiction of the reason.
The general refutation of the fallacies of reasons stated by others.

original: oṃ iti śrīmatparamahaṃsaparivrājakācāryaśrīmadbrahmaṇyatīrtathapūjyapādānāṃ śiṣyeṇa śrīmavdyāsayatinā viracite śrīmattarkatāṇḍave anumānaprapañcanaṃ
analyzed: om iti śrīmat paramahaṃsa parivrājaka ācārya śrīmat brahmaṇyatīrtatha pūjya pādānām śiṣyeṇa śrīmat dyāsayatinā viracite śrīmat tarkatāṇḍave anumāna prapañcanam
translated: Thus ends the expansion of inference in the Tarkatāṇḍava composed by the illustrious Vyāsayati, a disciple of the illustrious Brahmatīrtha, the revered teacher of the great paramahaṃsa parivrājakācāryas.
The chapter on inference.

analyzed: śrī kṛṣṇa arpaṇaḥ tu
translated: Offered to Lord Kṛṣṇa.

analyzed: tayoḥ grāhya abhāva avagāhi tvena sākṣāt eva anumiti pratibandhaka tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that because they directly contradict inference by engaging in the apprehension of the absence of the object to be grasped.

analyzed: etat eva iti
translated: This very thing.

analyzed: ukta niṣkṛṣṭam prameyam eva abhipretya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he has in mind only the topics that have been stated and distinguished.
The general refutation of the fallacies of reasons stated by others.

original: yatprasādādimāṃ vyākhyāmakārṣaṃ naumi taṃ harim/🔽anasūyāgarbharatnamānvīkṣikyāḥ prakāśakam//
analyzed: yad prasādāt imām vyākhyām akārṣam naumi tam harim  anasūyā garbha ratnam ānvīkṣikyāḥ prakāśakam
translated: By whose grace I have composed this commentary, I pay homage to that Hari,🔽The illuminator of the jewel of Anvikshaki (philosophy) in the womb of Anasunya (Aditi).

analyzed: yat avocam aham tena prīṇātu puruṣottamaḥ
translated: Urged on by the glorious lord of Shri and life,🔽May the Supreme Being be pleased by what I have said.

analyzed: prāyeṇa alasa buddhi tvāt lokānām tad jighṛkṣayā
translated: Mostly due to the dullness of the intellect of people, and with a desire to benefit them,

analyzed: na udgrantham kṣamyatām budhaiḥ  iti śrīmat paramahaṃsa parivrājaka ācārya sudhīndratīrtha guru pāda śiṣya rāghavendrayati kṛte
translated: I have stated only the meaning of the arguments, not the text. May the learned forgive me.🔽Thus ends the third chapter in the commentary on the Tarka-Tandava, called Nyaya-Dipika, composed by Raghavendra Yati,

analyzed: tarkatāṇḍavavivṛttau nyāyadīpe tṛtīyaḥ paricchedaḥ
translated: the disciple of the venerable Sudhindra Tirtha Guru Pada, a teacher of the lineage of Parmahamsa Parivrajakas.

analyzed: saṃvyākhyam tarkatāṇḍavam samāptam
translated: The Tarka-Tandava commentary is complete.

analyzed: śrī kṛṣṇa arpaṇam astu
translated: All glory to Lord Krishna.🔽The end of the third chapter.

analyzed: hega ṭarā kya artham āṭa ṭhaḍa
translated: The end of the Tarka-Tandava commentary.🔽All glory to Lord Krishna.
